subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Survey of African American Literature
description: Literature of blacks in the United States from slavery to freedom. Works of major writers and significant but unsung bards of the past.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Literatures of the Black World
description: Introductory survey of fiction, poetry, drama, folktales, and other literary forms of Africa and the African diaspora. Texts may span the precolonial, colonial, and postcolonial periods and cover central themes, such as memory, trauma, spirituality, struggle, identity, freedom, and humor.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Introduction to African-American History: Key concepts from 1700-1861
description: African origins, the slave trade, origins of slavery and racism in the United States, life under slavery in the North and the South. AF_AM_ST 212-1 and HISTORY 212-1 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Introduction to African American History: Emancipation to Civil Rights Movement
description: Emancipation to the civil rights era. Reconstruction, rise of legal segregation, strategies of resistance, migration, and urbanization. AF_AM_ST 212-2 and HISTORY 212-2 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: History of the Black World
description: Introductory survey of the history of Africans and their descendants across the globe. African civilizations prior to European colonialism, encounters between Africa and Europe, movements of "Africans" to the Americas and elsewhere, and development of black communities in and outside Africa.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Comparative Race and Ethnic Studies
description: Problems and experiences of racialized minorities: blacks, Native Americans, Asian Americans, and Latina/os. Comparison of their relationships with each other and with the majority society.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Introduction to Black Social & Political Life
description: Analysis of class, gender, sexuality, immigrant status, and ethnic origin in black society and politics. Focus on demographic trends, lived experiences, and ideological debates.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Asian/Black Historical Relations in the U.S.
description: Comparative historical analysis of relations of these groups in the United States, including racialized and sexualized discourses structuring interracial relations and social, political, and economic location. Slavery, immigration, model minority myth, cross-racial politics. AF_AM_ST 218-0 and ASIAN_AM 218-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Civil Rights and Black Liberation
description: The Northern and Southern civil rights movements and the rise of black nationalism and feminism, 1945-72.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: African-American Culture
description: Survey of African American culture from slavery to the present. Relation of African American culture to African and Euro-American cultures, the Black Atlantic as a unit of analysis, representations of blackness in the public imagination.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Introduction to African-American Studies
description: Introduction to the discipline of black studies using key historical and theoretical texts.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: The Black Diaspora and Transnationality
description: Examination of events, movements, theories, and texts that have shaped development of the African diaspora. Topics include slavery, abolitionism, pan-Africanism, the culture-politics nexus, hip-hop, AIDS, and linkages among gender, sexuality, and diasporic sensibilities.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Race, Class and Gender
description: Introduction to scholarship and key theories that treat race, class, and gender as intersecting social constructs. Race, class, and gender in work, family and reproduction, education, poverty, sexuality, and consumer culture. How race, class, and gender inform identity, ideology, and politics to incite social change.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: The Mixed Race Experience
description: Exploration of demographic trends in interracial and interethnic marriages to highlight the complexity of the American experience. Special attention to mixed-race experiences portrayed in film and novels. AF_AM_ST 251-0 and ASIAN_AM 251-0 are taught together; students may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Introduction to African-American Drama
description: Thematic and historical survey of African American drama. Sociopolitical context, the aesthetic reflected in the work, impact on African American and general theater audiences.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Queer Literatures in the African Diaspora
description: Advanced introduction to critical theories of race, gender, and sexuality in the African diaspora from the 19th century to today.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Contemporary Asian Black Relations
description: Divides between these groups, as well as areas of positive cross-cultural collaboration. Historical analysis of reparations, the 1992 Los Angeles riots, and affirmative action. Cross-racial exchange in youth expressions, popular culture, hip-hop. AF_AM_ST 310-0 and ASIAN_AM 310-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Religion in the Black Atlantic
description: Afro-Atlantic religions since the 1400s; traditions of Orisa devotion and monotheisms; religion and revolution in African slave religion; racialization and empire; theories of religion, materialities, and diaspora.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Race, Ethnicity and the American Constitution
description: Investigation of how race and ethnicity have influenced the evolution of the US Constitution and legal debate and practice. Topics include affirmative action, school integration, and the death penalty.
prereq: AF_AM_ST 220-0 or either POLI_SCI 220-0 or POLI_SCI 230-0

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Social Meaning of Race
description: Race as a social concept and recurrent cause of differentiation in multiracial societies. Impact of race on social, cultural, economic, and political institutions. Discussion of prejudice, racism, and discrimination.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Politics of Black Popular Culture
description: Examination of the debates within black communities about the proper role and function of black art and artists in relation to black politics.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Black Women in the 20th Century
description: Experiences and leadership of African American women in major events in recent history, including anti-lynching, women's suffrage, civil rights movements, and World War II.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: The African American Novel
description: Readings in classic black American fiction. The author as creator and participant. Works of Wright, Ellison, Baldwin, and others.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Gender and Black Masculinity
description: Perceptions and constructions of black masculinity within African American and "American" cultures in the United States; readings in gender and sexuality studies, feminist theory, African American studies, and cultural studies.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Race and Literature in 19th Century America
description: Examination of the evolution and persistence of the notion of "race" in 19th century America, with attention to the origins of the idea of race in the West. Focus on the multiracial character of 19th century America.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Unsettling Whiteness
description: Making the historical, political, and cultural formation of whiteness in Western modernity visible and narratable for commentary and analysis. Particular reference to contemporary culture.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Comparative Slavery
description: Traces slavery across historical epochs and geographic contexts, with an emphasis on Latin America, the Caribbean, and the United States.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Afro-Latin America
description: Exploration of Afro-Latin communities, cultures, and identities throughout Latin America and the Hispanic diaspora after 1800. Emergence of race and nation in modern Latin America, migration, gender, Afro-Latin spiritual systems and religion, family, and politics.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Africans in Colonial Latin America
description: History of Africans and African-descended people throughout Latin America from 1492 to 1800, emphasizing the varied experiences of slavery and freedom struggles, the emergence of race and colonial categories of difference, and the gendered lives of racialized colonial subjects.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Theorizing Blackness
description: Advanced introduction to critical theories of race and racialization. Investigation of blackness as a category of critical analysis for analyzing Afro-diasporic formations. Consideration of how blackness is shaped by gender, class, sexuality, and nationality.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Diaspora Studies
description: Interdisciplinary examination of the significance of diasporas, their histories, and common dynamics, illustrated with examples drawn from a wide range of cases.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Performing Memory in the Black World
description: Exploration of the ways in which peoples of the Black Atlantic remember slavery and fashion identities through novels, film, folktales, and drama.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Major Authors
description: In-depth examination of a selected author's body of work. Choice of author varies. May be repeated for credit with change of author.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Racism in Western Modernity
description: Impact of racism in the formation of Western modernity. Critical conceptual and historical analyses of the social formation of "race" and the historical implications of racism in the contemporary West.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Black Chicago
description: Surveys the social, cultural, and political history of African Americans in Chicago, including the Great Migration, the black political machine, black Chicago music, racial segregation, internal class stratification, and the role of black churches.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Post Colonial African American Studies
description: Development of critical approaches to African American studies from the perspectives of postcolonial analysis. In particular, examination of the meaning of the colonial in the formation of African American experiences and the significance of modernity, race, and black politics in the historical contexts of the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Harlem Renaissance
description: African American political and social movements and cultural production in theater, music, visual arts, and literature from 1915 to 1930.
prereq: AF_AM_ST 210-0 or another African American literature course

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Black Women Writers
description: Intensive, multi-genre examination of the contribution of black women to African American, women's, and American literature, with consideration of the factors and figures that have influenced the reception of black women's writings across time.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Topics in African-American Studies
description: Advanced work on social, cultural, or historical topics. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Topics in Transnational Black Studies
description: Examination of texts such as novels, poetry, film, drama, slave narratives, political manifestos, and historical texts in order to compare how people from across the African diaspora have approached issues of identity, culture, and community.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Research Seminar
description: Methods of researching the African American experience. Identification of research problems; location, selection, and critique of relevant literature; data gathering and analysis; report writing. Topics vary.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Internship in African-American Studies
description: Analysis of social and cultural institutions through field study and participant observation. Entails a research project sponsored by a Northwestern faculty member.

subject: AF_AM_ST
name: Independent Study
description: Open to advanced students with consent of instructor.

subject: AFST
name: First-Year Seminar
description: Freshman seminars in African Studies are small, writing and discussion-oriented courses geared to the investigation of a specific theme or issue and intended to hone your abilities as a critical thinker and effective writer.

subject: AFST
name: African Literature in Translation
description: Continental African literature. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Taught with COMP_LIT 270-0; may not receive credit for both courses with same topic.

subject: AFST
name: Culture, Language, and Identity in South Africa
description: Introduction to South African populations and cultures through direct experience and representations in history, art, literature, languages, and customs. Discussions of South African cultures and ethnicity, language use and policy, and identity. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

subject: AFST
name: Topics in African Studies
description: A general examination of topics relevant to African studies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

subject: AFST
name: Topics in African Studies
description: A general examination of topics relevant to African studies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

subject: AFST
name: Herskovits Undergraduate Research Award
description: 2-course sequence required for recipients of the Herskovits Undergraduate Research Award. Consecutive enrollment required in AFST 392-2.

subject: AFST
name: Herskovits Undergraduate Research Award
description: 2-course sequence required for recipients of the Herskovits Undergraduate Research Award.

subject: AFST
name: Senior Research Seminar
description: Capstone seminar addressing both techniques of research and the substance of a significant issue in African studies. Students develop skills at formulating a research topic and organizing research.

subject: AFST
name: Independent Study
description: May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: AMER_ST
name: Seminar for Majors
description: Set of required courses structured to share a broad comparativist or internationally oriented theme, integrating methods and materials from different disciplines. Change of instructor each quarter; change of theme every year. Limited to 20 students.

subject: AMER_ST
name: Seminar for Majors
description: Set of required courses structured to share a broad comparativist or internationally oriented theme, integrating methods and materials from different disciplines. Change of instructor each quarter; change of theme every year. Limited to 20 students.

subject: AMER_ST
name: Seminar for Majors
description: Set of required courses structured to share a broad comparativist or internationally oriented theme, integrating methods and materials from different disciplines. Change of instructor each quarter; change of theme every year. Limited to 20 students.

subject: AMER_ST
name: Studies in American Culture
description: Readings and discussions of topics in American cultural life-for example, law in 20th century America or television news in contemporary US culture. Limited enrollment with emphasis on student participation. Prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with consent of program director.

subject: AMER_ST
name: Senior Project
description: Thesis or field study. Required of majors.

subject: AMER_ST
name: Senior Project
description: Thesis or field study. Required of majors.

subject: AMER_ST
name: Independent Study
description: Readings and conferences on special subjects for students pursuing their theme within the major.

subject: ANTHRO
name: First-Year Seminar
description: Open to first-year students in Weinberg College; does not satisfy major/minor requirements in Anthropology.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Culture & Society
description: Introduction to the comparative study of culture, exploring different types of social organization and their economic and political correlates in the context of contemporary globalization.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Human Origins
description: Emergence of the human species through the process of organic evolution, emphasizing genetics, the fossil record, and comparison with our nearest living relatives.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Archaeology: Unearthing History
description: The evolution of culture from its earliest beginnings through the development of urbanism and the state. Principles of archaeological research.

subject: ANTHRO
name: The Study of Culture through Language
description: The scope of linguistic anthropology, from the study of language as an end in itself to the investigation of cultures through the medium of human languages.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Social and Health Inequalities
description: Bidirectional relationship between social (e.g., class, gender, and racial/ethnic) and health inequalities, including institutional/structural, individual/family/psychosocial, and biological mechanisms.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Myth and Symbolism
description: Introduction to different approaches to the interpretation of myth and symbolism, e.g., Freudian, functionalist, and structuralist.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Language in Asian America
description: Survey of linguistic anthropological topics relevant to Asian American communities, including bilingualism, code switching, language socialization, language shift, style, sociolinguistic variation, indexicality, media, and semiotics. ANTHRO 235-0 and ASIAN_AM 235-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Anthropology of Money
description: A survey of cultural and ethnographic approaches to money and finance. Topics of investigation include “primitive money,” the uses of money in religious and ritual practices, social and cultural meanings of numbers, mobile money, crypto-currency and other alternative currency systems, and the politics of central banking.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Porous Borders? Geography, Power and Techniques of Movement
description: At the advent of globalization scholars have argued that the movements of capital, commodities and people across nation-states have rendered their borders increasingly porous. The death of the nation-state was announced elsewhere. Yet, in the epoch of offshored refugee processing centers and border walls, this assumed porosity of borders begs a reexamination of broader geographies of power and techniques of movement.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Contemporary African Worlds
description: Use of key anthropological insights about value judgments and cultural relativism to examine the survival strategies and turbulent histories of contemporary African societies.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Topics in Anthropology
description: Intermediate work in areas of developing interest and special significance. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Evolution of Life Histories
description: Evolved strategies for allocating resources among growth, reproduction, and maintenance; emphasis on the biological processes underlying the human life cycle and its evolution.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Anthropology of Peace
description: Cultural and ethnographic approaches to peace, peace building and peace activism. Topics of investigation include the concept of "peaceful societies," cultural mechanisms for conflict resolution, truth and reconciliation, the relationship between peace and commerce, and the role of literature, art and material culture in peace activism.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Human Osteology
description: Introduction to human skeletal anatomy and biology. Identification and classification of human bones through hands-on dry-lab-based analysis.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Indians of North America
description: Aboriginal cultures of northern Mexico, continental United States, Alaska, and Canada. Languages, art, and social, economic, and religious life.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Human Population Biology
description: Current theory and research in human biological diversity, focusing on the impact of ecological and social factors on human biology; how adaptation to environmental stressors promotes human biological variation.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Evolutionary Medicine
description: In this course we explore how evolution has made our bodies susceptible to the role of environments and social forces, including factors like stress, discrimination and inequality. We consider fields at the interface of the social and biological, including genetics, epigenetics and social epidemiology.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Human Growth & Development
description: Integrated biological and cultural perspective on human growth and development from infancy through adolescence; cross-cultural variation in developmental processes and outcomes.
prereq: 100-or 200-level anthropology, biology, or psychology course or consent of instructor

subject: ANTHRO
name: Medical Anthropology
description: Theories of interactions between culture and biology that affect human health. Beliefs and practices for curing illness and maintaining wellbeing. Cross-cultural study of infectious and chronic diseases, mental illness, infant/maternal mortality, poverty, and gender.
prereq: 100-or 200-level anthropology or sociology course or consent of instructor

subject: ANTHRO
name: Forensic Anthropology
description: The application of traditional skeletal biology to problems of medicolegal significance, primarily in determining identity and analyzing trauma from human remains.
prereq: 200-level anthropology or biology course or consent of instructor

subject: ANTHRO
name: Human Evolution
description: Fossil record and reconstruction of phylogeny; morphological and behavioral adaptation of early hominids and forebears.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Material Worlds of the Middle Ages
description: Landscapes, buildings, and material culture of medieval Europe, as seen through archaeology and related disciplines.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Material Life & Culture in Europe, 1500-1800
description: Landscapes, buildings, and material culture of early modern Europe, as seen through archaeology and related disciplines.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Peoples of Africa
description: A survey of the cultures of Africa and the significant similarities and differences among the indigenous societies of the continent.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Archaeological Field Methods
description: Practical training in basic methods and techniques at an excavation site; given with summer Archaeology Field School.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Archaeological Field Methods
description: Practical training in basic methods and techniques at an excavation site; given with summer Archaeology Field School.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Introduction to Archaeology Research Design & Methods
description: Regional and site-specific approaches to the description and analysis of patterns in archaeological data, including settlement survey, site characterization, vertical excavations, and horizontal household excavations.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Archaeological Survey Methods
description: Unique contributions of archaeological surveys to research about past peoples and places. Course uses geospatial technologies, such as shallow geophysics and GIS.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Archaeological Methods Laboratory
description: Analysis of archaeological methods (faunal, botanical, artifact, or soil analysis) with various techniques. May be repeated for credit.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Archaeology of Ethnicity in America
description: History of different ethnic groups in America as shown through living quarters, burials, food remains, tools, jewelry, etc. How groups have been portrayed in museums claiming to depict the American past. Focus on African Americans and Native Americans.

subject: ANTHRO
name: The Maya
description: The archaeology of the Maya in Latin America; life and society in pre-Columbian Maya civilization.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Peoples of the World
description: Comparative ethnography of a regionally or historically associated group of cultures or a type of community defined in ecological, ideological, or other terms. May be repeated for credit.

subject: ANTHRO
name: The Anthropology of Reproduction
description: Marriage and reproduction throughout the world, particularly the developing world and Africa. Conjugal strategies, fertility, contraception.

subject: ANTHRO
name: The Anthropology of HIV/AIDS: Ethnographies
description: The experiences of HIV-positive people; local and global policies shaping access to treatment; contributions of anthropologists to reducing HIV/AIDS globally. Readings from classic and current ethnographies.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Material Culture
description: Relationship between material objects and social life; review of theoretical approaches to gifts and commodities; ethnographic collecting in colonial and postcolonial settings; relationship between culture and aesthetics.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Visual Anthropology of Africa
description: Anthropological analysis of techniques, visual rhetoric, and narrative strategies embedded in images of Africa and Africans in a variety of contemporary and digital media. Course includes instruction in video production.
prereq: 200-level social science or African studies course or consent of instructor

subject: ANTHRO
name: Economic Anthropology
description: Economic organization in small-scale non-industrialized communities. Traditional structures of primitive and peasant economies.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Anthropology of Race
description: Anthropological approaches to the analysis of race, racialization, and antiracism. Human variation, space, segregation, comparative analysis, and language ideologies.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Anthropology of Religion
description: The human relationship with the supernatural. Action patterns accompanying beliefs. Comparison of nonliterate religions and historical religions.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Hope and Futurity
description: An in‐depth survey of anthropological, sociological, literary, philosophical and religious explorations into the problem of hope.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Shady Business: Informal Economies in Contemporary Capitalism
description: Taking stock of world economic changes such as the collapse of socialism, the advent of globalization as well as the intensification of transnational labor migration, this course aims to reveal the categorical distinctions drawn between formal and informal economies in contemporary capitalism as historically situated and politically charged constructs.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Gender and Anthropology
description: Cross-cultural survey of women's roles from three perspectives: biosocial, sociocultural, politico-economic. Theory of gender inequality. Emphasis on the third world.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Sexualities
description: Cross-cultural survey of sexuality from an anthropological perspective. Focus on first half of the 20th century, the 1970s, 1980s, and the turn of the 21st century.

subject: ANTHRO
name: The Human Microbiome and Health
description: Discussion-based analysis of cutting edge research on the microbes associated with the human body and their impacts on health. Consideration of historical, social, and political influences on observed patterns.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Language and Culture
description: Relationship between language and culture; language as the vehicle of culture and as the manifestation of thought.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Talk as Social Action
description: Analysis of talk in interaction based on examination of audio and video recorded data and associated transcripts. Conversation, action, turn, sequence, relevance, social structure, qualitative methodologies.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Advanced Methods in Quantitative Analysis
description: Advanced applications of univariate and multivariate statistics to anthropological research questions.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Language, Race, & Ethnicity in the U.S.
description: Analysis of connections between language ideologies, language use, and meanings of race and ethnicity. Bilingualism, immigration, identity, accented English, African American English, language policy, English only movement, education, social change. ANTHRO 365-0 and ASIAN_AM 365-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Latina and Latino Ethnography
description: Sociocultural analysis of US Latina/o communities. Examines ethnographies by and about Latina/os based in the United States. Draws on a broad disciplinary basis to critique and elaborate on ethnographic methods and epistemologies.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Contemporary Immigration to the U.S.
description: Major theories in immigration studies; contemporary processes of immigration and immigrant "community building" in the United States.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Anthropology in Historical Perspective
description: Major schools of thought in social, archaeological, and biological anthropology over the last century.
prereq: 200-level anthropology course or consent of instructor

subject: ANTHRO
name: Power and Culture in American Cities
description: Overview of history and present realities of American urban life, with focus on ethnographic knowledge and stratifications by class, race, ethnicity, gender, nationality, and sexuality.
prereq: 100-or 200-level cultural anthropology or sociology course or consent of instructor

subject: ANTHRO
name: Socialization
description: Cross-cultural study of the intergenerational transmission of culture; processes by which social groups pass on social tradition and behavior to succeeding generations.
prereq: ANTHRO 211-0, introductory psychology course, or consent of instructor

subject: ANTHRO
name: Psychological Anthropology
description: Contemporary approaches to cross-cultural behavior: ecocultural aspects of behavior development through maturation and socialization in human and nonhuman primates.
prereq: introductory survey course in psychology or anthropology or consent of instructor

subject: ANTHRO
name: Law and Culture
description: Introduction to the anthropology of law; institutional knowledge as seen in material culture and legal documents; colonial and postcolonial settings; relationships between law and culture, colonialism, evidence, and globalization.
prereq: 200-level anthropology course or consent of instructor

subject: ANTHRO
name: Environmental Anthropology
description: How humans have changed and are changing the environment and what can be done to halt environmental deterioration. Topics include population trends, food supplies, consumerism, environmental regulation, and ecological consciousness.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Traveling While Muslim: Islam, Mobility, and Security after 9/11
description: What are the stakes of traveling while Muslim in that post 9/11 era of racing Islam? How do we come to understand such mobility? In probing these questions, amongst others, in this seminar we aim to examine the interlocked relationship between Islam, mobility and security.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Methods in Human Biology Research
description: Laboratory-based introduction to international research in human biology and health; methods for assessing nutritional status, physical activity, growth, cardiovascular health, endocrine and immune function.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Ethnographic Methods and Analysis
description: Descriptive, naturalistic study of the culture of human social groups. Data gathering through observation and interview. Data analysis for ethnographic reporting.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Topics In Anthropology
description: Advanced work in areas of developing interest and special significance. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Topics In Anthropology
description: Advanced work in areas of developing interest and special significance. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Senior Seminar
description: Supervised group discussion of research during preparation of the senior capstone project.

subject: ANTHRO
name: Independent Study
description: Open with consent of department to juniors and seniors who have completed with distinction at least 2 courses or the equivalent in anthropology. Under direction of individual members of department.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic I
description: Three-course introduction to modern standard Arabic primarily, along with some expo-sure to and familiarization with the main regional spoken varieties. Speaking, reading, listening comprehension, and basic writing skills developed.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic I
description: Three-course introduction to modern standard Arabic primarily, along with some expo-sure to and familiarization with the main regional spoken varieties. Speaking, reading, listening comprehension, and basic writing skills developed.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic I
description: Three-course introduction to modern standard Arabic primarily, along with some expo-sure to and familiarization with the main regional spoken varieties. Speaking, reading, listening comprehension, and basic writing skills developed.

subject: ARABIC
name: Conversation and Culture in the Arab World
description: Introduction to spoken colloquial Arabic of a country or region-for example, Egyptian, Levantine, or Moroccan. Emphasis on spoken language and conversation. May be repeated for credit with different dialect.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic II
description: Further development of grammar knowledge, reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills. Completion of at least this level is recommended for students seeking functional proficiency for study abroad.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic II
description: Further development of grammar knowledge, reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills. Completion of at least this level is recommended for students seeking functional proficiency for study abroad.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic II
description: Further development of grammar knowledge, reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills. Completion of at least this level is recommended for students seeking functional proficiency for study abroad.

subject: ARABIC
name: Media Arabic
description: Introduction to vocabulary, expressions, and terminology used in Arab print and broadcast media. Supplements study in modern standard Arabic. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic III
description: Continued skills development through reading, writing, and discussion of Arabic writings from both textbooks and media resources.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic III
description: Continued skills development through reading and discussion of Arabic writings from both textbooks and media resources.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic III
description: Continued skills development through reading, writing, and discussion of Arabic writings from both textbooks and media resources.

subject: ARABIC
name: Language and Culture
description: Varied topics.

subject: ARABIC
name: Current Events in the Middle East: Arab Society through Online News Media
description: This course focuses on current events in the Middle East through in‐depth exploration of online News Media sources such as foreign newspaper articles and videos. Students will gain respect for alternative ideas and diversity of views as expressed in Arab news. The course focuses on reading, listening, discussion as well as building a comprehensive vocabulary in MSA and dialect.
prereq: ARABIC 121-3 and ARABIC 125-0 or permission of the instructor. May be repeated for credit with different topic

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic IV
description: Continuation of instruction in Arabic using textbooks and supplemental materials from literary sources (prose and poetry) and broadcast and print media. Emphasis on developing more advanced writing skills.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic IV
description: Continuation of instruction in Arabic using textbooks and supplemental materials from literary sources (prose and poetry) and broadcast and print media. Emphasis on developing more advanced writing skills.

subject: ARABIC
name: Arabic IV
description: Continuation of instruction in Arabic using textbooks and supplemental materials from literary sources (prose and poetry) and broadcast and print media. Emphasis on developing more advanced writing skills.

subject: ARABIC
name: Reading Arabic Poetry
description: Development of Advanced Modern Standard Arabic through reading and analyzing Arabic Poetry. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Open to heritage speakers.

subject: ARABIC
name: Reading Classical Arabic Texts
description: Development of Advanced Modern Standard Arabic through reading and analyzing classical Arabic texts. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Open to heritage speakers.

subject: ARABIC
name: Reading Modern Arabic Prose
description: Development of Advanced Modern Standard Arabic through reading and analyzing Modern Arabic prose. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Open to heritage speakers.

subject: ARABIC
name: Independent Study
description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Arabic.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to Art History
description: Conceptual introduction to the problems and methods of art history. Introduces professors and their areas of expertise as well as fundamental concepts, monuments, and objects in art history.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to African Art
description: Introduction to art making in Africa; historical periods and regions of focus may vary depending on instructor.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to Art of the African Diaspora
description: Introduction to the visual arts and art history of the African diaspora, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the United States, from the 19th century to present day.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to Ancient Art
description: Introduction to the art and architecture of the ancient Near Eastern, Egyptian, Aegean, Greek, and Roman worlds.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to Medieval Art
description: Introduction to the art and architecture of Europe and the Middle East from the third to fifteenth centuries CE.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to Pre-Columbian Art
description: Introduction to South, Central and North American art and architecture before extended European contact.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to American Art
description: Survey of North American art and architecture in its cultural context, from the art of conquest to contemporary production.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to the History of Architecture and Design
description: The theory and history of architecture in relation to cities and landscape; historical periods and regions of focus may vary depending on the instructor.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to Latin American Art
description: Survey of the work of artists and groups from throughout the various countries of Central and South America from colonial times to the present.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to Asian Art
description: Introduction to the art and architecture of Asia from ancient cultures to contemporary developments, including religious, court, and popular genres. Depending on the instructor, this course covers South/Southeast Asia or East Asia.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to European Art
description: Leading centers and artists of Europe from the later Middle Ages to the 19th century, with attention to their global context. Architecture, sculpture, painting, and graphic arts in relation to their social and cultural settings.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to Modernism
description: Conceptual introduction to modernism, covering art and visual culture from the late-19th century to the mid-20th century, with a focus on Europe and the United States.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Introduction to Contemporary Art
description: Conceptual and thematic introduction to art since the 1960s, with attention to the impact of new technologies, social and political change, globalization, and the ongoing transformation of artistic production and distribution.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Ancient Art: Greece
description: Art and architecture of Greece from the prehistoric Aegean to the Hellenistic periods.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Ancient Art
description: Art and architecture of the Roman world from Etruscan forerunners to the High Empire.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Exhibiting Antiquity: The Culture and Politics of Display
description: Examination of the construction of Mediterranean antiquity through modes of reception since 1750. Analysis of programs of collecting and display and the intersection of institutional and scholarly agendas. ART_HIST 318-0, CLASSICS 397-0 and HUM 397-0 taught together; may receive credit for only 1 of these courses.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics in Ancient Art
description: Content varies-for example, monsters and civilization; monument and commemoration in antiquity; narrative in ancient art; and the Roman provinces.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Medieval Art Byzantine
description: Art and architecture of the Byzantine (Eastern Roman) empire in its larger Meditterranean, Middle Eastern and Eastern European context from the fourth to fifteenth century.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Medieval Art: Early Medieval
description: Art and architecture of the Europe from late antiquity to the twelfth century.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Medieval Art: Late Medieval
description: Art and architecture of Europe from the twelfth to fifteenth centuries.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics in Medieval Art
description: Content varies-for example, the early Christian church; history of illuminated manuscripts; pilgrimage and saints' cults; the cathedral; Spain; art and crusade.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Renaissance Art c. 1300-1550 (High Renaissance)
description: Painting, sculpture, architecture, and the graphic arts in Europe from c.1300-1550 (High Renaissance).

subject: ART_HIST
name: Renaissance and Mannerism: Southern European Art 1400-1600
description: Painting, sculpture, architecture, and the graphic arts in Southern Europe from 1400-1600.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Renaissance and Mannerism: Northern European Art 1400-1600
description: Painting, sculpture, architecture, and the graphic arts in Northern Europe from 1400-1600.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics in Renaissance and Mannerist Art
description: Content varies-for example, the art of Bosch and Brueghel; the history of collecting; art at court; portraiture; gender and representation.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Baroque Art: Southern Europe 1600-1700
description: Painting, sculpture, and the graphic arts in Southern Europe from 1600-1700.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Baroque Art: Northern Europe 1600-1700
description: Painting, sculpture, and the graphic arts in Northern Europe from 1600-1700.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics in Baroque Art
description: Content varies-for example, global baroque; early modern prints and drawings; art and science.

subject: ART_HIST
name: 19th-Century Art 1: Late 18th Century-1848
description: Survey of European painting and sculpture from the mid-18th century to 1848.

subject: ART_HIST
name: 19Th-Century Art 2: 1848-1900
description: Survey of European painting and sculpture, 1848-1900.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics in 19Th Century Art
description: Content varies-for example, the art of Edouard Manet; orientalism; the spaces of 19th-century art; painting in the south of France.

subject: ART_HIST
name: 20th Century Art 1
description: Painting, sculpture, architecture, design, and visual culture of the 20th century. 1900-1945.

subject: ART_HIST
name: 20th Century European Art
description: Painting, sculpture, architecture, design, and visual culture of the 20th century. Post-World War II.

subject: ART_HIST
name: American Art I
description: Survey of the arts and visual culture in the United States, encompassing architecture, painting, sculpture, photography, prints, film, and popular culture from colonial times to the Civil War.

subject: ART_HIST
name: American Art II
description: Survey of the arts and visual culture in the United States, encompassing architecture, painting, sculpture, photography, prints, film, and popular culture after the Civil War.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Contemporary Art
description: In-depth study of the art of the late 20th and early 21st centuries as seen from a global perspective and with attention to concurrent developments in critical theory.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics in American Art
description: Content varies-for example, nationalism and internationalism in American art; the myth of America; the artist in American society; elite and popular visual traditions.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics in Modern Art
description: Content varies-for example, art of the Russian Revolution; the avant-garde; totalitarian art; art during war; modernism and its discontents; art and decolonization; medium specificity.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics in 20th Century Art
description: Content varies and may coincide with local exhibitions- for example, art and activism; utopia and dystopia in recent practice; participatory art; video art; art criticism; globalization; visual cultural studies; photography in/as art; installation art; truth and fiction in recent practice.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Modern Architecture and Design
description: The history and theory of architecture, especially in relation to cities and landscape, from 1750-1900.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Contemporary Architecture and Design
description: The history and theory of architecture, especially in relation to cities and landscape, after 1900.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Japanese Art
description: Survey of art in Japan and Japanese culture. Topics may include painting, calligraphy, ceramics, architecture, sculpture, textiles, and gardens in religious and secular settings.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Media Theory
description: Comprehensive introduction from a humanistic perspective to theories about the nature of media and the role of technology in modern culture. ART_HIST 375-0 and HUM 225-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ART_HIST
name: The Global City
description: A critical examination of the city as a socioeconomic system; period and regions of focus vary.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics in Architecture
description: Content varies–may focus on particular cities, building types, or individual historical figures as well as on themes such as race or gender.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Tibetan Buddhist Art 1
description: Focused study of Buddhist art made in Tibet and neighboring countries. Art of the Imperial period (7th-9th centuries) through the end of the 14th century, including regional developments in western Tibet.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Tibetan Buddhist Art 2
description: Focused study of Buddhist art made in Tibet and neighboring countries. Art of the 15th-19th centuries, including regional developments in eastern and northeastern Tibet.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Chinese Painting
description: In-depth study of painting in China with consideration of formal and historical developments.

subject: ART_HIST
name: African American Art
description: Art of the African-descended cultures of North and South America and the Caribbean.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Black Visual Culture: Race and Representation
description: Examination of how visual representations and technologies of vision have been used to create, transform, or destabilize the idea of race as it pertains to people in the African diaspora at specific historical moments.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Art of Africa
description: Thematic and historical examination of the art and visual culture of Africa in selected periods and regions.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Special Topics: Arts of Asia and the Middle East
description: Content varies-for example, aspects of painting in the Indian subcontinent: Mughal and Rajput; issues of gender and sexuality in Japan and China from the 18th through 20th century; art in/about the Middle East.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Content varies- for example, rt and ecology; Picasso; World's Fairs; Japanese prints; the spaces of Chicago.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Art Historical Methods Seminar
description: Introduction to the history of the discipline of art history and to the different methodological approaches to the study of art and visual culture.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Museums
description: Museum studies seminars. Content varies-for example, the history of museums, their ethical basis, community responsibilities, educational prerogatives, and future directions.

subject: ART_HIST
name: Internship in the Arts
description: Direct participation, with oversight by the director of undergraduate studies, in the curatorial/educational activities of an established arts organization. By petition, on a limited basis; may be taken only once.
prereq: 300-level art history course or consent of instructor

subject: ART_HIST
name: Independent Study
description: Special projects involving reading and conferences with a supervising professor. Arranged in exceptional circumstances. Two quarters required for students writing a senior thesis in art history.

subject: ART
name: Introduction to Drawing
description: Introduction to basic drawing techniques and problems in line, space, perception, and the expressive use of various graphic media. No previous experience necessary.

subject: ART
name: Introduction to Painting
description: Introduction to problems in oil painting and visual thinking. Includes surface preparation, color mixing, and composition. No previous experience necessary.

subject: ART
name: Introduction to Time Based Arts
description: Introduction to a wide range of time-based art practices as used in the visual arts, including performance, sound, and video. No previous experience necessary.

subject: ART
name: Introduction to Sculpture
description: Introduction to basic sculptural materials and techniques and issues of three-dimensional form. No previous experience necessary.

subject: ART
name: Introduction to Photography
description: Extensive darkroom instruction focusing on aesthetic problems and the production of high-quality black-and-white prints. No previous experience necessary.

subject: ART
name: Studio Practice
description: Exploration of varied techniques and strategies geared toward the development of an individualized and self-directed studio practice.
prereq: junior standing in the major or consent of instructor

subject: ART
name: Contemporary Art Survey
description: Forms and concerns of art from the 1960s to the present, introduced in slide lecture format.

subject: ART
name: Critical Methods for Contemporary Art
description: Introduction to basic key terms, concepts, and analytical categories of theoretical discourses relevant to an informed and critical engagement with contemporary art.

subject: ART
name: Senior Critique
description: Students complete a body of work to be shown in the senior exhibition, develop their critical skills, and learn to give articulate verbal and written expression to the concerns their art explores.

subject: ART
name: Seminar
description: Variable content, seminar-based course. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Note that some sections of this course are not approved for graduate credit. Please consult the course description.

subject: ART
name: Studio/Seminar
description: Variable content course with both seminar and studio components. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Note that some sections of this course are not approved for graduate credit. Please consult the course description.

subject: ART
name: Studio
description: Variable content, studio-based course. May be repeated for credit with different topic. Note that some sections of this course are not approved for graduate credit. Please consult the course description.

subject: ART
name: Independent Study
description: For advanced majors pursuing projects outside the context of regularly offered courses.
prereq: consent of department chair and director of undergraduate studies

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Topics in Asian American Social and Cultural Analysis
description: Issues and themes in Asian American society and culture. Recent topics include the Arab American studies, student protests, and minority conservatisms. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Introduction to Asian American Studies
description: Origins of the field, emerging trajectories, core concepts, theories and methodologies. Analyzes race, gender, immigration, diaspora, class, labor, and sexuality as primary subjects of the field.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Introduction to Asian American History
description: Introduction to the history of Asians in the United States, with a focus on their impact on American society as well as their experiences within the United States. ASIAN_AM 214-0 and HISTORY 214-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Global Asians
description: Survey of Asian diasporas in the United States and elsewhere in the 19th and 20th centuries, emphasizing causes of migration, process of settlement, relations with other ethnic groups, and construction of diasporic identities. ASIAN_AM 216-0 and HISTORY 216-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Asian/Black Historical Relations in the U.S.
description: Comparative historical analysis of relations of these groups in the United States, including racialized and sexualized discourses structuring interracial relations and social, political, and economic location. Slavery, immigration, model minority myth, cross-racial politics. AF_AM_ST 218-0 and ASIAN_AM 218-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Topics in History
description: Exploration of theme, event, region, or historical period, with emphasis on historical interpretation. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Contemporary Issues in Asian American Communities
description: Critical examination of post-1965 Asian American communities in light of demographic, social, racial, and economic trends in the United States and Asia.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Language in Asian America
description: Survey of linguistic anthropological topics relevant to Asian American communities, including bilingualism, code switching, language socialization, language shift, style, sociolinguistic variation, indexicality, media, and semiotics. ANTHRO 235-0 and ASIAN_AM 235-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Asian Americans and Popular Culture
description: Examination of the varied roles of Asian Americans in U.S. popular culture, from representations to cultural production, historically and today.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: The Mixed Race Experience
description: Exploration of demographic trends in interracial and interethnic marriages to highlight the complexity of the American experience. Special attention to mixed-race experiences portrayed in film and novels. AF_AM_ST 251-0 and ASIAN_AM 251-0 are taught together; students may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Introduction to Asian American Literature
description: Introduction to Asian American literature from the late 19th century to the present, covering a range of genres and ethnicities. ASIAN_AM 275-0 and ENGLISH 275-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Topics in Literary and Cultural Studies
description: Close study of Asian American literary and cultural texts within a theme, genre, or other organizing criterion. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Advanced Topics in Social and Cultural Analysis
description: Detailed exploration of an issue and its ramifications in Asian American society and culture. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Asian American Women's History
description: Exploration of race, gender, and the contours of US history from the perspective of Asian American women's experiences. Considers migration, exclusion, labor, marriage, family, sexuality, and cross-racial alliances. ASIAN_AM 304-0 and HISTORY 304-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Contemporary Asian Black Relations
description: Divides between these groups, as well as areas of positive cross-cultural collaboration. Historical analysis of reparations, the 1992 Los Angeles riots, and affirmative action. Cross-racial exchange in youth expressions, popular culture, hip-hop. AF_AM_ST 310-0 and ASIAN_AM 310-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Advanced Topics in History
description: Close study of Asian American history within a theme, event, or other organizing criterion, with emphasis on primary documents, historical interpretation, and research. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Asian American Religions
description: Analysis of the role of religion in Asian American communities; how experiences as immigrants and as racial and ethnic minorities shape religious practices, communities, theologies, and identities.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Studies in Race, Gender, and Sexuality
description: Exploration of the intersections of gender, race, and sexuality, the construction of masculinity and femininity, and the role of gender and sexuality in the life experiences of Asian Americans. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Language, Race, and Ethnicity in the U.S.
description: Analysis of connections between language ideologies, language use, and meanings of race and ethnicity. Bilingualism, immigration, identity, accented English, African American English, language policy, English only movement, education, social change. ASIAN_AM 365-0 and ANTHRO 365-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Studies in Diaspora
description: Exploration of the ideas of diaspora and homeland and their implications for rethinking immigration and migration as they relate to the experiences of Asian Americans. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Advanced Topics in Literary and Cultural Studies
description: Close study of Asian American literary and cultural texts within a theme, genre, or other organizing criterion, with an emphasis on theory and its application. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: The American Century in Asia
description: Examination of US-Asia connections through history and representations of US wars in cultural and historical texts.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Studies in Arts and Performance
description: Analysis of Asian American contributions to the art and culture of the United States. Exploration of the dynamics of race, gender, and class in Asian American dance, theater, and film. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Seminar in Asian American Studies
description: Seminar on a topic in areas related to Asian American social structure and culture. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: ASIAN_AM
name: Independent Study In Asian American Studies
description: Readings and conferences on special subjects for students pursuing areas of interest in Asian American studies.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introductory Topics in Chinese Literature and Culture
description: Introduction to topics in Chinese literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introduction to Modern Chinese Literature and Culture
description: Introduction to topics in the history of cultural production in modern China between the 19th century and present day. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Modern Chinese Popular Culture I
description: Introduction to the history of modern Chinese popular cultural production between the mid-19th century and 1949. The course is designed around the introduction and adaptation of four media technologies: photography, film, mass print culture, and sound recording. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Modern Chinese Popular Culture II
description: Introduction to popular cultural production in Mainland China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong between 1949 and the present. ASIAN_LC 204-0 is recommended. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introductory Topics in Japanese Literature and Culture
description: Introduction to topics in Japanese literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introduction to Premodern Japanese Literature and Culture
description: Introduction to Japanese literature and culture from the earliest writings to the dawn of the modern era (8th-19th c.): poetry, narrative fiction, essays, diaries, theater. Focus is on reading literary texts in historical context. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introduction to Modern Japanese Literature and Culture
description: Culture Introduction to Japanese literature, thought, and culture from the mid-19th to mid-20th century: fiction, poetry, theater, essays. Focus is on reading literary texts in relation to historical context. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introduction to Contemporary Japanese Literature and Culture
description: Culture Introduction to Japanese literature, thought, and culture from the mid-20th to early 21st century: fiction, poetry, theater, essays, animation, manga. Focus is on reading literary texts in relation to historical context. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introduction to Japanese Film, Media, and Visual Culture
description: Introduction to Japanese media and visual culture. Topics may include: pre-modern visual narrative, pre-modern print culture, cinema, animation, manga, video games. Focus is on reading media and visual culture in relation to historical context. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introductory Topics in Korean Literature and Culture
description: Introduction to topics in Korean literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introductory Topics in South Asian Literature and Culture
description: Introduction to topics in South Asian literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: South Asian Popular Cultures
description: This course offers an introduction to the intersecting worlds of popular literature, digital media, folk arts, performance, and politics of South Asia with a focus on the relationship between artistic expression, social reform and political change. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: South Asian Cinemas
description: Narrative and aesthetic approaches to understanding popular cinemas in South Asia with special attention to historical, local, and global contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Introductory Topics in Asian Languages and Cultures
description: Content and prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Advanced Topics in Chinese Literature and Culture
description: Advanced study and analysis of topics in Chinese literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. One 200-level Chinese literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Advanced Topics in Japanese Literature and Culture
description: Advanced study and analysis of topics in Japanese literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. One 200-level Japanese literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Advanced Topics in Premodern Japanese Literature and Culture
description: In-depth examination of specialized topics in premodern Japanese literature and culture. Emphasis on reading, evaluating, and applying scholarship in Japanese studies to inform analysis of primary texts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Advanced Topics in Modern and Contemporary Japanese Literature and Culture
description: Advanced study in topics related to Japanese literature and culture from the late 19th century to the present. Topics may include, but are not limited to: significant cultural movements in specific historical periods, wartime literature and culture, minority literatures, and major authors and texts. Focus is on interpreting literature and culture in relation to historical contexts and theoretical concerns. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Advanced Topics in Korean Literature and Culture
description: Advanced study and analysis of topics in Korean literature and culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. ASIAN_LC 240 is recommended. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Advanced Topics in South Asian Languages and Cultures
description: Advanced study and analysis of topics in South Asian Literature and Culture, from precolonial to contemporary periods and contexts. Includes a research component. May be repeated for credit with change in topic. One 200-level South Asian literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Literary Cultures in South Asia
description: Advanced study of specific literary cultures in South Asia, and their impacts on South Asian history and contemporary society. Topics vary in historical, regional, and thematic scope. No prerequisite, but a 200-level ASIAN_LC topics courses is recommended. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. One 200-level South Asian literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Religious and Textual Traditions in South Asia
description: Explores the close relationship between religious practice and belief and literary traditions (Hindu, Muslim, Buddhist, etc.) in South Asia from classical to contemporary periods. Topics vary; may be repeated for credit with a change in topic. One 200-level South Asian literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: South Asian Societies
description: This class will examine how significant moments of social and political transformation (such as colonialism, Partition, and the growth of the South Asian diaspora) has been engaged in literature and popular culture. Content varies; a 200-level course in an area of South Asian literature and culture is recommended. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Advanced Topics in Asian Languages and Cultures
description: Content and prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Advanced Studies in Asian Film, Media, and Visual Culture
description: Advanced topics in Asian film, media, and visual culture. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: ASIAN_LC 202-0 or ASIAN_LC 204-0 or ASIAN_LC 205-0 or ASIAN_LC 224-0 or ASIAN_LC 265-0 (C- or better); or consent of instructor

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Asian Environmental Humanities
description: Topics in the study of environment and culture in Asian contexts. Content varies; may be repeated for credit with change of topic. One 200-level Asian LC course is recommended.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Space and Place in Asian Literatures and Cultures
description: Advanced undergraduate course examining representations of space and place in Asian cultural contexts, with focus on application of theoretical methods to primary texts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. One 200-level Asian literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Genre in Asian Literatures
description: Advanced undergraduate course examining the place of genre in Asian literary traditions. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. One 200-level Asian literary and culture studies course is recommended. No prerequisites.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Senior Seminar
description: Senior capstone research course for majors; topics vary.

subject: ASIAN_LC
name: Independent Study
description: The independent study is designed for advanced undergraduates interested in studying topics not otherwise covered in normal ALC courses.
prereq: consent of director of undergraduate studies and instructor

subject: ASTRON
name: Modern Cosmology
description: Modern views on the structure of the universe, its past, present, and future. For nonscience majors who want to take a more detailed course after completing ASTRON 120-0.

subject: ASTRON
name: Milky Way Galaxy
description: Structure of the galaxy, star formation, interstellar clouds and dust, star clusters, neutron stars and black holes, the galactic center. For nonscience majors who want to take a more detailed course after completing ASTRON 120-0.

subject: ASTRON
name: Solar System
description: The planets and their moons, the sun, comets, asteroids. For nonscience majors who want to take a more detailed course after completing ASTRON 120-0.

subject: ASTRON
name: A Brief Journey through the Invisible Universe
description: A conceptual course exploring the world of the invisible radio universe. The topics include: the historical development of the radio sky, the connection between cosmic rays and the radio sky, how radio telescopes work and numerous discoveries made over the last 90 years (pulsars, quasars, the Big Bang cosmic microwave background radiation, organic molecules, the shadow of a supermassive black hole), and the physics of radio astronomy.

subject: ASTRON
name: Introduction to Astrobiology
description: The modern scientific perspective on the question of life elsewhere in the universe. The prospects for life on Mars. The discovery of extrasolar planets and the search for extrasolar biospheres.

subject: ASTRON
name: Highlights of Astronomy
description: Acquaints students with modern ideas about the solar system, stars, galaxies, and the universe. Emphasizes fundamental principles and underlying concepts.

subject: ASTRON
name: Introduction to Astrophysics I: Life Cycle of Stars and Planets
description: The course will explore the origin and evolution of star/planet systems, focusing on underlying physical processes and observational techniques. We will discuss the recent discovery of thousands of planets orbiting stars other than our Sun - a.k.a. "exoplanets". We will also discuss stellar remnant black holes. (Prerequisites: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2 (concurrent registration in PHYSICS 135-2 is acceptable. Students who have taken ASTRON 220-0 should not take this course and take ASTRON 220-2 instead).

subject: ASTRON
name: Introduction to Astrophysics II: Galactic Evolution and Cosmology
description: The course will explore modern cosmology, including dark matter, the Big Bang, curved space-time, the origin and evolution of the first stars and galaxies, cosmic acceleration, and dark energy. In all cases, the focus will be on the underlying physical processes and the observational techniques used. (Prerequisites: ASTRON 220-1 or all of PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, and PHYSICS 135-3.)

subject: ASTRON
name: Basics of Radio Astronomy
description: Radio astronomy is the study of natural radio emission from the sky, providing important clues about the history of the universe. Topics include how a radio telescope receives invisible signals, how dramatically the radio sky differs from the optical sky, and interferometry.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, PHYSICS 135-3 (or equivalent) or PHYSICS 332-0; MATH 220-2 or equivalent

subject: ASTRON
name: Planetary Astrophysics
description: Methods of exoplanet detection. The observed architecture of exoplanetary systems. Formation and evolution of planetary systems. Modeling exoplanet interiors and atmospheres. Exoplanet habitability and the search for bio-signatures.

subject: ASTRON
name: Observational Astrophysics
description: Geometric optics applied to design of optical and x-ray telescopes; diffraction and the Airy disk; radio and optical interferometry and aperture synthesis; adaptive optics; recent developments in detector technology; quantum and thermal noise in astronomy. Independent research projects using the CCD camera and 18-inch refractor in Dearborn Observatory. Offered alternate years.

subject: ASTRON
name: Stellar Astrophysics
description: Physics of stellar interiors, stellar atmospheres, and star formation. Specific topics include simple stellar models, nuclear energy generation, overview of evolutionary phases, white dwarfs, neutron stars, interstellar gas and dust grains, gravitational collapse.

subject: ASTRON
name: Extragalactic Astrophysics and Cosmology
description: Big bang cosmology, thermal history of the universe, primordial nucleosynthesis, microwave background, dark matter, largescale structure, galaxy formation, spiral and elliptical galaxies, groups and clusters of galaxies.

subject: ASTRON
name: Astrophysics ISP
description: Stellar structure and evolution: nucleosynthesis, supernova phenomena, white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Limited to students enrolled in ISP or with consent of the physics department.

subject: ASTRON
name: Current Topics in Astronomy
description: Explores in detail an area of current research interest in astrophysics. Contact the department or instructor for specifics. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Prerequisites vary.

subject: ASTRON
name: Independent Study
description: Opportunity to study an advanced subject under the individual direction of a faculty member. Open to all advanced students. Consent of instructor required.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Introduction to Biological Sciences at Northwestern
description: For participants in Bio&ChemEXCEL summer program. An overview of recent advances in biological research and leadership within the field of biology. Taken with CHEM 100-0.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Diversity of Life
description: Comparative survey of organisms, emphasizing adaptation and phylogenetic relationships. Particular emphasis on animals.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Plant-People Interactions
description: Biology and history of the interaction of humans and flowering plants.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: The Nature of Plants
description: Plant adaptations for growth, survival, and reproduction. Plant defense against herbivory, pollination, and seed dispersal.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: First-Year Seminar
description: For participants in the NUBioscientist program. Biological Thought & Action; preparatory to BIOL_SCI 116-6.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: First-Year Seminar
description: For participants in the NUBioscientist program. Science Research Preparation; follows BIOL_SCI 115-6.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Human Genetics
description: Basic principles of human inheritance and genetic variation.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Human Reproduction
description: Basic biology of reproduction; relation between hormones, emotions, intelligence, and behavior; related policy issues.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Basic Genetics and Evolution
description: Principles of inheritance as they apply to evolution. May not receive credit after taking BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Molecular Biology
description: This course focuses on how information is stored and propagated in DNA, and used and regulated to generate proteins at the proper time and location. It also applies this information to understanding fundamentals of biotechnology. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 201-0 and BIOL_SCI 215-0.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Peer-Guided SG: Molecular Biology
description: Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U. Co-requisite: BIOL_SCI 201-0.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Cell Biology
description: This course covers how biomolecules function together to generate the complexity of cells, and how cells behave collectively to communicate with each other and to enact key decisions, such as proliferation and cell death.
prereq: Students must have completed, with a C- or better, BIOL_SCI 201-0 or 215-0 to register for this course. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 232-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 219-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Peer-Guided SG: Cell Biology
description: Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U. Co-requisite: BIOL_SCI 202-0.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Genetics and Evolution
description: This course provides an analytic framework for studying the flow of biological information across generations, and understanding how phenotypes reveal biological mechanisms. This framework is applied to development, cancer, the history of life, and mechanisms governing the evolution and distribution of organisms over time.
prereq: Students must have completed, with a C- or better, BIOL_SCI 202-0 or 219-0 to register for this course. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 233-0

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Genetics and Evolution
description: Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U. Co-requisite: BIOL_SCI 203-0.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant
description: Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Molecular and Cellular Processes Laboratory
description: Laboratory techniques and experiments in fundamental aspects of cell and molecular biology. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 202-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 221-0 and BIOL_SCI 232-0.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Genetics and Molecular Processes Laboratory
description: Laboratory techniques and experiments in fundamental aspects of transmission genetics and molecular biology.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 232-0. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 203-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 220-0 and BIOL_SCI 233-0

subject: BIOL_SCI
