name: Investigative Laboratory
description: A culminating life-science laboratory experience.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 233-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 222-0 and BIOL_SCI 234-0

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology - 1 for ISP
description: This course aims to provide a framework for understanding the chemistry, structure and function of life’s smallest functional units known as cells. Starting out with a basic description of inherent properties of biological macromolecules, the course deals with information storage, the flow of genetic information, cytoskeleton, cell organelles, and cell division.
prereq: Students must be enrolled in the Integrated Science Program to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology - 2 for ISP
description: The course takes an in depth look at how the chemical and physical properties of organic molecules drive all aspects of life. Focus on principles of chemical evolution/diversification, biological membranes, membrane transport processes, enzyme structure and function, molecular signaling and design principles of the metabolic engine that enables the breakdown and synthesis of biological macromolecules.
prereq: Students must have completed CHEM 171-0, CHEM 172-0, CHEM 212-1, BIOL_SCI 240-0, and ISP standing

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Principles of Biochemistry
description: Biochemical processes.
prereq: Students must have completed, or be currently enrolled in, CHEM 210-1 or CHEM 212-1 or CHEM 215-1

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Principles of Biochemistry
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in BIOL_SCI 301-0. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Fundamentals of Neurobiology
description: Cellular and biochemical approaches to the nervous system, focusing on neuron structure and function.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 217-0 or BIOL_SCI 310-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course. May not receive credit for both BIOL_SCI 302-0 and NEUROSCI 202-0

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Molecular Neurobiology
description: Exploration of the overlap between neurobiology and molecular biology.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 302-0 or NEUROSCI 311-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Neurobiology Laboratory
description: Hands-on experience in the performance of experiments in cellular neurophysiology.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 302-0 or NEUROSCI 311-0 and BIOL_SCI 222-0 or BIOL_SCI 234-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Brain Structure, Function, and Evolution
description: An overview of the evolution of the nervous system and cognition, from the origin of neurons to the structure and function of the human brain. No P/N.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 302-0, BIOL_SCI 325-0 or BIOL_SCI 344-0 in order to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Human Physiology
description: An exploration of the functions of the human body at the tissue, organ and organ system level. Emphasis on homeostatic mechanisms and interdependence within organs and organ systems and the influence of modulatory systems. Topics will include, but are not limited to: nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and CHEM 132-0, CHEM 152-0, or CHEM 172-0. Credit not allowed for both BIOL_SCI 310-0 and BIOL_SCI 217-0

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Advanced Cell Biology
description: Relationship of shape, structural dynamics, and function with the cellular state and gene expression; cell-to-cell communication.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Biology of Animal Viruses
description: Virus structure, synthesis of viral nucleic acids and proteins, the interaction of the viral and cellular genomes.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Bioinformatics: Sequence and Structure Analysis
description: Use of informational and modeling techniques to explore evolutionary and other problems related to the genome.
prereq: Students must have taken BIOL_SCI 241-0 or BIOL_SCI 301-0 in order to register for this class

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Animal Physiology
description: Physiological principles and mechanisms responsible for the ability of animals to regulate variables in the steady state.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 217-0 or BIOL_SCI 310-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Biology of Aging
description: Biological aspects of aging, from molecular to evolutionary.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Microbiology
description: How microbes interact with their environments, including with humans. Lecture and Laboratory.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 222-0 or BIOL_SCI 234-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Conservation Genetics
description: Critical issues in the management and understanding of endangered populations.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Plant-Animal Interactions
description: Plant-animal interactions, and their consequences for individuals, populations, ecological communities, and ecosystems. Examination of how these interactions are responding to ongoing global factors such as anthropogenic habitat destruction and climate change.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 339-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Soils and the Environment: The Earth's Critical Zone
description: Soil development and morphology; physical, chemical, hydrologic, and biological properties of soils.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Spring Flora
description: Life cycles, vegetative and reproductive structures, and adaptations for pollination and fruit and seed dispersal of the wildflowers, trees, and shrubs of oak woodland.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or BIOL_SCI 240-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Biostatistics
description: Approaches, methods, and techniques for analyzing datasets in ecology and conservation biology.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Modeling Biological Dynamics
description: Mathematical and computational techniques for analyzing and predicting biological dynamics. Techniques include statistical models, discrete- and continuous- time dynamical models, and stochastic models. Applications cover a range of scales, with an emphasis on common mathematical concepts and computational techniques, the interpretation of existing data, and making predictions for new experiments.
prereq: at least one of MATH 218-1, MATH 220-1, MATH 240-0, STAT 202-0, BIOL_SCI 337-0, OR equivalent

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Critical Topics in Ecology and Conservation
description: Seminar discussing historical and modern publications in the field.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Population Genetics
description: Processes that affect allele frequency change and thus cause evolution.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and a course in statistics to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Evolutionary Processes
description: Evolutionary mechanisms (natural selection, genetic drift), evolutionary history (speciation, phylogenetics), and adaptations (sex, cooperation, aging, life history).
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and a course in statistics to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Anatomy of Vertebrates
description: Vertebrate phylogeny illustrated via comparative morphology; anatomical/ functional and ontogenetic considerations; dissections.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 103-0, BIOL_SCI 203-0, BIOL_SCI 341-0, or BIOL_SCI 342-0

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Topics in Biology
description: Topics vary but always deal with an area of advanced study in the life sciences. With laboratory. May be repeated for credit with different topic.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 , BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 234-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Field Ecology
description: An intensive experience in field ecological research.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and a course in statistics to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Conservation Biology
description: Evolution, ecology, and conservation of patterns of biological diversity.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 or ENVR_SCI 202-0 and a course in statistics to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Community Ecology
description: Abundance, distribution, diversity, and scaling in plant communities in space-time.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Plant Evolution and Diversity Lab
description: Introduction to the diversity and evolutionary history of land plants.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Project-based approach to learning lab skills in eukaryotic molecular biology.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 222-0 or BIOL_SCI 234-0 and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Quantitative Analysis of Biology
description: Random genetic processes, gene expression, cell adaptation, cell cycle, developmental morphogens, phylgenomics.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Immunobiology
description: Nature of host resistance; characteristics of antigens, antibodies; basis of immune response; hypersensitivity.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Endocrinology
description: Physiology and biochemistry of hormones and glands of internal secretion in vertebrates; endocrine glands.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 325-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Advanced Physiology Laboratory
description: Experiments in several physiological systems. Design, techniques, data analysis, and report writing emphasized.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 310-0 or BIOL_SCI 217-0, and BIOL_SCI 234-0 or BIOL_SCI 222-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Quantitative Experimentation in Biology
description: Laboratory in experimental methods in quantitative biology. Random genetic processes, gene expression, cell cycle, developmental morphogens, genome sequencing.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, or BIOL_SCI 354-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Principles of Cell Signaling
description: Emphasis on principles, components, and logic that are common to different cell signaling systems. Modern experimental strategies for studying cellular signaling as well as the implications of disrupting cell communication pathways in disease will be described.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Protein Structure and Function
description: Structure and function of proteins; x-ray crystallography and NMR.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Biophysics
description: Protein interaction with small molecules; protein tertiary structure determination.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: The Human Microbiome
description: Course explores different communities of microorganisms in the human body – the gut, urogenital, oral, and skin microbiota, and how these communities contribute to or are altered in health and disease. Topics will include but are not limited to: the contribution of these communities to digestion and gut health, mood, obesity, the immune system, fertility and pregnancy, and neurological disorders.
prereq: BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Functional Genomics
description: Patterns of gene expression and their causes.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Biology of Cancer
description: The disease of cancer: causation at the cell and molecular levels; treatment.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Stem Cells and Regeneration
description: Developmental and molecular biology of tissue regeneration, with regard to regeneration from embryonic or adult stem cells. Discussion of conserved developmental pathways necessary for regeneration. Applications in regenerative medicine.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Advanced Molecular Biology
description: Nucleic acid structure; DNA mutation, repair, recombination, replication, restriction, and modification; translation.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Developmental Biology
description: Molecular mechanisms underlying early embryonic development, including establishment of the body and organogenesis. Discussion of original literature.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Developmental Genetics Laboratory
description: Development of independent projects alongside classic readings and experiments exploring key concepts in developmental biology.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 222-0 or BIOL_SCI 234-0 and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Human Genomics
description: This course will examine how the analysis of the human genome and its variation provides insight into diversity, human health and our evolutionary history.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Molecular Genetics
description: Exploration of recent advances that have revolutionized the fields of gene expression and cell regulation. Discussion of articles and primary research papers.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Evolution and Diversity: Mushroom Genetics and Genomics
description: The occurrence of natural genetic variation is the raw material with which evolution has sculpted every species that has ever existed. In this laboratory-based course, students are immersed in the world of a widespread and biologically famous mushroom-forming fungus.
prereq: Students must have completed BIOL_SCI 203-0 or BIOL_SCI 215-0 and BIOL_SCI 202-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0, and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Senior Thesis Colloquium
description: Supervision while writing a Senior Thesis. Discussion of students' research. Instructor feedback on thesis drafts. Continued student research. Enrollment limited to Senior Biological Sciences majors hoping to graduate with Program Honors and/or to produce a Senior Thesis. Registration required for all Honors candidates.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Tutorial in Biology
description: Supervised reading and discussion or supervised laboratory work. P/N only.

subject: BIOL_SCI
name: Independent Research
description: Supervised independent research project.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
description: Information to 1) help students determine if BME is the right major for them and 2) learn how to make the most of their undergraduate experience. The field of biomedical engineering, career and research opportunities, ethics.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: BME Lab: Experimental Design
description: A laboratory course focusing on quantitative physiological measurements and analyses, instrument characterization, statistical design of experiments, and training in preparation and organization of laboratory notes and reports.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Introduction to Biomedical Statistics
description: Basic statistical concepts presented with emphasis on their relevance to biological and medical investigations.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Thermodynamics
description: Physical and chemical principles as applied to biological systems and medical devices. Topics include material balances, thermodynamics, solution chemistry, electrochemistry, surface chemistry, transport, and kinetics.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Fluid Mechanics
description: Fundamentals of fluid mechanics and their applications to biological systems.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Introduction to Biomechanics
description: Analysis of stresses and deformations in solids. Problems in biomechanics, with emphasis on assumptions appropriate to modeling biological materials including bone, skin, muscle, and cell membranes.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Quantitative Systems Physiology
description: Functional/structural aspects of mammalian nervous system. Neural biophysics. Laboratory exercises.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Quantitative Systems Physiology
description: Rigorous overview of cardiovascular and respiratory anatomy, physiology, and pathophysiology. Case studies and a design team project.
prereq: Students must have taken MATH 228-1 or be a BME graduate student in order to register for this course; junior standing recommended

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Quantitative Systems Physiology
description: Cellular mechanisms of and quantitative systems' approach to human renal, digestive, endocrine, and metabolic physiology.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Biomedical Signals and Circuits
description: Time and frequency domain analysis: convolution representation, Fourier series, Fourier transforms, frequency response, filtering, sampling.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Biomedical Systems Analysis
description: Introduction to linear systems analysis. Time and frequency domain techniques for analyzing linear systems, emphasizing their applications to biomedical systems. MATLAB-based problem sets and lab illustrate topics covered in class.
prereq: BMD_ENG 207-0 (can also be taken concurrently); BMD_ENG 308-0; BMD_ENG 220-0, IEMS 303-0, or MECH_ENG 359-0; GEN_ENG 205-4

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Computational Genomics
description: The course introduces state-of-the-art genomic sequencing technologies and computational modeling of high-throughput sequencing datasets. Through the course, students will learn how to apply these experimental and computational genomics technologies to study gene expression regulation underlying various biological processes, such as oncogenesis. Students will also apply computational and statistical skills, using linux and R/Matlab/Python.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Biochemical Sensors
description: Theory, design, and applications of chemical sensors used in medical diagnosis and patient monitoring. Electrochemical and optical sensors.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Visual Engineering Science
description: Mammalian visual system. Physiological optics. Visual image representation and interpretation. Visual adaptation. Motion. Color vision.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Introduction to Medical Imaging
description: Diagnostic X-rays; X-ray film and radiographic image; computed tomography; ultrasound.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Magnetic Resonance Imaging
description: Nuclear magnetic resonance; two-dimensional Fourier transform, spinecho and gradientecho imaging; gradient and RF hardware.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Modern Optical Microscopy & Imaging
description: Rigorous introduction to principles, current trends, emerging technologies, and biomedical applications of modern optical microscopy.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Biomaterials and Medical Devices
description: Structure-property relationships for biomaterials. Metal, ceramic, and polymeric implant materials and their implant applications. Interactions of materials with the body. Taught with MAT_SCI 370-0; may not receive credit for both courses.
prereq: BIOL_SCI 215-0; BIOL_SCI 219-0; MAT_SCI 201-0 or MAT_SCI 301-0; senior standing

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Biological Performance of Materials
description: Structure-property relationships of materials, physical chemistry of surfaces and interfaces, materials-tissue interactions, applications to the selection and design of materials for medical implants and devices.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Tissue Engineering
description: In vivo molecular, cellular, and organ engineering, with emphasis on the foundations, techniques, experiments, and clinical applications of tissue engineering.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Foundations of Regenerative Engineering
description: Embryonic development, stem cell engineering, somatic regeneration, genome and transcriptome modifications, cell and tissue-level regenerative engineering.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Applications of Regenerative Engineering
description: Mechanisms of human disease, development and application of molecular, cellular, and tissue-level regenerative engineering strategies to selected human disorders, including neurodegenerative disorders, stroke, cystic fibrosis, cirrhosis, diabetes, muscular degenerative disorders, and skin injury.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Bioelectronics
description: Development and design of sensors, stimulators, and their medical devices for biointegrated electronics. Materials design and fabrication of passive and active components for sensitive, multimodal, and robust wearable and implantable devices.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Bioelectronics Lab
description: Laboratories focused on the practical implementation, instrumentation, and fabrication of wearables and skinsensing. Applications range from vital sign monitoring to rehabilitation.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Control of Human Limbs and Their Artificial Replacements
description: Human movement, biomechanics, skeletal and muscular anatomy, comparative anatomy, muscle physiology, and locomotion. Engineering design of artificial limbs.
prereq: senior standing with engineering or physical science background

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Biomechanics of Movement
description: Engineering mechanics applied to analyze human movement, including models of muscle and tendon, kinematics of joints, and dynamics of multi-joint movement. Applications in sports, rehabilitation, and orthopedics.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Mechanics of Biological Tissue
description: Stress and strain for small and large deformations. Nonlinear elastic, viscoelastic, pseudo-elastic, and biphasic models.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Intermediate Fluid Mechanics
description: Fundamental concepts of fluid dynamics. Kinematics, mass and momentum balances, constitutive relations. Navier-Stokes equations and methods of solution. Sealing techniques.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Transport Fundamentals
description: Fundamental and biomedical applications of diffusive and convective heat and mass transfer.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Medical Devices, Disease & Global Health
description: Health systems and technologies to address health problems of the world's underserved populations, with special emphasis on developing countries.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Health Systems Engineering
description: Introduction to health systems in the context of disease burden with special emphasis in developing countries. We examine healthcare systems, financing, data and analytics. The course focuses primarily on health-related issues confronting South Africa and the associated social and economic impact.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Health Technology Management
description: This course provides an introduction to formal concepts and methodologies used in support of health technology planning, assessment and adoption - and related decision making - as part of cost-effective healthcare delivery. Open to participants in the Global Health Technologies Program only.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Biomedical Engineering Design
description: Open-ended team-designed projects in the medical devices arena. Systems approach requiring design strategy and concepts, including reliability, safety, ethics, economic analysis, marketing, FDA regulations, and patents. Written and oral reports.
prereq: BMD_ENG 207-0, BMD_ENG 220-0, BMD_ENG 250-0, BMD_ENG 270-0, BMD_ENG 271-0, BMD_ENG 308-0, BMD_ENG 309-0 and MAT_SCI 201-0

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Biomedical Engineering Design
description: Development of a design project initiated during the previous quarter.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Biomedical Engineering Design
description: Continuation of a design project; independent study. May not be repeated for credit.
prereq: BMD_ENG 390-1 or BMD_ENG 390-2; consent of instructor

subject: BMD_ENG
name: HealthCare Techology Innovation and Design
description: Principles and practice of medical device design for the developing world. Evaluation of user needs in the environment of under-resourced segments of South African health care system. Validation and verification of engineering design solutions. Open to participants in the Global Health Technologies Program only.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Topics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Special Topics
description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering, Laboratory emphasis.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering, Laboratory emphasis.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering, Laboratory emphasis.

subject: BMD_ENG
name: Projects
description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS.

subject: BUS_INST
name: Accounting
description: Introduction to both financial and managerial accounting. Use of organizations' financial statements for making decisions.

subject: BUS_INST
name: Marketing Management
description: Basic principles and applications of marketing management. Marketing segmentation, target marketing, brand positioning, consumer behavior, channels strategy, pricing, advertising and promotion.

subject: BUS_INST
name: Leadership in Organizations
description: Social science tools for solving organizational problems and influencing individuals, groups, and organizations. Competitive decision making, reward system design, team building, strategic negotiation, political dynamics, corporate culture, and strategic organizational design.

subject: BUS_INST
name: Corporate Finance
description: Effects of time and uncertainty on valuation and decision making. Discounting techniques, stock and bond valuation, capital budgeting, firm valuation, capital asset pricing model, financial options. May not receive credit for both this course and ECON 360-1. Not for students who have previously taken KELLG_FE 310-0.
prereq: ECON 201-0 and ECON 202-0; STAT 210-0 or equivalent; MATH 218-1 or MATH 220-1; and BUS_INST 301-0

subject: BUS_INST
name: Business and Economic Institutions in Historical Perspective
description: Factors affecting economic growth and challenges to achieving economic success. Organization of firms and financial markets; corporate governance; innovation; financial crises; income inequality; race and gender.
prereq: ECON 201-0 and ECON 202-0; STAT 210-0 or equivalent; and MATH 218-1 or MATH 220-1

subject: BUS_INST
name: Professional Linkage Seminar
description: Content varies. Possible topics include entrepreneurship, investment banking, business ethics, global marketing, sports marketing, and nonprofit management. Prerequisites vary.

subject: CRDV
name: Introduction to Career Development
description: Course preparing students for the Walter P. Murphy Cooperative Engineering Education Program, internships, and fulltime employment. It includes units on job-search skills, self-assessment, transition to the workplace, workplace-management issues, and transition back to school.

name: Cooperative Engineering Education
description: Sequence of courses covering the work terms of students in the Walter P. Murphy Cooperative Engineering Education Program.

description: Sequence of courses covering the work terms of students in the Walter P. Murphy Cooperative Engineering Education Program. Offered in partnership with the Global McCormick initiative.

subject: CRDV
name: Career Development for Student Entrepreneurs
description: An opportunity for McCormick students who have created and/or manage start-up companies in the Chicagoland area to receive mentorship and training in the areas of business development, principles of supervision, leadership development and product development. Students are required to work directly with an entrepreneurial advisor of their choice including: entrepreneurship faculty, senior business executives, and other seasoned entrepreneurs.

subject: CRDV
name: Career Development for Student Entrepreneurs
description: An opportunity for McCormick students who have created and/or manage start-up companies in the Chicagoland area to receive mentorship and training in the areas of business development, principles of supervision, leadership development and product development. Students are required to work directly with an entrepreneurial advisor of their choice including: entrepreneurship faculty, senior business executives, and other seasoned entrepreneurs.

name: Career Development for Student Entrepreneurs
description: An opportunity for McCormick students who have created and/or manage start-up companies in the Chicagoland area to receive mentorship and training in the areas of business development, principles of supervision, leadership development and product development. Students are required to work directly with an entrepreneurial advisor of their choice including: entrepreneurship faculty, senior business executives, and other seasoned entrepreneurs.

subject: LDRSHP
name: Paradigms and Strategies of Leadership
description: ULP students' introduction to six foundational leadership assets: asking powerful questions, navigating and leading amid change, inspiring others through narrative, mobilizing difference to maximize team performance, thriving in collaborative and hierarchical settings, and responding to setbacks and failure with resilience. Components include weekly lectures, guest speakers, and discussion groups.

subject: LDRSHP
name: Leading From Design
description: Through readings, small group discussion, one-on-one coaching, self-assessment and reflecting on leadership and other life experiences, this course builds on the themes, models and concepts introduced in LDRSHP 204-0 (Paradigms and Strategies of Leadership), to help students develop a deeper self-awareness that serves as the foundation for the construction of their own individual leadership model.

subject: LDRSHP
name: Special Topics in Leadership
description: Topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the department.

subject: LDRSHP
name: Field Studies in Leadership
description: Students have the opportunity to leave a positive "leadership footprint" by fostering the success of a group, organization, or community. Spending at least 160 hours outside the classroom, they undertake a leadership role, an internship or externship, or a community engagement experience, exploring leadership models and concepts through application. Consent of instructor required.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Engineering of Chemical and Biological Processes
description: Survey of engineering principles as they are applied to processes involving chemical and biological transformations. Examples from the chemical, pharmaceutical, biotechnology, food processing, electronics, and other industries. Impact of economics, ethics, and other nontechnical constraints.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Analysis of Chemical Process Systems
description: Introduction to process systems. Material balances and stoichiometry. Analysis of process system flow sheets. Introduction to departmental computing facilities. Basic numerical analysis.
prereq: CHEM 132-0, CHEM 152-0, or CHEM 172-0; GEN_ENG 205-3 (may be taken concurrently)

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Thermodynamics
description: The first and second laws of thermodynamics. Entropy and equilibrium. Material and energy balances. Equations of state and properties of fluids. Solutions, phase equilibria, and chemical reactions.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Phase Equilibrium and Staged Separations
description: Thermodynamic models of mixtures and phase equilibrium. Analysis and design of staged separation processes such as distillation, absorption, stripping, and extraction.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Molecular & Cell Biology for Engineers
description: Introduction to cell and molecular biology concepts that provide the foundation for modern biotechnology and bioengineering.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Kinetics and Reactor Engineering
description: Chemical reaction kinetics with application to the design of chemical reactors.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Probability and Statistics for Chemical Engineering
description: Introduction to probability theory and statistical methods necessary for analyzing the behavior of processes and experiments. Statistical tests for detecting significant changes in process parameters.
prereq: MATH 220-1, MATH 220-2, MATH 228-1, & MATH 228-2 (formerly listed as MATH 220-0, MATH 224-0, MATH 230-0, & MATH 234-0), or ES_APPM 252-1 & ES_APPM 252-2

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Fluid Mechanics
description: Derivation and applications of continuity and Navier-Stokes equations. Macroscopic mass, momentum, and energy balance. Dimensional analysis: friction factors in pipes and packed beds; drag coefficients.
prereq: completion of mathematics requirements with no grades of D; GEN_ENG 205-4 (C- or better)

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Heat Transfer
description: The differential equations of energy transport. Solutions for various applications.
prereq: completion of mathematics requirements with no grades of D; GEN_ENG 205-4 (C- or better); CHEM_ENG 321-0 recommended

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Mass Transfer
description: Diffusion and rate concepts; application to distillation, extraction, absorption, humidification, drying.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Molecular Engineering and Statistical Mechanics
description: Basic statistical mechanics. Applications to thermodynamics, kinetics, and transport of various engineering systems, including frontier areas of chemical and biological engineering. Not open to students who have taken CHEM_ENG 406-0, CHEM 342-3, or PHYSICS 332-0.
prereq: CHEM_ENG 211-0 or another thermodynamics course; courses in probability and statistics, heat transfer, or other transport recommended

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Dynamics and Control of Chemical and Biological Processes
description: Dynamic behavior of chemical process components. Feedback control principles.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
description: Operation and control of process equipment for the determination of operating data. Analysis and written presentation of results.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Process Optimization for Energy and Sustainability
description: Modern techniques and application to the design and operation of chemical process systems. Steady-state and dynamic methods. Experimental search for the optimum.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Process Economics, Design, & Evaluation
description: Preliminary design of industrial processes for the production of chemical and allied products by the application of the engineering sciences and economics.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Chemical Engineering Design Projects
description: Design of chemical and process plants applying the principles of unit operations, thermodynamics, reaction kinetics, and economics. Mechanical design and selection of chemical process equipment.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Chemical Product Design
description: Properties and selection of chemicals for products from single-molecule pharmaceuticals to devices to manufactured products such as food and consumer goods.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Introduction to Polymers
description: Polymerization mechanisms and their relation to molecular structure, polymerization processes, and the mechanical properties of polymers, especially flow behavior.
prereq: CHEM_ENG 211-0 or other thermodynamics course; CHEM 210-1

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Chemical Processing and the Environment
description: Application of chemical engineering fundamentals to environmental problems. Chemistry and mechanisms, chemical reaction and rate, and transport emphasized. Risk assessment and analysis revealed through case studies.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Sustainability, Technology, and Society
description: Technical discussion of selected topics related to sustainability, sustainable development, global climate changes, natural and renewal resources and utilization, industrial ecology, eco-efficiency, technology related to sustainability such as biofuel, electrification of transportation, and water purification, and role of policy and business risk assessment.
prereq: junior standing in science or engineering; familiarity with process system analysis, energy and material balances (such as found in CHEM_ENG 210-0 or CIV_ENV 260-0)

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Quantitative Methods in Life Cycle Analysis
description: Lifecycle analysis (LCA) framework for environmental assessment of technology systems, focusing on modeling methods for systems mass and energy flows, process and input-output-based systems inventories, environmental impact analysis, and methods for robust engineering decisions. MECH_ENG 367-0 is taught with CHEM_ENG 367-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Bionanotechnology
description: Physical biology of the cell and its implications for nanotechnology, with a focus on the quantitative description of sizes, shapes, times, and energies at the nanoscale.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Biotechnology and Global Health
description: Recent advances in synthetic biology and genetic, metabolic, and tissue engineering. Design, development, and commercialization of healthcare technologies for countries in the developing world and the challenges of deploying preventative, diagnostic, and therapeutic products in these settings.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Biochemical Engineering
description: Modern biochemical engineering. Life sciences: microbiology, biochemistry, and molecular genetics. Metabolic stoichiometry, energetics, growth kinetics, transport phenomena in bioreactors, and product recovery.
prereq: CHEM_ENG 307-0, CHEM_ENG 323-0, or consent of instructor

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Principles of Synthetic Biology
description: Overview of synthetic biology's foundations in the natural sciences and engineering and its applications in medicine, biotechnology, and green chemistry. How engineering driven approaches may be used to accelerate design-build-test loops required for reprogramming existing biological systems and constructing new ones.
prereq: CHEM_ENG 275-0 or BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 202-0 (formerly BIOL_SCI 215-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0)

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Bioseparations
description: Downstream process in biotechnology. Separation and lysis of cells. Recovery of organelles and proteins. Protein separation and purification.
prereq: CHEM_ENG 323-0 (may be taken concurrently); CHEM_ENG 275-0 or BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 202-0 (formerly BIOL_SCI 215-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0)

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Computational Biology: Analysis and Design of Living Systems
description: This course provides an introduction to fundamental principles and methods for computational and mathematical analysis of natural and engineered biological systems. Emphasis is placed upon understanding and designing biological systems based upon conceptual framings including multi-scale networks, dynamic control, genetic circuits, and biological programs.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Practical Biological Imaging
description: Theory and practice of biological microscopy in a lab setting; image acquisition, analysis, and the ethics of image manipulation.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Regulatory Sciences in Biotechnology
description: Course on topics at the intersection of science, engineering, and biotech regulatory compliance. Federal regulations for drug product development; regulatory compliance processes and organizational structure; interface between biotechnology processes and regulatory sciences; global harmonization of regulations; regulatory documentation.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering
description: Topics suggested by students or faculty and approved by the department.

subject: CHEM_ENG
name: Projects
description: Supervised investigation of a chemical engineering problem with submission of a final report.

subject: CHEM
name: Introduction to Calculus and Chemistry
description: For participants in Bio&ChemEXCEL summer program. Introduction to calculus and general chemistry. Taken with BIOL_SCI 100-0.

subject: CHEM
name: Introduction to Problem Solving in Chemistry
description: For participants in Bridge I summer program. Developing facility with quantitative tools to solve problems in chemistry.

subject: CHEM
name: Quantitative Problem Solving in Chemistry
description: Solution strategies for traditional word problems and their application to basic chemistry quantitative problems: dimensional analysis, chemical equations, stoichiometry, limiting reagents.

subject: CHEM
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Quantitative Problem Solving in Chemistry
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 110-0. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
name: General Chemistry 1
description: Quantum mechanics, electronic structure, periodic properties of elements, chemical bonding, thermodynamics, intermolecular forces, properties of solids and liquids, special topics in modern chemistry.

subject: CHEM
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: General Chemistry 1
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 131-0. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
name: General Chemistry 2
description: Solutions and colligative properties, chemical equilibrium, aqueous solution equilibria, chemical kinetics, metals in chemistry and biology, oxidation-reduction reactions and electrochemistry, special topics in modern chemistry.

subject: CHEM
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: General Chemistry 2
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 132-0. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
name: General Chemistry Laboratory 1
description: Chemical analysis of real samples using basic laboratory techniques including titration, colorimetric analysis, density measurements, and atomic spectroscopy. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 131-0.

subject: CHEM
name: General Chemistry Laboratory 2
description: Chemistry laboratory techniques applied to materials science and nanotechnology, acid-base chemistry, and chemical kinetics. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 132-0.

subject: CHEM
name: Accelerated General Chemistry 1
description: Quantum mechanics, electronic structure, periodic properties of elements, chemical bonding, thermodynamics, gas laws, intermolecular forces, properties of solids and liquids, special topics in modern chemistry.
prereq: permission of department by placement exam

subject: CHEM
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Accelerated General Chemistry 1
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 151-0. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
name: Accelerated General Chemistry 2
description: Solutions and colligative properties, chemical equilibrium, aqueous solution equilibria, chemical kinetics, metals in chemistry and biology, oxidation-reduction reactions and electrochemistry, special topics in modern chemistry.

subject: CHEM
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Accelerated General Chemistry 2
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 152-0. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
name: Accelerated General Chemistry Laboratory 1
description: Chemical analysis of real samples using basic laboratory techniques including titration, colorimetric analysis, density measurements, and atomic spectroscopy. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 151-0.

subject: CHEM
name: Accelerated General Chemistry Laboratory 2
description: Chemistry laboratory techniques applied to materials science and nanotechnology, acid-base chemistry, and chemical kinetics. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 152-0.

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced General Inorganic Chemistry
description: Review of mole problems and stoichiometry; descriptive chemistry, elements, compounds, and inorganic reactions; gas laws; phase equilibria and colligative properties; chemical equilibrium; aqueous equilibria; topics in chemical bonding and molecular structure. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 181-0.
prereq: department placement exam or appropriate AP credit

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced General Physical Chemistry
description: Thermodynamics and equilibrium; chemical kinetics and mechanism; electrochemistry; electronic structure of the atom and quantum theory; advanced topics in chemical bonding; coordination compounds; solid-state chemistry; nuclear chemistry. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 182-0.

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced General Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory
description: Laboratory techniques for studying chemical analysis and chemical reactions relevant to environmental or materials research. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 171-0.

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced General Physical Chemistry Laboratory
description: Study of the physical chemistry (acid base chemistry, kinetics, etc.) behind the operating principles of biosensors. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on these experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 172-0.

subject: CHEM
name: Foundations of Organic Chemistry
description: For participants in Bridge II summer program. Exploring foundations and problem-solving skills in organic chemistry.

subject: CHEM
name: Chemistry of Nature and Culture
description: Chemistry for the nonscientist. Chemicals commonly encountered in everyday life. With laboratory.

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry
description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. Basic concepts of structure, stereochemistry, and reactivity of organic compounds. The chemistry of hydrocarbons and alcohols. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 232-1. No P/N registration.
prereq: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), and consent of department, enrollment in ISP, or department placement

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry
description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. The chemistry of aromatic, carbonyl, and nitrogen compounds; characterization of organic substances by chemical and spectral methods; reaction mechanisms. No P/N registration. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 232-2.

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry
description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. The chemistry of poly-functional compounds of biological and medicinal interest. Modern organic syn-thesis, bioorganic chemistry, and recent developments in organic chemistry. No P/N registration. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-3.

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry I
description: Foundational concepts in organic chemistry will be introduced. Topics include structure and properties of common functional groups, acidity/basicity, conformational analysis, stereochemistry, and reactivity of organic compounds.
prereq: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); or qualifying score on the Chemistry Placement Exam. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-1

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry II
description: Fundamental concepts in organic chemistry will be covered. The topics will include important functional groups and will include: nomenclature, structure, properties, and multistep synthesis. Reaction mechanisms for organic transformations will be presented, and synthesis strategies will be covered.
prereq: Grade of C- or better in CHEM 215-1 and CHEM 235-1. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-2

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
description: Advanced concepts in modern organic chemistry will be introduced. The material will focus on recent developments in synthetic organic chemistry, including: concerted/pericyclic reactions, catalysis, green/environmental chemistry, automated synthesis, and combinatorial/screening methods.
prereq: Grade of C- or better in CHEM 215-2 and in CHEM 235-2. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-3

subject: CHEM
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Organic Chemistry I
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 215-1. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Organic Chemistry II
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 215-2. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Organic Chemistry III
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 215-3. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
name: Introductory Instrumental Analysis
description: Introduction to basic laboratory techniques in analytical chemistry and spectroscopy. Topics include infrared and UV-visible spectroscopy, gas and liquid chromatography, elemental and thermal analysis, simple x-ray diffraction, error analysis, and literature searching techniques.
prereq: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), or equivalent

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory I
description: For ISP students and chemistry majors. Molecular modeling, unknown identification by spectroscopic methods, and experimental techniques of modern chemistry emphasizing reactions of alkanes, alkenes, alkyl halides, alcohols, and carbonyls. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 212-1.
prereq: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), or equivalent

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory II
description: For ISP students and chemistry majors. Techniques of modern organic chemistry including NMR spectroscopy and reactions such as electrophilic aromatic substitution, esterification, Grignard reaction, aldol condensation, Robinson annulation, and DielsAlder reaction. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 212-2 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry Lab I
description: Standard laboratory techniques in organic chemistry will be covered. Techniques will focus on the isolation and purification of organic compounds as well as the use of spectroscopic methods to determine identity and purity.
prereq: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); or qualifying score on the Chemistry Placement Exam. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 215-1

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry Lab II
description: Complete laboratory experiments focusing on standard synthetic organic chemistry will be conducted each week. Students will complete a prelab worksheet including stoichiometric calculations, prediction of reaction outcome, and identification of safety protocols.
prereq: Grade of C- or better in CHEM 215-1 and CHEM 235-1. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 215-2

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced Organic Chemistry Lab
description: Current laboratory practices for organic synthesis will be introduced. Reactions will include mechanistically complex multi-step process for the preparation of compounds related to topical themes from academic research and industrial chemistry. Synthetic targets will include complex small molecules, polymers, and molecules of biological relevance.
prereq: Grade of C- or better in CHEM 215-2 and in CHEM 235-2. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3

subject: CHEM
name: Principles of Organic Chemistry
description: Introduction to the field of physical organic chemistry. Topics include bonding and structure, conformational analysis, stereochemistry, acids and bases, reactivity, and reaction mechanisms. CHEM 301-0 and CHEM 401-0 are taught together.
prereq: CHEM 212-3 or CHEM 210-3 and CHEM 230-3 (C- or better) and 1 quarter of physical chemistry; or consent of instructor

subject: CHEM
name: Principles of Inorganic Chemistry
description: Topics in advanced inorganic chemistry. CHEM 302-0 and CHEM 402-0 are taught together.

subject: CHEM
name: Principles of Physical Chemistry
description: An overview of advanced topics in physical chemistry. CHEM 303-0 and CHEM 403-0 are taught together.

subject: CHEM
name: Chemistry of Life Processes
description: Topics in the chemistry and biochemistry of life processes. Taught with CHEM 405-0.
prereq: CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); and 1 biochemistry course; or consent of instructor

subject: CHEM
name: Environmental Chemistry
description: Topics in the physical chemistry of the environment. Taught with CHEM 406-0.
prereq: CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); MATH 230-2, MATH 250-0; PHYSICS 135-1 and PHYSICS 135-2; or consent of instructor

subject: CHEM
name: Materials and Nanochemistry
description: Introduction to frontier research at the interface of chemistry and materials science. CHEM 307-0 and CHEM 407-0 are taught together.

subject: CHEM
name: Design, Synthesis, and Applications of Nanomaterials
description: Fabrication, chemical synthesis, assembly, and characterization of controlled-dimensionality materials, including metals, semiconductors, oxides, polymers, and mesoporous scaffolds. Interfacial phenomena and particle stability, nano forms of carbon, and material design. Taught with CHEM 408-0.
prereq: 1 quarter of physical chemistry or consent of instructor

subject: CHEM
name: Polymer Chemistry
description: This course will cover the design and synthesis of polymers, including reaction mechanisms, characterization, and structure-property relationships. CHEM 309-0 is taught with CHEM 409-0. Prerequisites (for undergraduates only): CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); and one of the following courses: CHEM 307-0, CHEM 313-0, CHEM 319-0, CHEM 412-0, or CHEM 415-0.

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced Organic Chemistry 1. Advanced concepts of organic reactivity and selectivity in synthesis.
description: Strategies and tactics involved in complex target synthesis. Modern reaction classes as applied to chemical synthesis, coupled to in-depth discussion of the underlying key principles of synthesis design and execution, are covered in the class. Students will gain experience in problem solving, creative thinking, structural analysis and presentation skills.

subject: CHEM
name: Bioorganic Chemistry
description: Introduction to using chemical principles in biology and medicine. Experimental techniques and experiments in chemical biology. Suitable for students in chemistry, engineering, and biology. Taught with CHEM 415-0.
prereq: CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); and 1 quarter of biology; or consent of instructor

subject: CHEM
name: Medicinal Chemistry: the Organic Chemistry of Drug Design and Action
description: Introduction to principles of drug design and mechanisms of drug action from a chemical viewpoint. Historical introduction, drug design and development, receptors, enzymes and enzyme inhibitors, DNA, drug metabolism, and prodrugs.
prereq: CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); or consent of instructor

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced Organic Synthesis - Concepts and Applications
description: Synthesis of natural products and other medicinally relevant organic compounds. Retrosynthetic analysis, substructure keying, and pattern recognition. Classic and modern organic reactions. Terpenes, alkaloids, polyketides, steroids, proteins, and pharmaceuticals.

subject: CHEM
name: Analytical Chemistry
description: Principles and applications of analytical methods, with emphasis on advanced separation science, dynamic electrochemistry, and advanced mass spectrometry. No P/N registration.

subject: CHEM
name: Inorganic Chemistry
description: Descriptive chemistry of some important elements. Current concepts and models of chemical bonding.

subject: CHEM
name: Thermodynamics
description: Laws of applications of thermodynamics. Thermochemistry, chemical potentials, solution thermodynamics, nonideal gases.
prereq: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); MATH 230-1; PHYSICS 135-1 and PHYSICS 136-1 and PHYSICS 135-2 and PHYSICS 136-2 (PHYSICS 135-2 and PHYSICS 136-2 may be taken concurrently)

subject: CHEM
name: Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy
description: Quantum mechanics with emphasis on atomic and molecular electronic structure. Electronic, vibrational, rotational, and magnetic resonance spectroscopy.
prereq: MATH 230-1 (MATH 230-2 recommended also); PHYSICS 135-1 and PHYSICS 136-1 and PHYSICS 135-2 and PHYSICS 136-2

subject: CHEM
name: Kinetics and Statistical Thermodynamics
description: Chemical kinetics, including experimental techniques and theories of rate processes. Statistical mechanics, including Boltzmann distribution, partition functions, and applications to thermodynamics.

subject: CHEM
name: Physical Chemistry for ISP
description: Gas laws and properties; kinetic theory; first, second, and third laws; phase equilibria; mixtures, phase diagrams, statistical thermodynamics, kinetics.
prereq: ISP enrollment; CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); MATH 281-1, MATH 281-2, MATH 281-3; or consent of department

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced Laboratory 1
description: Advanced laboratory techniques in synthetic and analytical chemistry and spectroscopy: mass spectrometry, chromatography, NMR spectroscopy, and organic synthesis techniques.
prereq: CHEM 220-0; and CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3, and CHEM 235-3 (C- or better); or equivalent

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced Laboratory 2
description: Advanced laboratory techniques in synthetic and analytical chemistry and spectroscopy, polymer characterization methods, electrochemistry, x-ray crystallography, atomic spectroscopy, and inorganic synthesis techniques.
prereq: CHEM 333-0 and CHEM 350-1 (C- or better) or equivalent

subject: CHEM
name: Advanced Laboratory 3
description: Advanced laboratory techniques in synthetic and analytical chemistry and spectroscopy: infrared and Raman spectroscopy, electronic spectroscopy, fast kinetics, organic and inorganic synthesis techniques in a self-guided project.
prereq: CHEM 342-2 or equivalent and CHEM 350-2 (C- or better)

subject: CHEM
name: Nanopatterning: Top-down meets Bottom-up
description: Introduction to current problems in nanoscale science and technology; hands-on experience with nanoscale characterization tools and benchtop nanoscale experiments. With laboratory.
prereq: CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0, or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0, or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), or equivalent

subject: CHEM
name: Green Chemistry
description: Practices of environmentally benign chemistry as applied to the chemical industry. Introduction to the concept and discipline of green chemistry; growth and expansion of the discipline in historical context from its origins in the early 1990s to the present.

subject: CHEM
name: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Advanced work for superior students through supervised reading, research, and discussion.

subject: CHEM
name: Independent Study
description: Faculty-directed research. Must be taken P/N for first 2 quarters.

subject: CFS
name: Analysis of Field Experience
description: Online course for students who intern 10 to 40 hours a week in firms and organizations throughout the world. Requires students to read, reflect upon and discuss the structure and purpose of organizations as well as workplace inclusion, teamwork, productivity, and leadership styles. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying.

subject: CFS
name: Field Studies in Environment, Science, and Sustainability
description: Explores theoretical, geographic, and historical stakes of environmental thought and practice with emphasis on Chicago-based environmental work. Students intern 10 to 40 hours a week. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

subject: CFS
name: Field Studies in Business Culture
description: Online course for students who intern 10 to 40 hours a week in firms and organizations throughout the world. Course focus on critical issues shaping business culture, especially pertaining to interns and internships. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying.

subject: CFS
name: Field Studies in Social Justice
description: Approaches to social change with focus on particular justice issues and current events. Students intern 10 to 40 hours a week in advocacy, policy, and social justice organizations. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

subject: CFS
name: Field Studies in Public Health
description: Explores foundational concepts and current issues in global and local Public Health, with emphasis on promoting health equity. Students earn 10 to 40 hours a week in health- and medicine-related organizations. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

subject: CFS
name: Field Studies in the Modern Workplace
description: Workplace culture and political theory of labor. Students intern 25 to 40 hours a week in a variety of professional fields. 2- or 3-credit enrollment option available only during summer session. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

subject: CFS
name: Legal Field Studies
description: Contemporary issues and workplace culture in the legal field. Students intern 25 to 40 hours a week in legal organizations. 2- or 3-credit enrollment option available only during summer session. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

subject: CFS
name: Business Field Studies
description: Contemporary issues and workplace culture in business. Students intern 25 to 40 hours a week in business organizations (primarily finance, consulting, and marketing). 2- or 3-credit enrollment option available only during summer session. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

subject: CFS
name: Field Studies in Civic Engagement
description: Forms of civic engagement with emphasis on local issues and approaches. Students intern 10 to 40 hours a week in civic, educational, legal, governmental, nonprofit, or community-based organizations. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

subject: CFS
name: Field Studies in Humanities
description: Labor issues through arts and cultural history, with emphasis on humanities, arts, and media in the public sphere. Students intern 10 to 40 hours a week in fields including but not limited to arts and cultural organizations. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic adviser before applying. Maximum 1 unit may apply to Weinberg College distribution credit.

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese I
description: First-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese I
description: Second-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 111-1 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese I
description: Third-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 111-2 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese I - Accelerated
description: First-quarter course of the accelerated beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese I - Accelerated
description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 115-1 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese I - Accelerated
description: Third-quarter course of the accelerated beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 115-2 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese II
description: First-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 111-3 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese II
description: Second-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 121-1 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese II
description: Third-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 121-2 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese II - Accelerated
description: First-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence with emphasis on reading and writing.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 115-3 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese II - Accelerated
description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence with emphasis on reading and writing.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-1 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese II - Accelerated
description: Third-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence with emphasis on reading and writing.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-2 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese III
description: First-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 121-3 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese III
description: Second-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-1 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese III
description: Third-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-2 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese in Business Practice 1
description: Basic business Chinese focused on professional settings. For students interested in using business-related texts to learn Chinese or aspiring to China-focused careers.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-2, CHINESE 211-2 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese III - Accelerated
description: First-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate toward advanced-level sequence with emphasis on formal speaking and writing.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-3 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese III - Accelerated
description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate toward advanced-level sequence with emphasis on formal speaking and writing.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-1 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese III - Accelerated
description: Third-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate toward advanced-level sequence with emphasis on formal speaking and writing.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-2 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese IV: Formal Speaking
description: Development of skills in speaking formal Chinese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-3 or CHINESE 212-0, or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese IV: Formal Writing
description: Development of skills in writing formal Chinese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-3 or CHINESE 212-0, or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese IV: Formal Reading
description: Development of skills in reading different types of authentic Chinese works.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 211-3 or CHINESE 212-0, or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese in Business Practice 2
description: Training for professional tasks using Chinese. Especially for students who completed CHINESE 212-0 or aspire to China-focused careers or to becoming multi-proficient business professionals.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-3, CHINESE 211-3, CHINESE 212-0 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Multinational Corporations in China
description: Training in business reading skills, with a focus on case studies, and speaking/writing skills for discussing business topics professionally. Designed for students interested in China's economic development and using Chinese in their careers.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 125-3, CHINESE 211-3, CHINESE 212-0 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese IV - Accelerated: Formal Writing and Public Speaking
description: Development of academic writing and speaking in Chinese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-3; or in three of the following: CHINESE 311-1, CHINESE 311-2, CHINESE 311-3, CHINESE 312-1, CHINESE 312-2

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese IV - Accelerated: Advanced Reading and Writing
description: Development of academic reading and writing in Chinese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-3; or in three of the following: CHINESE 311-1, CHINESE 311-2, CHINESE 311-3, CHINESE 312-1, CHINESE 312-2

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese IV - Accelerated: Media & Society
description: Development of skills in reading primary sociocultural sources.
prereq: grade of at least C- in CHINESE 215-3; or in three of the following: CHINESE 311-1, CHINESE 311-2, CHINESE 311-3, CHINESE 312-1, CHINESE 312-2

subject: CHINESE
name: Chinese V: Special Topics in Advanced Chinese
description: Standalone topics course using films, audiovisual materials, and texts in primary sources to develop ability to analyze diverse textual logic, language patterns, and cultural features. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: grade of at least C- in three of CHINESE 315-1, CHINESE 315-2, CHINESE 315-3 or equivalent

subject: CHINESE
name: Independent Study
description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Chinese.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: In this seminar course we discuss the grand challenges facing society in the coming decades, and how Civil and Environmental Engineers are meeting these challenges. Seminars will focus on key CE and EE topics, the CE & EE curricula at NU, and the career paths of recent CE & EE graduates.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Civil and Environmental Engineering Seminar
description: Introductory-level special topic seminar intended for first and second-year students.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Introductory Course in Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: Introductory-level special topics courses in civil and environmental engineering. 195 is similar to CIV_ENV 395-0 but intended for first and second-year students.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Engineering Possibilities: Decision Science in the Age of Smart Technologies
description: Define challenges facing cities, and learn how to critically evaluate different solutions, ranging from traditional to innovative. Foster critical thinking about problem definitions along with the definition of metrics that represent desirable (and undesirable) outcomes in urban systems.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Biological and Ecological Principles
description: Fundamentals of biology - including cell biology, genetics, and biochemistry - and ecology - including biological interactions, microbial ecology - and biogeochemical cycling as they apply to natural and engineered systems. Bioinformatics tools necessary for analyzing biological and ecological data.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Earth in the Anthropocene
description: Fundamentals of Earth system science and their connections to the need for humans to develop food, water, energy and infrastructure systems that has led to transformation of the Earth's surface and of its atmosphere.
prereq: MATH 220-2; CHEM 131-0, CHEM 151-0, or CHEM 171-0 is highly recommended

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Economics and Finance for Engineers
description: Principles of corporate finance; financial decisions of firms; value; risk and return; investment and capital budgeting decisions under certainty and uncertainty; performance evaluation. May not be taken for credit with or after KELLG_FE 310-0.
prereq: MATH 220-1; basic understanding of probability and economics recommended

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Mechanics of Materials I
description: Analytical and experimental study of stresses and deformations and their application to the design of machine and structural elements subjected to static, dynamic, and repeated loads.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Structural Art
description: Learn how to interpret and understand the built environment through an examination of the history of structural engineering as a creative art, with particular emphasis on technical, visual, and social analysis and critique of bridges, buildings, and designers.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Theory of Structures I
description: Deflections of structures, energy concepts, idealization of structures, truss analysis, column stability, and influence lines. Introduction to indeterminate truss and frame analyses, slope-deflection analysis, and moment distribution. Portal method.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Earth Surface Engineering
description: Fundamental properties and behavior of soils as engineering materials. Origin of soils through the properties of soil components to the strength, permeability, and deformation of soil masses.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Environmental Systems and Processes
description: Basic engineering principles required for the design, operation, analysis, and modeling of both natural and engineered systems and their application to major issues facing human and environmental health of ecosystems. Corequisite: MATH 220-2; CHEM 131-0, CHEM 151-0, or CHEM 171-0 highly recommended.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Introductory topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: Intermediate-level study of topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the department.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Professional Development Seminar I
description: Case study in engineering ethics, with discussion of topics in professional development and lifelong learning.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Professional Development Seminar II
description: Preparation for the Fundamentals of Engineering (FE) exam.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Engineering Law
description: The American legal system from an engineer's perspective. Socratic-method analysis of statutory and case law. Contract, patent, corporation, antitrust, property, and environmental law. Torts, product liability, and arbitration.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Environmental Law and Policy
description: An introduction to important aspects of environmental law and policy. Covers a wide range of environmental topics, with a focus on major federal environmental statutes.

subject: CIV_ENV
name: Civil and Environmental Engineering Systems Analysis
