subject: ENGLISH
name: Research Seminar for Literature Majors
description: For juniors and seniors. Topics vary. Students research and complete an independent term paper related to the topic of the seminar.

subject: ENGLISH
name: Senior Sequence
description: For seniors preparing an honors essay in the literature major. Students pursue individual topics under the direction of a faculty adviser and the departmental honors coordinator. Admission by application. K grade given each quarter pending completion of essay.

subject: ENGLISH
name: Senior Sequence
description: For seniors preparing an honors essay in the literature major. Students pursue individual topics under the direction of a faculty adviser and the departmental honors coordinator. Admission by application. K grade given each quarter pending completion of essay.

subject: ENGLISH
name: Independent Study
description: Individual projects with faculty guidance. Open to majors with junior or senior standing and to senior minors. May be elected two times, but only 1 unit at a time.

subject: ENTREP
name: Principles of Entrepreneurship
description: This survey-style class is designed for students with limited or no prior exposure to entrepreneurship. The class serves as the foundational course for the undergraduate minor in entrepreneurship, but is also a good choice for students who simply wish to familiarize themselves with the world of entrepreneurship. Students will be introduced to the requisite skill sets for advanced entrepreneurship coursework. They will also learn how to understand and analyze a broad range of entrepreneurial activity, and will have the opportunity to locate their own goals and values within the field of entrepreneurship. Taught with IEMS 225-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENTREP
name: Personal Branding
description: Growing and Monetizing your Fanbase is designed to expose artists to entrepreneurial thinking in building their careers. Are you a singer, actor, musician, comedian, writer, graphic artist, fashionista, or dancer that wants to promote your career? Students will be exposed to highly relevant methodologies that startup entrepreneurs use to create and grow their companies, but in this case, the corporation being grown and promoted is their talent and fans, via their own personal brand.

subject: ENTREP
name: Storytelling for Business
description: Humans have been communicating through stories for 20,000 years. They have the power to persuade, engage, and inspire action. But too often, in business, we don't think about harnessing the power of stories. Storytelling for Business will teach students how to use narrative techniques and structures to create compelling stories to help them nail an interview, motivate a team, secure funding, build a brand, and inspire customers.

subject: ENTREP
name: Engineering Entrepreneurship
description: Overview of the entrepreneurial process from an engineering perspective. Idea generation, planning, financing, marketing, protecting, staffing, leading, growing, and harvesting. Business models for startups. Lectures, guest speakers, and case studies. Taught with IEMS 325-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENTREP
name: Startup Accounting and Finance
description: This class teaches students how to manage the finances of small and early-stage businesses using accounting software. Students also learn foundational accounting principles, and will work in teams on projects driven by case studies.

subject: ENTREP
name: Entrepreneurial Sales and Marketing
description: Principles and practices for scaling entrepreneurial ventures. Application of coherent methodology to a student-run venture. Self-organizing teams develop a customer/client focus, provide for continuous improvement in successive iterations, and operate with transparency.

subject: ENTREP
name: Financing Entrepreneurial Ventures
description: Topics selected from work of current interest in entrepreneurship and innovation. May be repeated for credit.

subject: ENTREP
name: Innovate for Impact
description: This is an experiential, team-based course in which students create social-impact focused entrepreneurial ventures using both lean startup methodology and human-centered design.

subject: ENTREP
name: Leadership, Ethics, and You
description: This class is designed for students who want to explore how ethics and integrity are tied to leadership, and how developing leadership skills can contribute to students’ future successes in both entrepreneurial endeavors and more traditional careers.

subject: ENTREP
name: Entrepreneurship Demystified
description: This is a discussion and project-based course in which students explore topics in ethics and leadership with the context of working for a startup or building one's own company.

subject: ENTREP
name: Special Topics
description: Topics selected from work of current interest in entrepreneurship and innovation. May be repeated for credit.

subject: ENTREP
name: Independent Study with Farley Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation
description: Special projects under faculty direction. May be repeated for credit.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: First-Year Seminar
description: Open to first-year students in Weinberg College. Does not satisfy major/minor requirements in EPC.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: Food and Society: An Introduction
description: Overview of past and present food systems from a sociological perspective, examining the roles of culture, government policy, and social movements in shaping such systems and future alternatives. ENVR_POL 211-0 and SOCIOL 211-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: Environment and Society
description: Key environmental problems, such as climate change and oil spills; how they are shaped by the market, government regulations, and social movements; possible solutions. SOCIOL 212-0 and ENVR_POL 212-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: American Religion, Ecology and Culture
description: The historical rise of environmentalism in American culture and its impact on religious thought and practice. ENVR_POL 261-0 and RELIGION 261-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: American Environmental History
description: American history from precontact to the present, focusing on the role of the natural world in human history and the role of human thought and action in natural history. ENVR_POL 309-0 and HISTORY 309-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: Food, Politics and Society
description: Social groups, institutions, and policies shaping food production, distribution, and consumption around the world; their social and environmental consequences. Alternatives to existing food systems. SOCIOL 311-0 and ENVR_POL 311-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: Social Change and the Environment
description: The ways social patterns of production and consumption affect the natural environment, such as climate and biodiversity. Roles of social actors and structures in shaping environmental problems and policies. SOCIOL 312-0 and ENVR_POL 312-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: The Climate Crisis, Policies, and Society
description: Examination of main impacts of climate change and of different perspectives toward mitigation and adaptation: market-based, institutionalist, bio-environmentalist, social movement, and climate justice. SOCIOL 336-0 and ENVR_POL 336-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: Global Environments and World History
description: Introduction to the recent histories of environmental issues around the world, including urbanization, industrialization, population growth, commodification, empire building, intercontinental welfare, energy extraction, and new technologies. ENVR_POL 340-0 and HISTORY 376-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: Native Americans and Environmental Decision Making
description: Focus on Native Americans, culture and cultural processes, and environmental decision making. Emphasis on contemporary Native American cultures and relevant research. ENVR_POL 356-0 and PSYCH 356-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: Special Topics in Environmental Policy and Culture
description: Lecture course on environmental issues of current interest to students and faculty. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: Special Topics Seminar
description: Seminar on current environmental issues and problems. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: ENVR_POL
name: Independent Study
description: Independent project in student's area of interest. Readings and conferences. Comprehensive term paper required.

subject: ENVR_SCI
name: Earth: A Habitable Planet
description: Overview of the physical processes governing environmental systems, from lithosphere to hydrosphere to atmosphere. Physical science perspectives on current debates, such as those over water resources, energy, and climate change.

subject: ENVR_SCI
name: The Health of the Biosphere
description: Dimensions of the ecological niche; growth and regulation of populations; interactions among populations; community structure and diversity; conservation.

subject: ENVR_SCI
name: Humans and the Environment
description: Introduction to human interactions with the environment. Topics may include but are not limited to energy, sustainability, pollution, and climate change.

subject: ENVR_SCI
name: Special Topics in Environmental Sciences
description: Lecture course on environmental science topics of interest to students and faculty. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: ENVR_SCI
name: Independent Study
description: Independent research on special problems under direct supervision of a faculty adviser. Comprehensive report required.

subject: KELLG_FE
name: Principles of Finance
description: Foundation course for the certificate. Basic principles of finance, focusing on the effects of time and uncertainty on value. First half emphasizes valuation, including discounted cash flows, equity and debt valuation, the term structure of interest rates, portfolio theory, asset pricing, and efficient market theory. Second half examines firms' financing decisions, including capital budgeting, capital structure, and payout policy.

subject: KELLG_FE
name: Investments
description: Active portfolio strategies in bonds and stocks, optimal portfolio selection from the perspective of individual and institutional investors, and the role of style and performance benchmarks in portfolio management. Performance evaluation, trading costs, and other special topics.

subject: KELLG_FE
name: Derivatives
description: Use and pricing of forwards and futures, swaps, and options. Strategies for speculation and risk management, no-arbitrage pricing for forward contracts, binomial and Black-Scholes option pricing models, applications of pricing models in other contexts.

subject: KELLG_FE
name: Topics in Financial Economics
description: In-depth examination of selected issues in finance.

subject: FRENCH
name: Elementary French
description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners. Four class meetings a week.

subject: FRENCH
name: Elementary French
description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 111-1 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Elementary French
description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 111-2 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Intensive Elementary French
description: For students with some previous experience in French. Review and development of skills in speaking, understanding, reading, and writing as preparation for work at the second-year level. Four class meetings a week.

subject: FRENCH
name: Intensive Elementary French
description: For students with some previous experience in French. Review and development of skills in speaking, understanding, reading, and writing as preparation for work at the second-year level. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 115-1 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Intermediate French
description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 111-3 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Intermediate French
description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 121-1 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Intermediate French
description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 121-2 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Intensive Intermediate French
description: French language and culture: conversation, composition, reading of cultural and literary texts, and grammar review. Three class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 115-2 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Intensive Intermediate French
description: French language and culture: conversation, composition, reading of cultural and literary texts, and grammar review. Three class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 125-1 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Intensive Intermediate French
description: French language and culture: conversation, composition, reading of cultural and literary texts, and grammar review. Three class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 125-2 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Independent Study
description: Credit for 1 quarter only.

subject: FRENCH
name: Language and Culture
description: Grammar, conversation, reading, writing, and culture study. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris programs. Students completing this course must take a placement exam before continuing French at Northwestern.

subject: FRENCH
name: Culture and Society
description: Development of fluency, accuracy, and creativity in speaking, comprehension, reading, and writing French; introduction to social, cultural, and literary topics.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in FRENCH 121-3 or Department placement

subject: FRENCH
name: Writing Workshop: Cultural Encounters in Contemporary France
description: Practical study of French grammar and structure; students develop and improve writing skills through practice in preparing short compositions.

subject: FRENCH
name: Oral Workshop: Individual and Society in France Today
description: Practical course to increase listening comprehension, build vocabulary and idiom use, and enhance communication skills.

subject: FRENCH
name: Acting French
description: Use of dramatic scenes, dialogues, songs and performance to help students improve their language skills and develop their interpretive, interpersonal and intercultural competence at the Intermediate Mid/High level.
prereq: FRENCH 121-3 or FRENCH 125-3 or FRENCH 201-0 or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Reading Literatures in French
description: Introduction to texts in various genres such as essay, poetry, drama, novel, and autobiography, from at least two periods from the Middle Ages to the present.
prereq: FRENCH 202-0, AP score of 5, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Reading Cultures in French
description: Introduction to French and/or francophone cultures through texts and media from at least two periods; major themes, issues, and debates.
prereq: FRENCH 202-0, AP score of 5, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Introducing the Novel
description: Textual interpretation and analysis of short French novels from different periods, with special attention to formal issues.
prereq: FRENCH 210-0 or FRENCH 211-0, AP score of 5 in literature, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Introducing Theatre
description: Textual interpretation and analysis of French plays from different periods, with special attention to formal issues. Principles of tragedy and comedy; contemporary developments.
prereq: FRENCH 210-0 or FRENCH 211-0, AP score of 5 in literature, or consent of instructor. Credit not allowed for both FRENCH 272-0 and FRENCH 279-0

subject: FRENCH
name: Introducing Poetry
description: Textual interpretation and analysis of French poetry from different periods, with special attention to formal issues. Overview of major poetic movements.
prereq: FRENCH 210-0 or FRENCH 211-0, AP score of 5 in literature, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: French Existentialism
description: Existentialism in its literary, philosophical, and cultural manifestations.

subject: FRENCH
name: Theater in Translation
description: Representative French plays from the 17th through 20th centuries; basic concepts of genre; social and historical context. Credit not allowed for both FRENCH 279-0 and FRENCH 272-0.

subject: FRENCH
name: Language and Culture
description: Study of French language and culture in Paris. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris programs. Students completing this course must take a placement exam before continuing French at Northwestern.

subject: FRENCH
name: French Phonetics
description: Development of near-native spoken French through practice in correct pronunciation. Phonetic system of contemporary French; introduction to basic issues of theoretical phonetics.
prereq: FRENCH 202-0, FRENCH 203-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Advanced Language in Context: Society and Popular Culture
description: Practical study of structure, syntax, and usage of French through contemporary media, cinema, theater, and popular culture.

subject: FRENCH
name: Advanced Writing: Finding Your Voice in French
description: Development of written expression for different communicative needs and functions based on the study of French writing styles and techniques.

subject: FRENCH
name: Advanced Conversation: Debating Contemporary France
description: Development of advanced proficiency and confidence in spoken French through practice of speech and discussion of issues in current French media and culture. Emphasis on culturally appropriate usage.
prereq: FRENCH 202-0, FRENCH 203-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: French For Professions
description: French language as used in professional contexts. May include study of a specific field and differences from its American counterpart. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: FRENCH
name: The Middle Ages & Renaissance
description: Study of literary texts of the French Middle Ages and Renaissance with emphasis on their historical and literary-historical contexts.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Medieval French Narratives
description: Major narrative works of the French Middle Ages in historical context. Content varies; may include epics such as the Song of Roland, romances such as Chrétien de Troyes's Perceval, and narratives of childhood. Texts read in modern French versions.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Topics in Renaissance Literature
description: Study of literary and other texts of the French Renaissance with emphasis on their literary, historical, and political contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Montaigne and Modernity
description: In-depth study of the work of Michel de Montaigne and his models within the context of Renaissance history, politics and philosophy. All readings and discussion in French.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: 17th Century Literature
description: Topics and issues related to the literature and culture of 17th century France. Content varies; topics covered previously include theater and its social and political contexts, the rise of rational thought, and the development of fiction and poetry. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Sexual Politics and the Ancien Regime
description: Literary, intellectual, and political role of women in view of the debates generated by the issues of women's power in the public sphere before the French Revolution.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Rousseau and the French Revolution
description: Analysis of Rousseau's political thought and major literary works and their impact on Revolutionary ideology and culture.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Studies in the Enlightenment
description: Authors such as Rousseau, Diderot, Montesquieu, Voltaire, and Graffigny in relation to Enlightenment debates about science, religion, political authority, human nature, colonialism, gender, and slavery.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: The Novel in French
description: Content varies; may include the novel of the ancien régime, the psychological novel, and the Bildungsroman in France.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: The Invention of Modernity
description: Study of the origins of modernity in the 19th century, addressing such issues as the rise of mass culture, urbanization, and the beginnings of consumer society.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: From Modernism to Postmodernism
description: Crises and reinventions of French prose from the modernist moment of the early 20th century to the ambiguities of "engaged" literature of the 1930s to postmodernism.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: African Literatures and Cultures
description: Major issues, trends, and authors from francophone Africa. Content varies; may include Shahrazade, narratives of gender relations, law and literature, violence, and writing.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Caribbean Literatures and Cultures
description: Major issues, trends, and authors from the francophone Caribbean and its diasporas. Content varies; may include Caribbean women writers; slavery, history, and memory; Caribbean identities.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: The Maghreb and the Middle East
description: Major issues in the literatures and cultures of North Africa and the Middle East. Content varies. May include exile in writing; politics of language and translation.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: France and East Asia
description: Interdisciplinary approaches to the history of French-East Asian relations, including French representations of East Asia. May include translation, japonisme, cinema, literary and philosophical avant-gardes, and culture and globalization.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Transnational Francophone Studies
description: Exploration of cultural production in various genres from the French-speaking world, with an emphasis on themes, ideas, and/or forms that traverse national and/or cultural boundaries.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor. May be repeated for credit when content changes

subject: FRENCH
name: Giants, Cannibals, and Critique
description: Analysis of works of Rabelais and Montaigne and their techniques of satire and social critique. Readings include related selections from Erasmus, More, La Boétie, and others.

subject: FRENCH
name: Proust
description: Introduces the works of Marcel Proust, a central figure of European literature and thought.

subject: FRENCH
name: French Film
description: Topics in French cinema: for example, French classical cinema, the New Wave, postcolonial French film, the cinema of Marguerite Duras.

subject: FRENCH
name: Gender & Sexuality
description: Major trends and perspectives in gender and sexuality studies such as first and second wave feminisms, lesbian writers, AIDS literature, queer theory, gender and orientalism, cross-cultural feminism.

subject: FRENCH
name: Contemporary Theory
description: Introduction to some major trends in contemporary French theory and the way they have influenced literary studies in the United States.

subject: FRENCH
name: Topics in French Literature and Culture
description: Advanced exploration of special topics in French studies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: FRENCH
name: Political & Social Thought in France
description: Major political and social trends in France from the ancien régime to the 20th century. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Women Writing in French
description: Analysis of texts by women authors with regard to their respective social, cultural, political, and historical contexts.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Gender & Writing
description: Issues of gender and sexuality in the production of literary and other creative texts in various historical periods. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Topics in Literature and Culture
description: Topics, issues, and questions in French and francophone culture. Content varies; may include French and francophone cinema, the intellectual in France. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Topics in Literature and Culture
description: Topics, issues, and questions in French and francophone culture. Content varies; may include French and francophone cinema, the intellectual in France. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: FRENCH 271-0, FRENCH 272-0, or FRENCH 273-0, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Theory and Practice of Translation
description: Intercultural communication through analysis of translation theories and translated works; translation exercises. Content varies; genres may include prose, poetry, graphic novels, and theater.
prereq: FRENCH 301-0, FRENCH 302-0, study abroad, or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Foreign Language Teaching: Theory and Practice
description: Theoretical foundation and practical applications of second-language acquisition and applied linguistics. Analysis and design of pedagogical materials. Self-reflection and analysis of teaching style and teaching philosophy.
prereq: senior status or consent of instructor

subject: FRENCH
name: Advanced Studies in Culture and Thought
description: Theoretical perspectives and paradigms for understanding culture through in-depth study of a historical, cultural, or theoretical issue or of a literary or artistic work. Independent term paper.
prereq: senior status or consent of undergraduate advisor

subject: FRENCH
name: Independent Study
description: Independent reading and research. Topics arranged through consultation with an instructor and approval of the department.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Sexual Subjects: Introduction to Sexuality Studies
description: Survey of sexuality studies across a range of disciplines. Introduction to major theoretical and methodological approaches. Epistemology, morphology, history, subjectivity/identity, race formation, gender, social organization, and regulation.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Traditions in Feminist Thought
description: Introduction to milestone texts in the development of 200 years of British, European, and American feminist thought, with particular attention to emerging arguments and strategies around issues of gender and sexuality.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Representation
description: Representations in art and literature within their historical, social, and political contexts. Theories of spectatorship, resistance, and revision.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Sexuality & Society
description: Examination of the role of sexuality in the cultural, economic, political, and social organization of the United States. Sex work, sex tourism, sexual migration, LGBT social movements, and moral panics. SOCIOL 232-0 and GNDR_ST 232-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Politics, and Philosophy
description: Role of gender difference in the main political-philosophical traditions: social contract, liberalism, republicanism, socialism-Marxism, critical theory. Classics of feminist and political thought (Wollstonecraft, Mill, Taylor, Engels) and contemporary debates. PHIL 221-0 and GNDR_ST 233-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Language & Gender
description: Exploration of socially significant differences in the language used by/about/to men and women, focusing on the role of language in constructing gender as part of local communities of practice. LING 223-0 and GNDR_ST 234-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Beyond the Binary: Transgender and Race
description: Exploration of transgender history, identity, and expression, with a focus on the intersection of gender and race.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender Issues in Science and Health
description: Aspects of gender in the cultures of science and medicine.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and History
description: Historical considerations of gender and/or sexuality. Topics may cover different historical time periods. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: US Gay and Lesbian History
description: Gender, sexuality, and the rise of modern lesbian and gay identities. Lecture and discussion. HISTORY 324-0 and GNDR_ST 324-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Language & Sexuality
description: The use of language to construct sexual identity, focusing on the language of and about gay men and lesbians. Topics include heteronormativity, identity labels and categories, gender versus sexuality, and cross-cultural sexual diversity. Taught with GNDR_ST 327-0; may not receive credit for both courses.
prereq: any 200 level course in linguistics or consent of instructor

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Sociology of Gender and Sexuality
description: Gender and issues of social reproduction and social change, with an emphasis on sexuality and reproduction.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Health
description: Health-related topics concerning gender and/or sexuality. Topics include reproductive health, sexual health, HIV/AIDS, women's health movements, trans* health and activism and disability studies. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and the Law
description: Examination of the changing role of law in governing gender and sexual relations in America. Legal definitions of gender and sexuality in the household, the marketplace, and the state. GNDR_ST 340-0 and LEGAL_ST 340-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Transnational Perspectives on Gender and Sexuality
description: Studies of gender and sexuality in relation to globalization or non-US/non-Western cultures. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Research Seminar in Gender & Sexuality Studies
description: Students research and complete a research paper or project on a topic of choice. Course number indicates distribution area in which a seminar counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Research Seminar in Gender & Sexuality Studies
description: Students research and complete a research paper or project on a topic of choice. Course number indicates distribution area in which a seminar counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Research Seminar in Gender & Sexuality Studies
description: Students research and complete a research paper or project on a topic of choice. Course number indicates distribution area in which a seminar counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Public Policy
description: Studies of legal systems and public policy. Specific topics may include domestic violence and abortion legislation. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Political Theory
description: Studies in political theory relating to gender and sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender and Citizenship
description: Examinations of conventional conceptions of political participation and counter-public spheres informed by feminist activism and feminist and gender theory.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Literature
description: Studies of literary texts in the context of gender theory, feminism, or sexuality studies. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Drama
description: Studies in gender and/or sexuality in the context of theater and drama in or across historical periods. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Postcolonial Studies and Gender and Sexuality
description: Postcolonial approaches to literature and theory. Topics include orientalism and diaspora theory as they relate to gender and sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Popular Culture
description: Cultural studies perspective on selected topics in popular culture as they relate to gender and/or sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Performance
description: Selected topics concerning theories of performance in relation to gender and/or sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Film
description: Primary emphasis on representations of gender and sexuality in film and film theory. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Gender, Sexuality, and Digital Technologies
description: Theories concerning gender and sexuality in digital representations, particularly Internet related. Content varies by quarter.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Internship in Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Field research and practical work experience in activist organizations; biweekly meeting with the instructor and other interns for discussion of internship experiences and common readings.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Black Feminist Theory
description: Survey of black feminist theories. Content may vary by quarter. Fulfills the major's theory requirement.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Queer Theory
description: Survey of queer theories and methodologies. Fulfills the major's theory requirement. Content varies by quarter.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Race, Gender, and Sexuality
description: Literature and/or theory concerned primarily with the intersections of race and/or ethnicity and gender and sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Topics in Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Topics vary. For example: masculinity; gender, race, and reproduction; gender, law, and public policy; Asian American women's history; women artists and their publics. May be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Senior Capstone Seminar
description: Introduction to research methods in the interdisciplinary study of gender and sexuality.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Feminist Theory
description: Survey of gender and feminist theory. Content may vary by quarter. Fulfills the major's theory requirement.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Senior Research Seminar
description: Students work with an adviser and begin research on a senior thesis project, meeting on a reduced schedule over two quarters.

subject: GNDR_ST
name: Independent Study
description: Individual tutorials or research projects.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Freshman Seminar
description: Broad engineering or interdisciplinary subjects of current interest.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Dialog I
description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Dialog II
description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Dialog III
description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Dialog IV
description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Discourse I
description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-1.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Discourse II
description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-2.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Discourse III
description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-3.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Discourse IV
description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-4.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Analysis I
description: Introduction to linear algebra from computational, mathematical, and applications viewpoints. Computational methods using a higher-level software package such as MATLAB.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Analysis II
description: Linear algebra and introduction to vector methods in engineering analysis. Statics and dynamics of rigid bodies and matrix analysis of trusses and networks. Engineering design problems.
prereq: C- or better in GEN_ENG 205-1; MATH 220-1

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Analysis III
description: Dynamic behavior of the elements. Modeling of mechanical (both translational and rotational), electrical, thermal, hydraulic, and chemical systems composed of those elements.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Engineering Analysis IV
description: Solution methods for ordinary differential equations, including exact, numerical, and qualitative methods. Applications and modeling principles; solution techniques.
prereq: C- or better in GEN_ENG 205-2; MATH 220-2

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis I
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-1. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis II
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-2. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis III
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-3. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis IV
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-4. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Honor Engineering Analysis
description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-1 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Honors Engineering Analysis
description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-2 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Honors Engineering Analysis
description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-3 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Honors Engineering Analysis IV
description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-4 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Analy/Comp Graph
description: Introduction to AutoCAD, geographic information systems (GIS), and electronic surveying and measuring.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Analy/Comp Graph II
description: Introduction to AutoCAD, geographic information systems (GIS), and electronic surveying and measuring.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Special Topics in Engineering
description: Intermediate-level topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the curriculum committee.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Domestic Study Affiliated
description: Fulltime registration in an academic program in the continental United States that is affiliated with Northwestern. Upon successful completion of the program, registration is replaced with credits transferred from the affiliated institution.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Special Topics in Engineering
description: Topics suggested by faculty and approved by the curriculum committee.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Selected Topics in Engineering
description: Topics of limited scope as suggested by faculty and approved by the curriculum committee.

subject: GEN_ENG
name: Independent Study
description: Independent study on an engineering subject supervised by a faculty member and concluding with a final report.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Introductory Topics in Language Study I
description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the introductory level. Permission required in advance.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Introductory Topics in Language Study II
description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the introductory level. Permission required in advance.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Introductory Topics in Language Study III
description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the introductory level. Permission required in advance.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Internship
description: Restricted to Weinberg College students who need documentation of an internship on their transcripts. Requires approval of the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs. Contact college advisers for more information.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Intermediate Topics in Language Study I
description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the intermediate level. Permission required in advance.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Intermediate Topics in Language Study II
description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the intermediate level. Permission required in advance.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Intermediate Topics in Language Study III
description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the intermediate level. Permission required in advance. Does not automatically satisfy the Weinberg College foreign language proficiency requirement.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Arch Scholar Mentoring Program
description: A weekly 1-hour workshop for first-year students in the Arch Scholar programs. Workshops will focus on academic skills, professional development, and college success strategies. Only two excused absences are allowed. Instructor permission to register is required.

subject: GEN_LA
name: UPAL: Strategies for Advancing Learning
description: Peer-mentored weekly small-group meetings about enhanced learning strategies. Time management, study strategies, interacting with faculty, and other topics.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Science Research Workshops
description: Learn about entering research with the help of a peer group leader and writing a research proposal for summer funding. Instructor permission or prior attendance at a Finding a Lab Workshop run by the Office of Undergraduate Research required. Grade of satisfactory given to students who attend and participate in at least 7 of the weekly workshops.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Residence-Linked Seminar - I (Natural Sciences)
description: Seminar for students in a residential college or community on a theme of common interest. Meets in the residence and is directed by an associated faculty member. Enrollment is normally limited to 10 students. Proposals for seminars must be approved by the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs of Weinberg College.

subject: GEN_LA

Enrollment is normally limited to 10 students. Proposals for seminars must be approved by the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs of Weinberg College.

description: Seminar for students in a residential college or community on a theme of common interest. Meets in the residence and is directed by an associated faculty member. Enrollment is normally limited to 10 students. Proposals for seminars must be approved by the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs of Weinberg College.

Enrollment is normally limited to 10 students. Proposals for seminars must be approved by the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs of Weinberg College.

subject: GEN_LA

description: Seminar for students in a residential college or community on a theme of common interest. Meets in the residence and is directed by an associated faculty member. Enrollment is normally limited to 10 students. Proposals for seminars must be approved by the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs of Weinberg College.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Undergraduate Research
description: Required registration for students receiving summer research grants from Weinberg College or the Undergraduate Research Grants Committee. Grade of satisfactory will be entered after final report is submitted.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Student Organized Seminar
description: Student-initiated seminar, supervised by a sponsoring faculty member. See Weinberg College Policies section of the Undergraduate Catalog for more information. P/N grading only.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Study Abroad Affiliated
description: Registration in an academic program outside the United States. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Study Abroad Summer PT
description: Registration in an academic program outside the United States. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

subject: GEN_LA

description: Registration in an academic program outside the United States. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Study at NU-Qatar, Doha Campus
description: For Evanston-based Northwestern students studying in Qatar (NU-Q) for a term. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

subject: GEN_LA
name: Domestic Study - Affiliated
description: Registration in an academic program in the United States that is affiliated with Northwestern. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

subject: GEN_MUS

description: Audition required.

subject: GEN_MUS

description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Introduction to Music
description: Key concepts and contexts for becoming an informed listener and critical thinker with respect to a broad range of musical styles and genres and for acquiring the skills and vocabulary to discuss and write about music effectively. Individual sections may vary from quarter to quarter; see specific section descriptions for more information. No previous musical training or ability to read music notation is required. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Selected Topics in Applied Music for Non-Majors
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: GEN_MUS
name: History of the Symphony
description: Study of music for the symphony orchestra from the 17th century to the modern period. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

subject: GEN_MUS
name: History of Opera
description: History of opera from its origins in Italy at the end of the 16th century to the modern period. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

subject: GEN_MUS
name: History of Rock
description: The basic elements of rock from its roots in pop, country and western, and rhythm and blues to the present. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Harmony
description: A basic course in music theory fundamentals, including harmonic materials and tonal structures. Analysis of harmonic structures; harmonization of melodies. (II. Formal studies)

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Form and Analysis
description: Nature of musical forms found in musical literature from renaissance to the present; analysis of musical examples.
prereq: GEN_MUS 252-0, or music-reading skills and some understanding of harmony

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Non-Major Private Voice-Intermediate
description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Western Musical Tradition
description: Major genres and composers from 1600 to 1825. Primary emphasis on the generations of Bach and Handel, Haydn and Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert.
prereq: GEN_MUS 170-0 or equivalent. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Western Musical Tradition
description: Major genres and composers from 1825 to the present.
prereq: GEN_MUS 170-0 or equivalent. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Non-Major Piano and Organ
description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Selected Topics for Non-Majors
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Non-Major Private Voice-Advanced
description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Choral Organizations
description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

subject: GEN_MUS
name: Band Organizations
description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

subject: GEN_MUS

subject: GEOG
name: World Biogeography
description: Geography of the world's major ecosystems based on the global climate model. Physical processes of soil formation and vegetation development in various ecosystems. Human impacts on natural systems resulting from past and present land-use practices.

subject: GEOG
name: Atmosphere and Climate
description: Nature and composition of the atmosphere, principles of atmospheric motion, global circulation model, cyclonic storms; climates and climatic change.

subject: GEOG
name: Economic Geography
description: Population, natural resources, land use, commodity production, and trade, with an emphasis on the world scale. Industrial location theory and global economic structures.

subject: GEOG
name: Geography of Chicago & Its Region
description: Chicago as an example and model of city form. Physical environments of the Chicago region and their influence on settlement. Evolution of the geography of Chicago and its suburbs from the 19th century to the present, with an emphasis on recent trends.

subject: GEOG
name: North America
description: Detailed study of the regional geography of the United States and Canada. The regional distribution of landform types. Patterns of culture, history, and economic development that underlie the distribution of distinctive lifeways in the two countries.

subject: GEOG
name: The Human Use of the Earth
description: Geography of the earth's natural environments as modified by human agency. Natural versus anthropogenic environmental change. Processes of habitat alteration in hunter-gatherer societies. Impacts of modern agriculture and forestry.

subject: GEOG
name: Principles of Cartography
description: Design, construction, and use of thematic maps for effective presentation of spatial data. Typography and symbolization. Coordinate systems and map projections.

subject: GEOG
name: Geographic Information Systems
description: Methods and techniques of digital cartography; encoding and analysis of spatial information; applications to archaeology, environmental sciences, and business geographics.

subject: GEOG
name: Independent Study
description: Independent research projects. Open to qualified advanced students with consent of department.

subject: GERMAN
name: Beginning German
description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.
prereq: None or one year of high-school German or placement exam results

subject: GERMAN
name: Beginning German
description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.

subject: GERMAN
name: Beginning German
description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.

subject: GERMAN
name: Intermediate German
description: This sequence offers students a systematic review of German language and culture. The class fosters learning in the four modalities: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.
