subject: GERMAN
name: German for Research
description: Introduction to the translation of scholarly and scientific German texts. No prerequisites in the language.

subject: GERMAN
name: Intensive Beginning German through Musical Journeys in Vienna
description: Interdisciplinary course offering musically interested students the opportunity to acquire German language skills through an immersion in the musical and cultural history of Vienna.
prereq: None or one year of high-school German or placement exam results

subject: GERMAN
name: Focus Reading
description: Course for students who would like to explore German texts in more depth. Examines contemporary German culture. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Does not count for the language requirement. (This course will not count for the language requirement but may be taken concurrently with GERMAN 102-3).

subject: GERMAN
name: Focus Speaking
description: Practical training in listening comprehension and speaking. Examines contemporary German culture. Does not count for the language requirement. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. (This course will not count for the language requirement but may be taken concurrently with GERMAN 102-3).

subject: GERMAN
name: Focus Writing
description: Development of written proficiency in German through analysis and production of portraits, descriptions, narratives, reviews of films, reports, argumentative essays, advertisements, and interpretations of literary works.

subject: GERMAN
name: Focus Writing
description: Development of written proficiency in German through analysis and production of portraits, descriptions, narratives, reviews of films, reports, argumentative essays, advertisements, and interpretations of literary works.

subject: GERMAN
name: Current Events in German Media
description: Exploration of current events in a variety of German media (newspapers, TV, Internet, etc.). Topics include politics, music, film, sports, and literature.

subject: GERMAN
name: German in the Business World
description: German language study oriented toward business-related communication situations, such as social interactions with customers, business travel, basic business letters.

subject: GERMAN
name: German Culture through Film
description: Introduction to 20th century German cinema. Discussion of German identity, culture, history, and politics. Course emphasizes cultural knowledge and German language skills.

subject: GERMAN
name: History, Politics, and Culture in 21st Century German
description: In-depth cultural and linguistic exploration of history, politics, and current issues (e.g., integration of foreigners, multicultural life) in Germany.

subject: GERMAN
name: Introduction to Literature: 1800-1900
description: Introduction to representative texts and writers of 19th century German literature and familiarizes them with literary analysis and genres.

subject: GERMAN
name: Introduction to German Literature: 1900-1945
description: Introduction to representative German texts and writers of the first half of the 20th century, when the First World War, the Weimar Republic, and the Third Reich marked the demise of the German Empire.

subject: GERMAN
name: Introduction to Literature: 1945-today
description: Introduction to representative short stories by major German-speaking authors since 1945. The stories represent a dynamic period in German literature and highlight important social, political, and intellectual issues.

subject: GERMAN
name: German History from 1789-1989
description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history from the consolidation of the nation in the aftermath of the French Revolution to reunification at the end of the Cold War.

subject: GERMAN
name: German History from 1789-1989
description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history from the consolidation of the nation in the aftermath of the French Revolution to reunification at the end of the Cold War.

subject: GERMAN
name: Austrian Literature
description: Overview and introduction to contemporary Austria-the land, its people, and cultural institutions-through newer writers such as Hackl, Handke, Haslinger, Helfer, Jelinek, Nöstlinger, Reichart, Schlag, and Turrini.

subject: GERMAN
name: Contemporary Germany
description: The German political, social, and cultural scene after 1945.
prereq: None. May be repeated for credit with different topic

subject: GERMAN
name: New Voices in German Literature
description: Introduction to contemporary German literature in English translation. Topics vary and may include the contemporary historical novel, short story, novel, or memoir.

subject: GERMAN
name: German Film
description: In-depth study of German films and cultural background. Topics may vary-for example, the pioneer film or "new" German cinema.
prereq: None. May be repeated for credit with different topic

subject: GERMAN
name: Berlin and the Culture of Democracy
description: History and culture of the city from 1900 to the present, including the Weimar period, Nazi regime, the divisions of the Cold War, and the newly unified capital.

subject: GERMAN
name: The Theme of Faust Through the Ages
description: Faust theme in literature and music through shifting intellectual and social climates from the 16th century to the present.

subject: GERMAN
name: Jews and Germans: An Intercultural History I
description: Exploration of Jewish encounters with German culture. German Jewry from the 18th century to the end of the 19th century, when Jews were granted legal standing as German citizens.

subject: GERMAN
name: Jews and Germans: An Intercultural History II
description: Jewish culture-German culture exploration. German-speaking Jewry from the late 19th century to 1933.

subject: GERMAN
name: Kafka and Nietzsche
description: Exploration of two key figures in German modernity. Analysis of the relation between philosophy and literature; inquiry into the idea of the "ascetic ideal."

subject: GERMAN
name: Turn-of-the-Century Vienna
description: Literature and thought of fin de siècle Vienna and their impact on modern consciousness. Fiction, poetry, essays, and plays by Freud, Schnitzler, Wittgenstein, Hofmannsthal, Musil, Karl Kraus, and Schoenberg.

subject: GERMAN
name: Imagining Modern Jewish Culture in Yiddish and German
description: History and character of Yiddish and the development of modern German culture and German-Jewish culture. Appreciation of the variety of "Judaisms" imagined and reimagined during modern European history.
prereq: None. GERMAN 242-0 and JWSH_ST 242-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses

subject: GERMAN
name: Analyzing Freud
description: Freud's work from a comparative and interdisciplinary perspective. Fundamental texts by Freud in dialogue with related materials that situate him in historical, cultural, and intellectual context.

subject: GERMAN
name: Special Topics in German Literature and Culture
description: Studies of a major author, a prominent theme in German literature or culture, a movement, or a genre. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: GERMAN
name: Special Topics in German Literature and Culture
description: Topics vary-for example, the fairy tale, Germanic mythology.

subject: GERMAN
name: Learning Diversity: Germany and Global Migration
description: Explores how migration from and to Germany has impacted and shaped the country's political, social, and cultural development as an increasingly diverse country.

subject: GERMAN
name: Introduction to Yiddish Culture: Images of the Shtetl
description: Analysis and discussion of the literary, visual, and filmic images of the communal life developed by Eastern European Jews and inseparably associated with them. GERMAN 266-0, JWSH_ST 266-0 and YIDDISH 266-0 taught together; students may receive credit for only one of these.

subject: GERMAN
name: Luther and the West
description: Examination of Luther's work in the context of his life and times. Introduces basic dimensions of Western thought, showing how theology relates to broader cultural, political, social, and aesthetic issues. GERMAN 272-0 and RELIGION 272-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GERMAN
name: Speaking as Discovery
description: A course to improve German listening and speaking skills to the advanced level. Uses current cultural texts, films, and television broadcasts.

subject: GERMAN
name: Writing as Discovery
description: Practice of advanced and sophisticated structures of written German through a series of linguistic exercises, including a biographical piece of writing.

subject: GERMAN
name: German Media
description: Current political and cultural events in Germany and Europe. Topics from German language media, including newspapers, magazines, Internet sources, and news broadcasts. Discussion of journalistic differences.

subject: GERMAN
name: Advanced Business German: the German Economy
description: Germany's economy, its current problems, business practices, and differences from the United States.

subject: GERMAN
name: Advanced Business German: Marketing and Management
description: Students gain skills to function in a multitude of German business contexts, such as management and marketing. They also increase their cross-cultural knowledge and intercultural competency.

subject: GERMAN
name: Reason, Revolution, and Despair: 1800-1900
description: Discussion of key texts in German intellectual history from the Enlightenment to the prerevolutionary period in the 1830s.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: Myth and Modernity: 1900-1945
description: Literature and thought, events, and ideologies that shaped German cultural, political, and social life from 1900 to 1945, during the Weimar Republic and the Nazi state.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: Recoveries and Transitions: 1945-Present
description: Examination of the relationship of literature and film to the sociopolitical sphere since 1945.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: German Contributions to World Literature
description: Topics vary-for example, Rilke's poetry; Nietzsche's influence on literature; Thomas Mann; Hesse, the German novel, and the mystic tradition; German intellectual history.
prereq: None. May be repeated for credit with different topic

subject: GERMAN
name: Rhyme and Reason in German Poetry
description: Introduction to German poetry from the early 18th century to the present. Concentrates on the main formal categories of poetry as well as the main topics and themes of German poetry.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: Modern German Drama
description: Plays by authors ranging from Heinrich von Kleist to Peter Weiss, from the perspective of the stage as a "moral institution."

subject: GERMAN
name: German Cultural Studies
description: Exploration of key concepts, major figures, and cultural and literary themes in German studies and interdisciplinary fields such as music, art, political science, media studies, and popular culture.

subject: GERMAN
name: German Expressionism
description: German Expressionism in its most extreme literary and artistic reactions to the impact of modernity, war, and revolution and on the individual and collective experience in Berlin from 1910 to 1920.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: Brecht: Theater, Film, and Media
description: Introduction to Bertolt Brecht's theater in the 1920s and early 1930s during the Weimar Republic. Historical critical review of the still-evolving media of film and radio.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: Shattered Worlds: Representation after the Shoa
description: Examination of the role of German literature and art in the creation of historical consciousness in the postwar period.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: Literature of a Divided Nation
description: Study of the literature and culture of the German Democratic Republic within social, political, and historical contexts.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: Writers and their Critics
description: Study of the texts of leading writers in German through a discussion of the criticism these texts have evoked. Emphasis on 20th and 21st century criticism.

subject: GERMAN
name: Minority Voices in Germany
description: Study of minority literatures in Germany (including Turkish, Italian, Afro German, and Jewish) within social, political, and historical contexts.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: Science and Culture in Germany
description: Exploration of key texts popularizing major scientific innovations in Germany. The focus is on tracing the scientific, political, philosophical, aesthetic history of German as a "green nation" from the 18th century until today.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: German History: Weimar and Nazi Germany
description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history covering Weimar and Nazi Germany. GERMAN 344-1 and HISTORY 344-1 are taught together: may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GERMAN
name: German History: Germany Since 1945
description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history covering Germany beginning in 1945 to reunification at the end of the Cold War. GERMAN 344-2 and HISTORY 344-2 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GERMAN
name: Topics in German Literature and Culture
description: In-depth study of topics in German literature and/or pivotal periods in German culture.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature). May be repeated for credit with different topic

subject: GERMAN
name: Topics in German Literature and Culture
description: In-depth study of topics in German literature and/or pivotal periods in German culture.
prereq: None. May be repeated for credit with different topic

subject: GERMAN
name: History of the Holocaust
description: Origins and development of the massacre of European Jewry during World War II. GERMAN 349-0 and HISTORY 349-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GERMAN
name: Yiddish Culture and the Holocaust
description: Analysis of modern Yiddish literature before the Holocaust as well as literary work that emerged from Yiddish-speaking writers who survived the Second World War.
prereq: None. GERMAN 366-0, JWSH_ST 366-0 and YIDDISH 366-0 taught together; may receive credit for only one course

subject: GERMAN
name: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Advanced work through supervised reading, research, and discussion.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GERMAN
name: Independent Study
description: Open to outstanding German majors with senior standing.
prereq: Three 200-level courses in German (at least one in literature)

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Introduction to International Public Health
description: Introduces students to pressing disease and health care problems worldwide. The course identifies the main actors, institutions, practices, and forms of knowledge production characteristic of what we call "global health" today, and explores the factors that shape patterns and experiences of illness and healthcare across societies.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Global Bioethics
description: Global health is a popular field of work and study for Americans, but though entered with the best of intentions, the work is beset with ethical questions, concerns, and dilemmas. In this course, students will assess emblematic ethical challenges in global health and consider approaches to addressing them.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Global Health & Indigenous Medicine
description: Exploration of a variety of healing systems, their relationship to global health, and the factors underlying why people choose one over another.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Biomedicine and Culture
description: Comparative exploration of biomedical cultures in different contexts, both in the U.S. and other countries. This course covers how biomedicine intersects with technology, consumerism, politics, economics, culture, power, and place. It further investigates the possibilities and limitations of biomedicine across the globe, particularly regarding how biomedical cultures affect and are affected by patients and health care workers.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: International Perspectives on Mental Health
description: Cross-cultural and international perspectives on mental health issues and examination of the impact of psychological illness on the global burden of disease.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Global Health in Human History
description: Exploration of paleopathology, including records of pre- and proto-historic adaptations to human disease, health, and medicine. The biocultural perspective on patterns of disease links past perspectives and current realities.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Biomedicine and World History
description: Introduction to the social, political, scientific, and economic forces allowing biomedical systems to become synonymous with global health governance. GBL_HLTH 309-0 and HISTORY 379-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Supervised Global Health Research
description: Majors and minors are encouraged to do supervised public health research on campus and abroad. Students receive elective credit for this course only when taught abroad, however.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Supervised Global Health Research
description: Majors and minors are encouraged to do supervised public health research on campus and abroad. Students receive elective credit for this course only when taught abroad, however.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Health Care Systems in Europe and the United States
description: Provides students with an understanding of the various ways in which health care systems are organized in European countries, the problems they face, and the reforms implemented or proposed at the national and EU levels. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Public Health in Europe: Issues and Policies
description: Examines issues and debates on health policy in France and the EU, including primary health issues, health insurance, health inequalities, HIV/AIDS, SARS, elderly care, and genetically modified organisms. Lectures are supplemented by visits to relevant sites. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: International Organizations and Health: A Research Seminar
description: Students design team research projects, learn about research methodology, discuss their research progress, and present findings. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Health and Community Development in South Africa
description: Health-related issues confronting South Africa, their social and economic impact, efforts to address them. Apartheid and post-transition policies. Demographics, prevention, and treatment of both infectious and chronic non-communicable diseases. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Public Health in South Africa
description: Context of and responses to public health issues in South Africa, including HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, malnutrition and poverty, psychosocial rehabilitation, and environmental and occupational health. Lectures are supplemented by visits to relevant sites. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Development Perspectives on Health in South Africa Through Community Engagement
description: Reflection on service-learning experiences at community organizations in relation to theories of international development and global health. Focus on how health-related issues, including HIV/ AIDS, malnutrition, poverty, the environment, occupational health, and gender, impact development. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Qualitative Research Methods in Global Health
description: This course emphasizes research skills acquisition in a practical manner. Topics include how to design, conduct, analyze and write up qualitative ethnographic research. The course covers research methodologies, ethics and Institutional Review Boards, and ethnographic field methods such as participant observation, qualitative interviewing, life histories, focus groups, data coding and analysis. Students acquire research skills while receiving significant feedback throughout.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: War and Public Health
description: Comparative overview of the impact of armed conflict on public health and healthcare delivery worldwide. Historical and contemporary case studies. Specific health needs of refugees and vulnerable populations.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: The Social Determinants of Health
description: Advanced introduction to socioeconomic, political, and cultural determinants of health disparities between social groups and categories. Case studies from the United States, South Africa, and Brazil.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Global Health from Policy to Practice
description: Examines global health and development policy, from the politics of policy-making to the impacts of policy on global health practice and local realities. This course highlights the histories and material, political, and social realities of policy and its application. The course draws on case studies of policy makers, economists, public officials, health care workers, and aid recipients.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Volunteerism and the Ethics of Help
description: Explores the ethics of altruism through the discourses and practices that make up volunteering, from the perspectives of volunteers, hosts, and a range of others both promoting and critiquing volunteerism. What motivates people to volunteer among strangers or in unfamiliar contexts? What are the implications for volunteers, and communities and institutions where foreign volunteering takes place?

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: History of Reproductive Health
description: This course concerns the history of human reproduction from multiple vantage points. Since reproduction is often about power, the course is framed around the distribution of power in matters of reproduction; as such we will pay particular attention during this class to struggles over matters of reproduction as we explore historical changes and continuities in reproduction globally since 1900.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Public Health in China
description: Examination of China's public health system. Focus on role of government, emerging environmental problems, food safety, and prevalent communicable and non-communicable diseases. Restricted to students in Northwestern's China program.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Traditional Chinese Medicine
description: Introduces traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) principles and methods as they relate to Chinese culture and philosophy, including TCM diagnostics and therapies. Compares and discusses integration of TCM and Western medicine. Restricted to students in Northwestern's China program.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Special Topics in Global Health
description: Advanced work in areas of developing interest and special significance. Can be repeated for credit with a different topic. Offered on campus and on Northwestern programs abroad. Recent courses include Ecology of Infant Feeding, Native American Health, and Public Health and Mental Health in Serbia.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Special Topics in Global Health
description: Advanced work in areas of developing interest and special significance. Can be repeated for credit with a different topic. Offered on campus and on Northwestern programs abroad. Recent courses include Ecology of Infant Feeding, Native American Health, and Public Health and Mental Health in Serbia.

subject: GBL_HLTH
name: Independent Study
description: Advanced work under faculty supervision. May be taken twice for credit but does not count toward the core or elective requirements.

subject: GREEK
name: Elementary Greek
description: Vocabulary, forms, and syntax of Attic Greek. Course one of three.

subject: GREEK
name: Elementary Greek
description: Vocabulary, forms, and syntax of Attic Greek. Course two of three.

subject: GREEK
name: Elementary Greek
description: Vocabulary, forms, and syntax of Attic Greek. Course three of three.

subject: GREEK
name: Accelerated Elementary Ancient and Biblical Greek
description: This is the first in an accelerated two-quarter series designed to teach students to read ancient Greek texts, from the biblical New Testament to Homeric poetry and Platonic philosophy. These two quarters will teach all the fundamentals of grammar and vocabulary and lead students directly into a course dedicated to reading the Greek New Testament, and classical Greek texts thereafter. Usually taught in the Winter.

subject: GREEK
name: Accelerated Elementary Ancient and Biblical Greek
description: This is the second in an accelerated two-quarter series designed to teach students to read ancient Greek texts, from the biblical New Testament to Homeric poetry and Platonic philosophy. These two quarters will teach all the fundamentals of grammar and vocabulary and lead students directly into a course dedicated to reading the Greek New Testament, and classical Greek texts thereafter. Usually taught in the Spring.

subject: GREEK
name: Introduction to Greek Literature
description: Review of basic grammar and vocabulary. Representative selections from Greek authors in their historical and cultural contexts.

subject: GREEK
name: Introduction to Greek Literature
description: Review of basic grammar and vocabulary. Representative selections from Greek authors in their historical and cultural contexts.

subject: GREEK
name: Introduction to Greek Literature
description: Review of basic grammar and vocabulary. Representative selections from Greek authors in their historical and cultural contexts.

subject: GREEK
name: Introduction to Greek Literature: Intensive
description: For students who have completed GREEK 201-1 or equivalent. Review of ancient Greek grammar and syntax and development of reading skills to prepare for third-year level. Four classes a week. May not receive credit for both GREEK 201-4 and GREEK 201-2, GREEK 201-3.

subject: GREEK
name: Readings in Greek Literature
description: Selected authors and topics. Topics recently offered include Homer, Plato, Aeschylus, Herodotus, Sophocles, and Thucydides.
prereq: GREEK 201-3 or consent of instructor. May be repeated for credit with different topics

subject: GREEK
name: Independent Study
description: Individual program of study under the direction of a faculty member. For advanced students only. Permission of department required.

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew I
description: This sequence offers students a systematic introduction to mainly conversational Hebrew language and culture. Emphasizes the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.
prereq: None or one year of high-school Hebrew or placement exam results

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew I
description: This sequence offers students a systematic introduction to mainly conversational Hebrew language and culture. Emphasizes the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew I
description: This sequence offers students a systematic introduction to mainly conversational Hebrew language and culture. Emphasizes the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew II
description: This sequence further develops speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills in Hebrew. Offers also insights into Hebrew culture and history. Uses authentic written and audiovisual materials, including newspapers, short stories, poems, television, film.

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew II
description: This sequence further develops speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills in Hebrew. Offers also insights into Hebrew culture and history. Uses authentic written and audiovisual materials, including newspapers, short stories, poems, television, film.

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew II
description: This sequence further develops speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills in Hebrew. Offers also insights into Hebrew culture and history. Uses authentic written and audiovisual materials, including newspapers, short stories, poems, television, film.

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew III:Topics in Hebrew Literature
description: Hebrew language, literature, and culture. Review of more complex grammar including the development of reading, writing, and speaking. Material includes authentic written and audiovisual works and newspaper articles.

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew III: Topics in Hebrew Literature
description: Hebrew language, literature, and culture. Review of more complex grammar including the development of reading, writing, and speaking. Material includes authentic written and audiovisual works and newspaper articles.

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew III: Topics in Hebrew Literature
description: Hebrew language, literature, and culture. Review of more complex grammar including the developemnt of reading, writing, and speaking. Material includes authentic written and audiovisual works and newspaper articles.

subject: HEBREW
name: Current Events in Israel: Israeli Society through Online News Media
description: This course focuses on current events in Israel through in-depth exploration of online news media sources such as foreign newspaper articles and videos. Students will gain respect for alternative ideas and diversity of views and learn how news and public opinion are chosen, disseminated, shared. The course focuses on reading, listening, discussion and on building a comprehensive Hebrew vocabulary.
prereq: HEBREW 121-3 or permission of the instructor. May be repeated for credit with different topic

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew IV: Advanced Topics in Hebrew Literature
description: Literature Reading 20th-century Hebrew literature. Presentations, discussion, and essays in Hebrew.

subject: HEBREW
name: Hebrew IV: Advanced Topics In Hebrew Literature
description: Literature Reading 20th-century Hebrew literature. Presentations, discussion, and essays in Hebrew.

subject: HEBREW
name: Advanced Topics in Hebrew Literature
description: Literature Reading 20th-century Hebrew literature. Presentations, discussion, and essays in Hebrew.

subject: HEBREW
name: Independent Study
description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Hebrew.

subject: HIND_URD
name: Hindi-Urdu I
description: Beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari script only. Prerequisite - none.

subject: HIND_URD
name: Hindi-Urdu I
description: Beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari script only.
prereq: grade of at least C- in HIND_URD 111-1 or equivalent

subject: HIND_URD
name: Hindi-Urdu I
description: Beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari script only.
prereq: grade of at least C- in HIND_URD 111-2 or equivalent

subject: HIND_URD
name: Accelerated Hindi-Urdu Literacy
description: One-quarter course for speakers of Hindi-Urdu with no literacy skills. Devanagari and Nastaliq scripts; broad overview of Hindi-Urdu grammar.

subject: HIND_URD
name: Hindi-Urdu II
description: Intermediate-level sequence developing literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari and Nastaliq scripts.
prereq: grade of at least C- in HIND_URD 111-3 or equivalent

subject: HIND_URD
name: Hindi-Urdu II
description: Intermediate-level sequence developing literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari and Nastaliq scripts.
prereq: grade of at least C- in HIND_URD 121-1 or equivalent

subject: HIND_URD
name: Hindi-Urdu II
description: Intermediate-level sequence developing literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari and Nastaliq scripts.
prereq: grade of at least C- in HIND_URD 121-2 or equivalent

subject: HIND_URD
name: Hindi-Urdu III: Topics in Intermediate Hindi-Urdu
description: A series of independent intermediate Hindi-Urdu courses, developing proficiency through readings and discussions. Devanagari and/or Nastaliq script. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in HIND_URD 121-3 or equivalent

subject: HIND_URD
name: Hindi-Urdu IV
description: Standalone course focused on literature and culture. Emphasis on reading, writing about, and discussing literary culture. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
prereq: 3 iterations of HIND_URD 210-0 (minimum grade C-) or equivalent

subject: HIND_URD
name: Independent Study
description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Hindi Urdu.

subject: HISTORY
name: New Introductory Courses in History
description: Introductory lecture courses on topics not covered in regular offerings. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: HISTORY
name: Europe in the Medieval and Early Modern World
description: Culture and structure of preindustrial society, high medieval through mid-18th century.

subject: HISTORY
name: Europe in the Modern World
description: Impact of industrial and political change and development of modern society to the present.

subject: HISTORY
name: Jewish History 750-1492
description: 750-1492: Political, economic, cultural, and intellectual life of Jewish communities under medieval Islam and Christianity. Judeo-Arabic culture and its critics; Jewish-Christian relations; the place of violence; rise and influence of Jewish law and mysticism.

subject: HISTORY
name: Jewish History 1492-1789
description: 1492-1789: Jewish community's economic and cultural reshaping; legalized readmission of Jews to European cities and integration into European society.

subject: HISTORY
name: Jewish History 1789-1948
description: 1789-1948: Plurality of models of integration, acculturation, and assimilation; multiple identities; split of traditional community; sociocultural behavior; political movements.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of the United States, Precolonial to the Civil War
description: Interpretative survey from the 17th century to the present. Pre-colonial to the Civil War.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of the United States, Reconstruction to the Present
description: Interpretative survey from the 17th century to the present. Reconstruction to the present. Lectures, discussion sections.

subject: HISTORY
name: Introduction to African-American History: Key concepts from 1700-1861
description: African origins, the slave trade, origins of slavery and racism in the United States, life under slavery in the North and the South. AF_AM_ST 212-1 and HISTORY 212-1 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: Introduction to African American History: Emancipation to Civil Rights Movement
description: Emancipation to the civil rights era. Reconstruction, rise of legal segregation, strategies of resistance, migration, and urbanization. AF_AM_ST 212-2 and HISTORY 212-2 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: Asian American History
description: Introduction to the history of Asians in the United States, with a focus on their impact on American society as well as their experiences within the United States. ASIAN_AM 214-0 and HISTORY 214-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: Global Asians
description: Survey of Asian diasporas in the United States and elsewhere in the 19th and 20th centuries, emphasizing causes of migration, process of settlement, relations with other ethnic groups, and construction of diasporic identities. ASIAN_AM 216-0 and HISTORY 216-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: Latina and Latino History
description: History of Latina/os in the United States and in the context of US- Latin American relations from the 18th century to the present. HISTORY 218-0 and LATINO 218-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: Global History: Early Modern to Modern Transition
description: The early-modern to modern transition.

subject: HISTORY
name: Global History: The Modern World
description: The modern world. HISTORY 250-1 is not a prerequisite for HISTORY 250-2.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Politics of Disaster: A Global Environmental History
description: A global survey of key natural disasters from the eighteenth century to the present. Focus on the political and human-made dimensions of these supposedly "natural" events.

subject: HISTORY
name: Global History of Refugees
description: Global History of Refugees Development of the international refugee regime in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, including humanitarianism, international law, and activism by and on behalf of refugees.

subject: HISTORY
name: Background to African Civilization and Culture: Origins to 17th C.
description: Historical approach to society, economy, polity, and culture in Africa. Agricultural origins to the 17th century.

subject: HISTORY
name: Background to African Civilization and Culture: 16th-19th C.
description: Historical approach to society, economy, polity, and culture in Africa. 16th through 19th centuries.

subject: HISTORY
name: Background to African Civilization and Culture: 1875-1994
description: Historical approach to society, economy, polity, and culture in Africa. 1875 to 1994.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Latin America in the Colonial Period 1492-1821
description: Aspects of the development of Latin America's socioeconomic, political, cultural, and religious institutions and practices. From the pre-Columbian and Iberian backgrounds through the colonial period, c. 1492-1821.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Latin America in the Modern Period, 1789-present
description: Aspects of the development of Latin America's socioeconomic, political, cultural, and religious institutions and practices. After independence and through the modern period, c. 1821 to the present.

subject: HISTORY
name: Sex after Shakespeare
description: Sexual behavior in England between 1500 and 1800, concentrating on scandalous narratives and public controversy.

subject: HISTORY
name: Pirates, Guns, and Empires
description: Piracy in the Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea, the Indian Ocean, and the China Seas from the late sixteenth to the early nineteenth century.

subject: HISTORY
name: Middle Eastern/Islamic Civilization
description: Influence of Islam on the components of Middle Eastern societies (nomads, agrarian and urban populations) from the inception of the faith (7th century BCE) to the modern period.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of the Islamic Middle East: 600-1200
description: The classical Islamic community; medieval Islamic civilization, 600-1200.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of the Islamic Middle East: 1200-1789
description: Invasions from Central Asia and the empires that followed: Mamluks (Egypt), Ottomans (Turkey), and Safavids (Iran), 1200-1800.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of the Modern Middle East, 1789 - Present
description: Jewish and Arab nationalism, oil diplomacy, Islam in the modern context, 1789-present.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Ancient Egypt, 3100-c. 1000 B.C.E.
description: The Old Kingdom: centralized government, divine kingship. The Middle Kingdom: new monarchic principles in the aftermath of social disorder. The New Kingdom: imperialism in response to foreign aggression; religious revolution of Akhenaton.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Early Modern Science and Medicine
description: The transformations of science and medicine in Europe and beyond during the period known as the 'Scientific Revolution' (c. 1500-1800). Focus on the social dimensions of scientific and medical knowledge, including the relations of science and medicine to religion, politics, commercial markets, and the expansion of Europe's overseas empires during the first age of globalization.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern Science and Medicine
description: The transformation of modern science and medicine in Europe, America and around the world over the past two hundred years; topics include the relations of science and technology from telecom to the A-bomb to biotech; and the relations of science to society, from Darwin to genetics/eugenics to climate change.

subject: HISTORY
name: Chinese Civilization
description: Chinese history to the 16th century, emphasizing cultural and intellectual history.

subject: HISTORY
name: Sino-American Relations in the Modern World
description: This course considers the bilateral Sino-American relationship in its larger global context and in connection to the issues of war, diplomacy, race, gender, religion, and material and popular culture. Focuses on the ways domestic politics shape international relations.

subject: HISTORY
name: Japanese History, Ancient & Medieval, 200-1600
description: Ancient and medieval Japan (200-1600), from the first evidence of civilization on the archipelago through the Warring States Period.

subject: HISTORY
name: Japanese History: Tokugawa Period, 1600-1868
description: Social, cultural, and political developments in the Tokugawa Period (1600-1868).

subject: HISTORY
name: World War II in Asia
description: Analysis of the vast intended and unintended effects of World War II on Asia. Nationalism, global history, decolonization, fascism, Communism, democracy, and the experiences of ordinary people.

subject: HISTORY
name: Introduction to Topics in History
description: Introductory seminar for non-majors and majors interested in a variety of topics related to a historical event, period, or broader historical problem.

subject: HISTORY
name: New Lectures in History
description: Lecture courses on special topics not covered in regular offerings. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: HISTORY
name: New Lectures in History: City and Civilization in the Eastern Mediterannean World
description: Topics in the history of the eastern Mediterranean world. Restricted to students in Northwestern's study aborad programs.

subject: HISTORY
name: New Lectures in History: Milestones of Czech History & Civilization
description: Topics in the history of the Czech Republic. Restricted to students in Northwestern's study abroad programs.

subject: HISTORY
name: American Women's History, to 1865
description: Women and gender in American life, with attention to differences among women based on class, race, and ethnicity. To 1865.

subject: HISTORY
name: American Women's History, since 1865
description: Women and gender in American life, with attention to differences among women based on class, race, and ethnicity. Since 1865.

subject: HISTORY
name: Asian American Women's History
description: Exploration of race, gender, and the contours of US history from the perspective of Asian American women's experiences. Considers migration, exclusion, labor, marriage, family, sexuality, and cross-racial alliances. ASIAN_AM 304-0 and HISTORY 304-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: American Immigration
description: Themes in history of immigration, especially from Europe, Latin America, and Asia. Law, racial formation, acculturation, transnational and international contexts, competing notions of citizenship. HISTORY 305-0 and LEGAL_ST 305-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: The American West
description: Examination of the history of the American West as both frontier and region, real and imagined, from the first contacts between natives and colonizers in the 15th century to the multicultural encounters of the 21st century.

subject: HISTORY
name: American Environmental History
description: American history from precontact to the present, focusing on the role of the natural world in human history and the role of human thought and action in natural history. ENVR_POL 309-0 and HISTORY 309-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: Early American History: Conquest and Colonization, to 1688
description: Conquest and colonization.

subject: HISTORY
name: Early American History: The Age of the American Revolution, 1688-1789
description: The age of the American Revolution.

subject: HISTORY
name: New Nation: The United States, 1787-1848
description: The early years of the new republic from the Constitution to the war with Mexico. Political theory, slavery, social reform, religious revivalism, westward expansion, political parties, the growth of capitalism.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Civil War and Reconstruction
description: "Middle period" of American history, emphasizing origins of the Civil War, its revolutionary nature, and its immediate and long-term consequences for the South and the nation.

subject: HISTORY
name: The United States Since 1900: Early 20th C.
description: America's domestic history and role in world affairs since 1900. Early 20th century.

subject: HISTORY
name: The United States Since 1900: Mid-20th C.
description: America's domestic history and role in world affairs since 1900. Mid-20th century.

subject: HISTORY
name: The United States Since 1900: Late 20th C. to Present
description: America's domestic history and role in world affairs since 1900. Late 20th century to the present.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Sixties
description: Examination of one of the most tumultuous eras in US history, its roots in the reshaping of American society after World War II, and its legacies for the present. Emphasis on social movements of the period, particularly the civil rights movement, and political and cultural change.

subject: HISTORY
name: American Cultural History: 19th C.
description: Changing values of the American people, how they have been transmitted, and how they have shaped American society, politics, and the economy. 19th century.

subject: HISTORY
name: American Cultural History: 20th C. to Present
description: Changing values of the American people, how they have been transmitted, and how they have shaped American society, politics, and the economy. 20th century to the present.

subject: HISTORY
name: Legal and Constitutional History of the United States: Colonial Period to 1850
description: Colonial period-1850. Development of legal institutions, constitutionalism, law and social change, law and economic development. Taught with LEGAL_ST 318-1; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: Legal and Constitutional History of the United States: 1850 to Present
description: 1850-present. Law in industrial society: administration, race relations, corporations, environmental protection, civil liberties. Taught with LEGAL_ST 318-2; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of US Foreign Relations
description: Survey of US relations with the rest of the world from the 18th century to the present, with particular attention to the 20th century.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Fourteenth Amendment
description: The Fourteenth Amendment's role in defining and protecting citizenship, privileges and immunities, due process, and equal protection from its nineteenth-century origins to the present. HISTORY 320-0 and LEGAL_ST 320-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Vietnam Wars
description: Analysis of Vietnam's wars for national independence, with emphasis on US involvement. Topics include international context, political rationales, military engagements, popular attitudes, cultural exchange, and lasting legacies.

subject: HISTORY
name: Development of the Modern American City: to 1880
description: City characteristics of urban society in America from the period of settlement to the present. To 1880.

subject: HISTORY
name: Development of the Modern American City: 1880-Present
description: City characteristics of urban society in America from the period of settlement to the present. 1880-present.

subject: HISTORY
name: US Gay and Lesbian History
description: Gender, sexuality, and the rise of modern lesbian and gay identities. Lecture and discussion. HISTORY 324-0 and GNDR_ST 324-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of American Technology
description: American history through its material culture; industrialization and its discontents; consumer culture and household technology; mass communication and democracy; technological utopia and the computer revolution.

subject: HISTORY
name: U.S. Intellectual History
description: Central questions in America's intellectual past from the colonial era forward; specific dates vary by instructor.

subject: HISTORY
name: Medieval Sex
description: Fluidity of sex and gender roles in an age before "sexual orientation"; impact of and resistance to Christian theology's negative assessment of sexuality; the cult of chastity.

subject: HISTORY
name: Women in Medieval Society
description: Examination of medieval women's lives in both secular and religious spheres through the different ideologies (religious, philosophical, scientific) that shaped them.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Development of Medieval Europe: Early Middle Ages, 300-1000
description: Early Middle Ages, 300-1000.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Development of Medieval Europe: High & Late Middle Ages, 1000-1450
description: High and Late Middle Ages, 1000-1450.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Age of the Renaissance
description: Decline and revival of European civilization, 1350-1530. Cultural, political, economic, and social developments.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Age of the Reformation
description: Europe in the 16th century, especially origins, evolution, and effects of changes in religion.

subject: HISTORY
name: Spain 1500 - 1700: Rise and Fall of a European Empire
description: Social, political, and economic history of the largest early-modern European empire, its multicultural genesis, rise to domination in Europe and the Americas, and struggle to integrate internally.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern Europe
description: Survey of the political and social history of Europe between 1815 and 1945, with emphasis on the political integration and disintegration of the Continent and the causes and effects of social and economic change.

subject: HISTORY
name: Europe in the 20th Century, 1900-1945
description: Growth of mass politics, fascism, the home fronts, rise of the welfare state, loss of empire, economic resurgence and integration. 1900-45.

subject: HISTORY
name: Europe in the 20th Century, 1945-Present
description: Growth of mass politics, fascism, the home fronts, rise of the welfare state, loss of empire, economic resurgence and integration. 1945-present.

subject: HISTORY
name: Gender, War, and Revolution in the 20th Century
description: Examination of changes in gender ideals and in the lives of women and men in Europe and America as a result of world wars, Russian revolution, fascism, and the Cold War.

subject: HISTORY
name: Paris: World City, 1700 to the Present
description: Survey of the social, cultural, political, economic, and spatial development of Paris from aristocratic enclave to a class-divided bourgeois city, from an imperial capital to a postcolonial metropolis.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern France: Ancien Regime and the French Revolution
description: The Ancien Régime and the French revolution.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern France : 19th c. to present
description: 19th century to the present.

subject: HISTORY
name: Modern Italy
description: Italy from the Enlightenment to the present, concentrating on the Risorgimento, the world wars, Mussolini and fascism, the postwar economic miracle, and terrorism.

subject: HISTORY
name: Weimer and Nazi Germany
description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history covering Weimar and Nazi Germany. GERMAN 344-1 and HISTORY 344-1 are taught together: may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: Germany Since 1945
description: Debates about the development of the postwar German states from 1945 to the present. Social, political, economic, and everyday history within the context of East, West, and unified Germany. GERMAN 344-2 and HISTORY 344-2 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Russia: 800-1700
description: Emergence of the Kievan and Muscovite states, 800-1700.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Russia, 1700-1917
description: Russia from Peter to the Revolution, 1700-1917.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Russia, 1917-Present
description: The Soviet Union and its successor states, 1917-present.

subject: HISTORY
name: East Central Europe under Communist Rule and Beyond, 1945 to the Present
description: The history of East-Central Europe from the World War II to the collapse of Soviet rule and beyond.

subject: HISTORY
name: Christians and Jews
description: Varieties of historical encounters between Jews and Christians. Origins of the "Jesus movement"; rabbinic attitudes toward Christianity; medieval polemic and engagement; the modern "Judeo-Christian tradition"; Christian Zionism and postwar ecumenicism.

subject: HISTORY
name: Jews in Poland, Ukraine, and Russia
description: Social, political, religious, and cultural interaction of Jews and Slavs over a millennium, 1250-1917.

subject: HISTORY
name: Jews in Poland, Ukraine, and Russia
description: Jewish encounter with Marxism and communism; social, political, cultural, and artistic aspects of Jewish life; Soviet Jews and the Russian empire: patterns of survival, accommodation, and interaction, 1917-91.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of the Holocaust
description: Origins and development of the massacre of European Jewry during World War II. GERMAN 349-0 and HISTORY 349-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: Global History of Death and Dying
description: How death shapes the modern world via slave trades, imperial conquests, pandemics, wars, medicine, and genocide. Transformations in rituals; personal and social meanings of death; ways and patterns of dying.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of South Africa, Early Times to 1879
description: From the African iron age to the establishment of the multinational gold mining industry, emphasizing the rise of African states and the contest for land with white settlers.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of South Africa, 20th century
description: Emphasis on the 20th century, the rise of African nationalism, and the clash with the apartheid state.

subject: HISTORY
name: East Africa
description: Selected topics in East African history.

subject: HISTORY
name: Topics in West African History
description: Selected topics in West African history: economy, society, and government.

subject: HISTORY
name: Tudor and Stuart Britain
description: Formation of the British state during the Tudor and Stuart dynasties, 1485- 1714, with emphasis on changing patterns of religious belief and the transformation of the monarchy.

subject: HISTORY
name: Modern British History, 1688 - 1815
description: Social, political, and institutional history, 1688-1815.

subject: HISTORY
name: Modern British History, 1780-1900
description: The Victorians: liberalism, empire, and morality, 1780-1900.

subject: HISTORY
name: Modern British History, 1900-present
description: Empire to Cool Britannia, 1900-present.

subject: HISTORY
name: Gender and Sexuality in Victorian Britain
description: Key debates and issues: prostitution, the city and sexual crime, sexuality and empire, sex and the single woman, homosexuality on trial, and the "scientific" writings of Victorian sexologists.

subject: HISTORY
name: Revolutions in Medicine
description: Introduction to the history of medicine in the Americas from precontact to the present, with special focus on Latin America and the Caribbean in imperial, transnational, and global frameworks.

subject: HISTORY
name: Race and Nation in the Independence Era
description: The process of Latin American independence, from the colonial background to 19th century insurgency wars, economic development, and nation formation, with emphasis on race and "the Indian question" in liberal thought.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern Brazil
description: Historical roots of modern Brazilian society: its rush toward economic modernization; radical social and economic inequalities; racially and culturally hybrid national identities; quest for effective democracy and universal citizenship.

subject: HISTORY
name: Revolution in 20th Century Latin America: Mexico and its Revolutions
description: Mexico and its revolutions. Mexican history, from the modernizing regime of Díaz, through the revolutionary upheaval and the consolidation of a new regime, to contemporary problems.

subject: HISTORY
name: Revolution in 20th Century Latin America: Marxist Revolutions
description: Comparative study of the origins and aftermaths of major Marxist revolutions in Cuba and South and Central America.

subject: HISTORY
name: Development and Inequality in Modern Latin America
description: Examination of various models of economic development that have been implemented in 20thcentury Latin America, exploring the cultural, social, political, and economic roots of such policies and their impact on the region's poorest and most marginalized populations.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Ottomans: Last Empire of Islam, 1300-1622
description: The Last Empire of Islam, 1300-1622. Emergence and rise to power; relations with other European and Asian powers; principal institutions; governmental and societal frameworks.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Ottomans: From "Second Empire" to the Age of Nationalism, 1622-1918
description: From the Second Ottoman Empire to the Age of Nationalism, 1622-1918. Political and societal changes that shaped the modern Middle East and southeast Europe.

subject: HISTORY
name: Global Environments and World History
description: Introduction to the recent histories of environmental issues around the world, including urbanization, industrialization, population growth, commodification, empire building, intercontinental welfare, energy extraction, and new technologies. ENVR_POL 340-0 and HISTORY 376-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Law and Science
description: The changing relations between justice and science-including the forensic sciences of identification and intellectual property-in the United States and Europe over the past 300 years.

subject: HISTORY
name: Biomedicine and World History
description: Introduction to the social, political, scientific, and economic forces allowing biomedical systems to become synonymous with global health governance. GBL_HLTH 309-0 and HISTORY 379-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern China: Late Imperial China, 1600-1911
description: Survey of Chinese history from the rise of the last dynasty (the Qing) to the Revolution of 1911 and the inauguration of the Republic of China. Explores the transition from the “traditional” to the “modern” era and considers the transformation of social, economic, cultural, and international relations.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern China: Twentieth-Century China, 1911-2000
description: Survey of Chinese history from the Revolution of 1911 to the era of post-Mao reform. Course explores the political, social, cultural, and international challenges confronting China under the Republic of China (1912-1949) and the early People’s Republic of China after 1949.

subject: HISTORY
name: China in Reform: History of the Present
description: This course examines the complexities of China’s reformist period from the late 1970s until the early 21st century. Topics include the transformation of rural-urban relations, domestic arguments about the unevenness and morality of socio-economic change, the 1989 Spring Democracy Movement, China’s “Peaceful Rise,” the AIDS crisis and SARS, and its growing participation in global affairs.

subject: HISTORY
name: The Modern Japanese City
description: Social and cultural history of urban Japan.

subject: HISTORY
name: Japan's Modern Revolution
description: History of Japan from 1830 to 1912, focusing on the overthrow of the Tokugawa shogunate and emergence as a modern imperialist power.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern Japan: The Modern State, 1860-1943
description: Japan: the modern state, 1860-1943.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern Japan: War and postwar Japan, 1943-present
description: War and postwar Japan, 1943-present.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern South Asia, 1500-1800
description: The early modern period, ca. 1500-1800: The Mughal Empire; the early phase of European trade and conquest in the subcontinent.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern South Asia, ca. 1750-present
description: ca. 1750-present: The age of British colonial dominance; the politics of nation building and anticolonial resistance; independence, partition, and the postcolonial predicament.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Modern Southeast Asia Until 1945
description: A social and economic history of Southeast Asia from c.1750 to 1945.

subject: HISTORY
name: History of Contemporary Southeast Asia Since 1945
description: A social and political history of Southeast Asia from the end of the Second World War to the Present.

subject: HISTORY
name: Approaches to History
description: Introductory seminar for history majors and others interested in understanding how history is thought about and written. Intensive exploration of a significant historical event, period, or topic.

subject: HISTORY
name: Research Seminar
description: Students research and complete a term paper on a topic of choice. Required of majors.

subject: HISTORY
name: Thesis Seminar
description: Advanced work through supervised reading, research, and discussion. Admission by written application, to be reviewed by department. Grade of K given in 398-1 and 398-2.

subject: HISTORY
name: Thesis Seminar
description: Advanced work through supervised reading, research, and discussion. Admission by written application, to be reviewed by department. Grade of K given in 398-1 and 398-2.

subject: HISTORY
name: Thesis Seminar
description: Advanced work through supervised reading, research, and discussion. Admission by written application, to be reviewed by department. Grade of K given in 398-1 and 398-2.

subject: HISTORY
name: Independent Study
description: Reading and conferences on special subjects for advanced undergraduates. Open only with consent of director of undergraduate studies and instructor.

subject: HISTORY
name: Independent Study
description: Reading and conferences on special subjects for advanced undergraduates. Open only with consent of director of undergraduate studies and instructor.

subject: HDC
name: The Counseling Process: Theory & Practice
description: Survey of counseling perspectives and techniques, along with the theories that form the basis of understanding these concepts. Overview of clinical assessment, client systems, counseling theories, and counseling techniques. Review how dynamics and complexity associated with counseling diverse populations and understanding the roles that diversity and personal values play in the counseling process.

subject: HDC
name: Identity and Motivation
description: Examines the connection between conceptions of the self and goal-oriented motivation, with particular attention to the influence of social, structural, and cultural forces.

subject: HDC
name: Emotional Mysteries
description: Classrooms, work settings, and family relations are hotbeds of emotion. But what is an emotion? What happens in our bodies when an emotion is triggered? How can emotions help us live productive, healthy, and connected lives? And can we ever truly understand what somebody else is feeling? These are some of the mysteries that we will seek to unravel in this course. We will read literature from Darwin to the latest scientific studies, combine lectures and small-group discussions, conduct research experiments, and engage in peer review and online collaboration.

subject: HDC
name: Team Dynamics
description: In this course, we will explore team dynamics, those forces that influence a team's behavior and performance, and what can enhance or hinder potential for impact. We will analyze the contributors to team functioning and their interrelationships at multiple levels: intrapersonal, interpersonal, group and organizational. Key topics include team development, team make-up and roles, leadership and followership, decision-making, navigating conflict, collaboration and competition, effective communication, content vs. process, diversity and in-group/out-group tensions. Throughout the class, students will be analyzing and applying concepts through case studies and simulations. Assignments to demonstrate mastery include regular written individual papers and a team project. This course is suitable for undergraduate students in LOC, Human Development in Context, and related majors throughout Northwestern that are interested in leadership, teams/groups or organizational change. Taught with LOC 309-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HDC
name: The Art and Science of Aging
description: For over 2000 years, poets and philosophers have commented on the universal human experience of "getting older." In the past few hundred years, novelists and scientists have joined the effort, along with filmmakers, musicians, counselors, bloggers, motivational speakers, and a host of others. What does it feel like to move through the adult years and toward "old age"? How do people's personalities, social relationships, and overall world view change as they grow older? What does psychological and social science have to say about general trends, as well as individual differences, in aging? This discussion-based and writing-intensive seminar is sequentially organized in terms of five cardinal themes: (1) the social/emotional world, (2) generations, (3) memory and the self, (4) loss, and (5) wisdom of the ages. Within these five themes, the seminar will consider a range of psychological and social issues as they apply to adult development and aging, sampling some of the most provocative sources from fiction, drama, poetry, music, and cinema - and from the scientific literature.

subject: HDC
name: Building Loving and Lasting Relationships: Marriage 101
description: The intricacies and problems of close, committed, interpersonal relationships, especially marriage. Open to first-year students.

subject: HDC
name: Special Topics in Human Development in Context
description: Advanced work on special topics.

subject: HDC
name: Independent Study
description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS.

subject: HUM
name: Introduction to Critical Thinking in the Humanities and Social Sciences
description: For participants in Bridge I summer program. Commonalities and distinguishing features of critical thinking in humanities and social sciences. Emphasis on analysis and argumentation. Taken with MATH 100-BR.

subject: HUM
name: Asking - and Answering - Questions in the Humanities and Social Sciences
description: For participants in Bridge I summer program. How to determine the appropriate scope of a research paper, how to begin research, and related skills in humanities and social sciences.

subject: HUM
name: First-Year Seminar
description: Part of a two-course exploration of the humanities for first-year students selected into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program. This team-taught program—lecture + small coordinated seminar—is designed to challenge students to integrate a variety of intellectual methods to probe the qualitative aspects of human experience. Course topics and instructors change each year. HUM 101-6 is the lecture section (2 days/week) and HUM 210-0 is the paired seminar section (2 days/week).
prereq: This course is reserved for first-year students of the Kaplan Humanities Scholar Program

subject: HUM
name: The Humanities Plunge
description: A half-credit course over spring break immersing students in Chicago's cultural riches. Events and tours are introduced and contextualized by field experts. Enrollment in the Plunge is by application.

subject: HUM
name: The World of Homer
description: Introduction to the history and material culture of Iron Age Greece. Society, economy, art, and archaeology of the Greek world that gave rise to the Homeric epic. CLASSICS 210-0 and HUM 205-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HUM
name: Humanities in the World I
description: Part of a two-course exploration of the humanities for first-year students selected into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program. This team-taught program—lecture + small coordinated seminar—is designed to challenge students to integrate a variety of intellectual methods to probe the qualitative aspects of human experience. Course topics and instructors change each year. HUM 101-6 is the lecture section (2 days/week) and HUM 210-0 is the paired seminar section (2 days/week).
prereq: This course is reserved for first-year students of the Kaplan Humanities Scholar Program

subject: HUM
name: Humanities in the World II
description: Part of a two-course exploration of the humanities for first-year students selected into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program. This team-taught program—lecture + small coordinated seminar—is designed to challenge students to integrate a variety of intellectual methods to probe the qualitative aspects of human experience. Course topics and instructors change each year. HUM 101-6 is the lecture section (2 days/week) and HUM 211-0 is the paired seminar section (2 days/week).
prereq: This course is reserved for first-year students of the Kaplan Humanities Scholar Program

subject: HUM
name: Health, Biomedicine, Culture, and Society
description: Broad introduction to controversies surrounding health and biomedicine by analyzing culture, politics, values, and social institutions. HUM 220-0 and SOCIOL 220-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HUM
name: Media Theory
description: Comprehensive introduction from a humanistic perspective to theories about the nature of media and the role of technology in modern culture. ART_HIST 375-0 and HUM 225-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: HUM
name: Humanities Explorations
description: Lecture course, often team-taught, that explores social, ethical, and political big questions-e.g., the nature of love, the value of reading, relativity in science and culture, ways to model "choice" across the humanities-from different disciplinary perspectives. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: HUM
name: Global Humanities Lab
description: Investigation of an international humanities topic through experiential learning and offsite research; focus on how different cultures process and understand the artifacts of human cultures and their values. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: HUM
name: Global Humanities Lab
description: Investigation of an international humanities topic through experiential learning and offsite research; focus on how different cultures process and understand the artifacts of human cultures and their values. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: HUM
name: Global Humanities Lab
description: Investigation of an international humanities topic through experiential learning and offsite research; focus on how different cultures process and understand the artifacts of human cultures and their values. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: HUM

description: Investigation of an international humanities topic through experiential learning and offsite research; focus on how different cultures process and understand the artifacts of human cultures and their values. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: HUM
name: Humanities in the Digital Age
description: Innovative and collaborative ways to incorporate technology into humanistic study. Ways to digitize text, image, sound, and/ or video for analysis. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: HUM
name: Humanities in the Digital Age
description: Innovative and collaborative ways to incorporate technology into humanistic study. Ways to digitize text, image, sound, and/ or video for analysis. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: HUM
name: Humanities in the Digital Age
description: Innovative and collaborative ways to incorporate technology into humanistic study. Ways to digitize text, image, sound, and/ or video for analysis. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: HUM
name: Humanities in the Digital Age
description: Innovative and collaborative ways to incorporate technology into humanistic study. Ways to digitize text, image, sound, and/ or video for analysis. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: HUM
name: Special Topics in the Humanities
description: Intensive seminars in cutting-edge research on interdisciplinary issues. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

subject: HUM
name: Special Topics in the Humanities
description: Intensive seminars in cutting-edge research on interdisciplinary issues. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

subject: HUM
name: Special Topics in the Humanities
description: Intensive seminars in cutting-edge research on interdisciplinary issues. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

subject: HUM
name: Special Topics in the Humanities
description: Intensive seminars in cutting-edge research on interdisciplinary issues. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

subject: HUM
name: Humanities Seminar
description: Interdisciplinary course offered by a changing roster of humanities faculty. Topics have included cities as modern utopia/dystopia in Europe, Asia, and America; the afterlife of Marxism; the politics of reputation; being animal, being human.

subject: HUM
name: Exhibiting Antiquity: The Culture and Politics of Display
description: Examination of the construction of Mediterranean antiquity through modes of reception since 1750. Analysis of programs of collecting and display and the intersection of institutional and scholarly agendas. ART_HIST 318-0, CLASSICS 397-0 and HUM 397-0 taught together; may receive credit for only 1 of these courses.

subject: HUM
name: Senior Humanities Seminar
description: Two consecutive quarters (fall and winter) during which students work on a senior humanities project under faculty mentorship and within the interdisciplinary community of the Kaplan Humanities Institute.
prereq: selection as a Franke Undergraduate Fellow

subject: HUM
name: Senior Humanities Seminar
description: Two consecutive quarters (fall and winter) during which students work on a senior humanities project under faculty mentorship and within the interdisciplinary community of the Kaplan Humanities Institute.
prereq: selection as a Franke Undergraduate Fellow

subject: HUM
name: Independent Study
description: Individual projects with faculty guidance. Open to junior and senior minors.

subject: IEMS
name: Introduction to Statistics
description: Collecting data; summarizing and displaying data; drawing conclusions from data; probability background, confidence intervals, hypotheses tests, regression, correlation. Not open to industrial engineering degree candidates. May not receive credit for both IEMS 201-0 and any of STAT 210-0, BMD_ENG 220-0, IEMS 303-0, or CHEM_ENG 312-0.

subject: IEMS
name: Probability
description: Introduction to probability theory and its applications. Conditional probabilities and expectation values. Random variables and distributions, including binomial, Poisson, exponential, and normal. Joint distributions and limit laws for foundation of and connection to statistics. Examples in reliability, inventory, finance, and statistics. May not receive credit for both IEMS 202-0 and any of the following: ELEC_ENG 302-0; MATH 310-1, MATH 314-0, MATH 385-0; STAT 320-1, STAT 383-0.

subject: IEMS
name: Principles of Entrepreneurship
description: Introduction to essential elements of building one's own business, from brainstorming ideas and assessing opportunities to pitching a business idea. History of entrepreneurship and the entrepreneurial psyche. Business plan fundamentals, including strategy, finance, accounting, marketing, operations, and choosing the ideal management team. Taught with ENTREP 225-0; may not receive credit for both courses. May not be taken after IEMS 325-0 or ENTREP 325-0.

subject: IEMS
name: Statistics
description: Introduction to the foundations of statistics and statistical computing for data analysis and their applications. Descriptive statistics and statistical inference for estimation, testing, and prediction. May not receive credit for both IEMS 303-0 and any of IEMS 201-0, STAT 210-0, BMD_ENG 220-0, or CHEM_ENG 312-0. May not be taken for credit with or after STAT 320-1.
prereq: IEMS 202-0 or equivalent; COMP_SCI 150-0 or equivalent

subject: IEMS
name: Statistical Learning for Data Analysis
description: Predictive modeling of data using modern regression and classification methods. Multiple linear regression; logistic regression; pitfalls and diagnostics; nonparametric and nonlinear regression and classification such as trees, nearest neighbors, neural networks, and ensemble methods.

subject: IEMS
