name: Quality Improvement by Experimental Design
description: Methods for designing and analyzing industrial experiments. Blocking; randomization; multiple regression; factorial and fractional factorial experiments; response surface methodology; Taguchi's robust design; split plot experimentation. Homework, labs, and project.

subject: IEMS
name: Data Science and Analytics
description: Focuses on select problems in data science, in particular clustering, association rules, web analytics, text mining, and dimensionality reduction. Lectures will be completed with exercises and projects in open source framework R. Prior knowledge of classification techniques and R is required.

subject: IEMS
name: Operations Research
description: Survey of operations research techniques. Linear programming, decision theory, stochastic processes, game theory. May not be taken for credit with or after IEMS 313-0.
prereq: IEMS 201-0 or IEMS 202-0; GEN_ENG 205-1 or MATH 240-0

subject: IEMS
name: Foundations of Optimization
description: Formulation and solution of applicable optimization models, including linear, integer, nonlinear, and network problems. Efficient algorithmic methods and use of computer modeling languages and systems. Homework, exams, and project.
prereq: GEN_ENG 205-1; MATH 228-1; COMP_SCI 110-0 or COMP_SCI 111-0 or COMP_SCI 150-0; sophomore standing

subject: IEMS
name: Stochastic Models
description: Fundamental concepts of probability theory; modeling and analysis of systems having random dynamics, particularly queueing systems.
prereq: IEMS 202-0 and concurrent enrollment in IEMS 303-0; GEN_ENG 205-1

subject: IEMS
name: Discrete Event Systems Simulation
description: Computer simulation of discrete-change systems subject to uncertainty. Choice of input distributions; development of models; design and analysis of simulation experiments. Mini-projects, exams, and computer labs.

subject: IEMS
name: Engineering Entrepreneurship
description: Overview of the entrepreneurial process from an engineering perspective. Idea generation, planning, financing, marketing, protecting, staffing, leading, growing, and harvesting. Business models for startups. Lectures, guest speakers, and case studies. Taught with IEMS 325-0; may not receive credit for both courses.
prereq: 1 course in accounting or finance such as CIV_ENV 205-0 or ENTREP 330-1

subject: IEMS
name: Field Project Methods
description: Use of field research methods to solve management problems. Students define projects, design field studies and pilot tests of data collection instruments, and present results.
prereq: DSGN 106-1 and DSGN 106-2, or consent of instructor for non-McCormick students

subject: IEMS
name: Social Networks Analysis
description: The use of social network analysis to understand the growing connectivity and complexity in the world around us on different scales, ranging from small groups to the World Wide Web. How we create social, economic, and technological networks, and how they enable and constrain attitudes and behaviors.

subject: IEMS
name: Organizational Behavior
description: Manager's view of tools available to recruit, develop, appraise, compensate, organize, and lead a team going through change. Application of psychological principles relating to human dynamics, motivation, teams, power, and organizational culture. Lectures, guest speakers, and exams. Work experience recommended.

subject: IEMS
name: Project Management for Engineers
description: A case study-based exploration of the body of project management knowledge. Key topics include project scheduling, risk management, project leadership, small-group dynamics, project methodologies, lifecycle concepts, and project controls. A Socratic approach is taken to exploring various case studies in the context of established and leading-edge project management concepts.

subject: IEMS
name: Whole-Brain Leadership
description: This course examines whole-brain thinking and leading. Students will draw upon previous work and leadership experience to identify their own thinking and leading preferences and those of team member, and will examine contrasting thinking and leading styles in an effort to appreciate and combine these to produce optimal outcomes. A number of leadership theories and ways of leading will be examined including creative and agile leadership. Analytical thinkers/leaders will be challenged to spend more time with innovation and creativity, while creative thinkers/leaders will be presented with opportunities to engage in analytical problem-solving. Work experience recommended.

subject: IEMS
name: Negotiations and Conflict Resolution for Engineers
description: In this highly interactive class, students participate in negotiation and dispute resolution simulations that range in complexity from single-party/single-issue to multiparty/ multi-issue cases. In addition students explore the role of agents and third parties in the managing conflict. Throughout all of the simulations integrative and distributive strategies are emphasized that can be applied across a variety of contexts.

subject: IEMS
name: Optimization Methods in Data Science
description: Introduction to nonlinear mathematical optimization with applications in data science. The theoretical foundation and the fundamental algorithms for nonlinear optimization are studied and applied to supervised learning models, including nonlinear regression, logistic regression, and deep neural networks. Students write their own implementation of the algorithms in the Python programming language and explore their performance on realistic data sets.
prereq: COMP_SCI 111-0 and IEMS 303-0 and IEMS 313-0, or equivalent

subject: IEMS
name: Analytics for Social Good
description: Challenges and opportunities in using analytics to pursue social good. Application of data-analysis and decision-making tools and frameworks to such case studies as disaster response and community-based healthcare. For juniors and seniors with interests in humanitarian and nonprofit operations.

subject: IEMS
name: Intro to Financial Engineering
description: Financial markets, derivative securities, risk management, mathematical models in finance. Foreign exchange, debt, equity, commodity markets. Investing, trading, hedging, arbitrage. Forwards, futures, options, swaps, exotic derivatives. Models of price dynamics, binomial model, introduction to Black-Scholes theory and Monte Carlo simulation. Homework, projects, and guest speakers.
prereq: CIV_ENV 205-0, IEMS 315-0, MATH 228-2, and COMP_SCI 111-0, or equivalent or consent of instructor

subject: IEMS
name: Supply Chain Modeling and Analysis
description: Application and development of mathematical modeling tools for the analysis of strategic, tactical, and operational supply-chain problems, including facility location, customer assignment, vehicle routing, and inventory management. Related topics including the role of information and decision support systems in supply chains. Homework, exams, and project.

subject: IEMS
name: Operations Engineering and Management
description: Applications of operations research methods in managing and control of operations processes in manufacturing and service systems: including operations strategy; process-flow analysis; forecasting; capacity management; variability analysis; flow time and inventory management; flexible operations; lean operations; and production and workforce scheduling in manufacturing and service systems. Case studies, homework, and exams.

subject: IEMS
name: Service Engineering and Management
description: Exploration of service industries: cost-reduction and service-enhancement models, location planning, workforce scheduling, yield management, queuing analysis, and call-center management.

subject: IEMS
name: Introduction to Health Systems Management
description: Health systems, lean concepts, patient-flow analysis, inference, and data-driven knowledge generation, decisions, and change. Forecasting, operations, and optimization of health resources.

subject: IEMS
name: Industrial Engineering Design Project
description: Case studies and small-scale projects involving application of operations research techniques to complex-decisions problems. Mathematical modeling, optimization, and policy analysis in public-and private-sector systems. Written and oral presentations of analyses.
prereq: IEMS 313-0, IEMS 315-0, concurrent enrollment in IEMS 317-0, and senior standing

subject: IEMS
name: Industrial Engineering Design Project
description: Large-scale, open-ended team projects from selected fields of industrial engineering. Systems approach requiring establishment of objectives and criteria, analysis and synthesis of alternatives, feasibility, trade-offs, testing, and evaluation. Written and oral reports.

subject: IEMS
name: Industrial Engineering Client Project Challenge
description: Open-ended client projects involving application of operations research techniques to complex data analysis and decision problems. Typically taken at the end of junior year or at the start of senior year. Closed to seniors in spring quarter.
prereq: IEMS 202-0, IEMS 303-0, IEMS 304-0, IEMS 313-0, IEMS 315-0, and IEMS 317-0

subject: IEMS
name: Special Topics in Industrial Engineering
description: Topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the department.

subject: IEMS
name: Independent Study in Industrial Engineering
description: Independent study on an industrial engineering topic supervised by a faculty member.

subject: ISEN
name: Introduction to Sustainability: Challenges and Solutions
description: Introduction to using lifecycle systems perspectives in forming evaluations and basic quantitative understandings of the challenges and potential solutions that exist for sustainable societies; framing these in the context of resource use, energy consumption and development, and environmental constraints.

subject: ISEN
name: Introduction to Energy Systems for the 21st Century
description: Overview of energy issues in the context of global sustainability: energy demands for industrial, transportation, housing, and commercial uses, strategies for demand reduction, traditional versus renewable energy systems.

subject: ISEN
name: Climate Change and Sustainability: Ethical Dimensions
description: Interdisciplinary analysis of economic and ethical issues concerning climate change; scientific evidence for anthropogenic global warming; economics and ethics of resource use, conservation practices, and sustainability. ISEN 230-0 taught with PHIL 270-0; students may not earn credit for both courses.

subject: ISEN
name: Energy Technology & Policy in China
description: Examines the energy landscape in China, including an overview of various energy technologies, national policies, practical applications, and future innovations, through lectures and field trips in the US and China. Restricted to students in Northwestern's China program.

subject: ISEN
name: Special Topics in Energy & Sustainability
description: Focused exploration of specific topical themes, trends, and challenges in applied energy and sustainability. Content varies each year; previously offered topics include geographic information systems and the impact of energy systems on the geographic distribution, wellbeing, and social organization of societies. May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

subject: ISEN
name: Special Topics in Energy & Sustainability
description: Focused exploration of specific topical themes, trends, and challenges in applied energy and sustainability. Content varies each year; previously offered topics include geographic information systems and the impact of energy systems on the geographic distribution, wellbeing, and social organization of societies. May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

subject: ISEN
name: Independent Study
description: Independent study under direction of faculty member. Consent of department required.

subject: IMC
name: Introduction to Integrated Marketing Communications
description: Basic introduction to the strategic marketing communications process, including consumer insight and research, market segmentation, brand positioning, communications messages, and media decisions. Overview of tactical areas, such as branding, advertising, digital media, and corporate communications. Course is for non-IMC certificate students only and does not count toward the certificate.

subject: IMC
name: Consumer Insight
description: Psychological, economic, communication, anthropological, and sociological perspectives on why and how individuals, families, and groups acquire, consume, and dispose of goods, services, ideas, brands, and experiences. Goals and experiences as means to understanding people as consumers.

subject: IMC
name: Research for Marketing Communications
description: Analytic methods and metrics, including web analytics and social media metrics, to develop, execute, and evaluate marketing communications. Designing questionnaires and analyzing survey results and databases to evaluate consumer behavior. Students develop hands-on analytic skills with Qualtrics survey and SPSS statistics software.

subject: IMC
name: Integrated Marketing Communications Strategy
description: Consumer insight and research, market segmentation, brand positioning, communication messages, and media decisions. Brand communications integrated with other aspects of marketing, including product strategy, pricing, and retailing. Case studies and writing-intensive assignments.

subject: IMC
name: Media and Message Delivery
description: The contemporary media landscape and how brand communications adapt to media technology and usage. Current case studies are used to understand the transition from passive consumption of traditional media to active participation in digital and social media. Engaging and communicating effectively with consumers through media.

subject: IMC
name: Message Strategy and Persuasive Communications
description: Development of message strategies for communicating with audiences. Understanding audiences, persuasion, development and execution of brand communications. Hands-on exercises in writing creative briefs and using digital and social media.

subject: IMC
name: Strategic Communications
description: Development and execution of communications strategies and relationship building with employees, the news media, government, investors, and the public. Outlets include traditional print and broadcast media and contemporary channels including blogs, social media platforms, and emerging technologies. Exercises in written communications.
prereq: Non-Medill students, IMC 303-0; Medill students, JOUR 301-0

subject: IMC
name: Digital, Social and Mobile Marketing
description: Focus on the tools, methodologies, and programs used by companies to develop, justify, deploy, and measure their social and mobile marketing programs. Development of complete social marketing programs for actual companies using best-of-breed social monitoring, web analysis, social marketing systems, blogs, Twitter, Google Plus, LinkedIn, and other tools.

subject: IMC
name: Marketing Models
description: Quantitative models for marketing and communications. Multivariate statistical methods, such as factor and cluster analysis, and marketing models, including regression, discrete choice models, and time-series analysis. Hands-on experience in handling data types, using SPSS to conduct analysis, interpreting results, and providing recommendations.

subject: IMC
name: Integrated Marketing and Communication Law, Policy and Ethics
description: Legal and ethical issues and the policy side of communications, media, and marketing. Media law, First Amendment protection of commercial speech, contracts, intellectual property, privacy, and ethics.
prereq: Non-Medill students, IMC 303-0; Medill students, JOUR 301-0

subject: IMC
name: Data Governance: Critical Issues in Digital Marketing Communications
description: Data Governance will address the rapid move of companies toward digital marketing and communications efforts, and the world of connected devices known as the Internet of Things. With the emphasis on data privacy and security, the class will explore critical legal and technology issues that create liability for marketing professionals and their companies.
prereq: Medill students JOUR 301-0; non-Medill IMC Certificate students IMC 303-0

subject: IMC
name: IMC Capstone Project
description: Students work with sponsoring organizations to develop comprehensive marketing communications programs in real-world settings. The final product is a report outlining the learning and insight behind strategic, creative, and marketing recommendations; a client presentation; and a project book detailing research, analysis, strategy, creative execution, media use, and other integrated communications activities.

subject: IMC
name: Special Topics
description: Specialized courses include Finance for Integrated Marketing Communications -Finance for IMC will focus on the familiarity and use of financial tools important to marketing executives in budget development and spending allocation; Technology and Innovation for Media-This course addresses the profound impact that evolving media strategies have on news, marketing communications and audience experiences.
prereq: Medill students JOUR 301-0; non-Medill IMC Certificate students IMC 303-0

subject: IMC
name: Integrated Marketing Communications Strategy
description: Consumer insight and research, market segmentation, brand positioning, communication messages, and media decisions. Brand communications integrated with other aspects of marketing, including product strategy, pricing, and retailing. Case studies and writing-intensive assignments.

subject: IMC
name: Practicum: Great Lakes Challenge
description: The Great Lakes Challenge provides the opportunity for the class to complete an actual project for the company in competition with a student team from Michigan State University. Each winter quarter, the instructors and client will develop and assign a new project that both student teams will complete and present. This total IMC project will build upon your learning from the three core courses.

subject: IMC
name: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite: IMC 303-0.

subject: INTG_SCI
name: Undergraduate Research
description: Advanced independent study and research for superior students. Consent of ISP director required.

subject: INTL_ST
name: Topics in International Studies
description: Topics vary. Augments offerings of departments.

subject: INTL_ST
name: Special Topics in International Studies
description: Topics vary. Augments offerings of departments.

subject: INTL_ST
name: Special Topics in International Studies
description: Topics vary. Augments offerings of departments.

subject: INTL_ST
name: Development in the Global Context: Participation, Power, and Social Change
description: Central debates and issues of international development. Global poverty, development goals, alternative approaches, participation, scale, sustainability, power, evaluation, and social change. Restricted to students in the Global Engagement Studies Institute program.

subject: INTL_ST
name: Development in the Global Context: Participation, Power, and Social Change
description: Central debates and issues of international development. Global poverty, development goals, alternative approaches, participation, scale, sustainability, power, evaluation, and social change. Restricted to students in the Global Engagement Studies Institute program.

subject: INTL_ST
name: Integrating Project Seminar
description: Small research seminars allow international studies majors to conduct research in their chosen themes.

subject: INTL_ST
name: Honors Seminar
description: Two consecutive quarters (fall and winter) during which students work on their senior theses. Admission by written application to the program director.

subject: INTL_ST
name: Honors Seminar
description: Two consecutive quarters (fall and winter) during which students work on their senior theses. Admission by written application to the program director.

subject: INTL_ST
name: Independent Research
description: Advanced research is carried out under the supervision of a Northwestern professor. Independent study may count toward completion of either a regional or a thematic cluster. Consent of the director of the undergraduate's major is required following submission of a written proposal.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Elementary Italian
description: Emphasis on oral communication, supported by grammar, writing, reading, and listening. Four class meetings a week.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Elementary Italian
description: Emphasis on oral communication, supported by grammar, writing, reading, and listening. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in ITALIAN 101-1 or Department placement

subject: ITALIAN
name: Elementary Italian
description: Emphasis on oral communication, supported by grammar, writing, reading, and listening. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in ITALIAN 101-2 or Department placement

subject: ITALIAN
name: Intermediate Italian
description: Grammar review, conversation, composition, and readings in modern prose and drama. Four class meetings a week.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Intermediate Italian
description: Grammar review, conversation, composition, and readings in modern prose and drama. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least a C- in ITALIAN 102-1 or Department placement

subject: ITALIAN
name: Intermediate Italian
description: Grammar review, conversation, composition, and readings in modern prose and drama. Four class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in ITALIAN 102-2 or Department placement

subject: ITALIAN
name: Italian for Musicians
description: Italian language course for musicians, focusing on developing comprehension and pronunciation skills for operatic performance. Analysis of libretti and scores of Italian operas.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in ITALIAN 101-2 or Department placement

subject: ITALIAN
name: Italian in the Business World
description: Italian language course with an emphasis on communication and a cultural focus on business and its practices.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Intensive Italian
description: Intensive double course covers two years of Italian language, the equivalent of Italian 101 and Italian 102, in a single academic year. Students enroll concurrently in ITALIAN 133-1 and ITALIAN 134-1 and receive 2 credits a quarter. Four two-hour class meetings a week.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Intensive Italian
description: Intensive double course covers two years of Italian language, the equivalent of Italian 101 and Italian 102, in a single academic year. Students enroll concurrently in ITALIAN 133-2 and ITALIAN 134-2 and receive 2 credits a quarter. Four two-hour class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in ITALIAN 133-1 and ITALIAN 134-1 or Department placement

subject: ITALIAN
name: Intensive Italian
description: Intensive double course covers two years of Italian language, the equivalent of Italian 101 and Italian 102, in a single academic year. Students enroll concurrently in ITALIAN 133-3 and ITALIAN 134-3 and receive 2 credits a quarter. Four two-hour class meetings a week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in ITALIAN 133-2 and ITALIAN 134-2 or Department placement

subject: ITALIAN
name: Intensive Italian
description: Intensive double course covers two years of Italian language, the equivalent of Italian 101 and Italian 102, in a single academic year. Students enroll concurrently in ITALIAN 133-1 and ITALIAN 134-1 and receive 2 credits per quarter. Four two-hour class meetings per week.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Intensive Italian
description: Intensive double course covers two years of Italian language, the equivalent of Italian 101 and Italian 102, in a single academic year. Students enroll concurrently in ITALIAN 133-2 and ITALIAN 134-2 and receive 2 credits per quarter. Four two-hour class meetings per week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in ITALIAN 133-1 and ITALIAN 134-1 or Department placement

subject: ITALIAN
name: Intensive Italian
description: Intensive double course covers two years of Italian language, the equivalent of Italian 101 and Italian 102, in a single academic year. Students enroll concurrently in ITALIAN 133-3 and ITALIAN 134-3 and receive 2 credits per quarter. Four two-hour class meetings per week.
prereq: Grade of at least C- in ITALIAN 133-2 and ITALIAN 134-2 or Department placement

subject: ITALIAN
name: Italian Through Media
description: Issues from Italian media; frequent oral and written reports: for instance, America in Italian media, advertising, immigration, youth culture. Students produce a newspaper or newscast at the end of the quarter.
prereq: ITALIAN 102-3 or ITALIAN 133-3 / ITALIAN 134-3 or equivalent

subject: ITALIAN
name: Italian Through Performance
description: Students develop and perform original material on video or live. Content may derive from television, theater, opera, and commedia dell'arte.
prereq: ITALIAN 102-3 or ITALIAN 133-3 / ITALIAN 134-3 or equivalent

subject: ITALIAN
name: Creative Writing in Italian
description: A course meant to improve written Italian through exercises and experiments in a variety of genres and styles.
prereq: ITALIAN 102-3 or ITALIAN 133-3 / ITALIAN 134-3 or equivalent

subject: ITALIAN
name: Introduction to Italian Literature
description: Introduction to the history, genres, and themes of Italian literature. Course content may vary, focusing on reading, comprehension, and interpretive skills. May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Voyage to Italy
description: An approach to Italian culture and civilization through exploration of representative Italian cities.
prereq: ITALIAN 102-3 or ITALIAN 133-3 / ITALIAN 134-3 or equivalent proficiency

subject: ITALIAN
name: Business Italian
description: Introduction to the business and economic environment in Italy. Study of business practice and development of linguistic skills necessary for professional communication.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Conversation in Italian
description: Introduction to Italian culture. Emphasizes group activities and focuses on listening comprehension and speaking skills.
prereq: ITALIAN 102-3 or ITALIAN 133-3 / ITALIAN 134-3 or equivalent proficiency

subject: ITALIAN
name: Italian Theatre and Performance
description: Introduction to drama and performance in Italy.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Topics in Italian Culture and Literature
description: Cross-disciplinary exploration of a defined topic in Italian studies as it interacts with other cultural and literary traditions-for example, aspects of love. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Introduction to Italian Cinema
description: Focus on filmmakers fundamental to the development of modern cinema (including Rossellini, Fellini, and Antonioni) from 1942 to the present. Emphasis on formal analysis and film criticism.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Body and Soul from Rome to the Renaissance
description: Comprehension of the human body and soul in Italy from Augustan Rome to the Renaissance, as seen in literary and religious authors. Readings include Ovid, St. Paul, Gnostics, St. Francis, "dolce stil novo," Boccaccio.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Michelangelo and the Italian Renaissance
description: Close examination of Michelangelo's life and work in the broader context of Italian Renaissance culture.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Dante's Divine Comedy
description: Introduction to the Divine Comedy, its artistic and intellectual achievement, and its cultural and historical context.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Global Neorealism
description: Exploration of Italian neorealism and its influence on European (especially the French New Wave), New Latin American, West African, and Indian cinema.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Politics and Mass Culture
description: Culture of Italy from World War II to the present. Novels, films, popular culture.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Migrations
description: Italian literary practice in contact with groups that Italy has defined as other-either beyond or within its geographical boundaries.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Reading Italian Literature (in Italian)
description: Introduction to principal genres of Italian literature in historical and cultural context from the Middle Ages to the present. Authors include Dante, Boccaccio, Goldoni, Leopardi, Verga, Pirandello, Levi, and Montale.
prereq: One 200-level course in Italian or equivalent proficiency

subject: ITALIAN
name: Italy in Art and Literature
description: Interdisciplinary course on Italian culture from the Middle Ages to the present. Each week pairs an artist with an author-for instance, Giotto/Dante, Michelangelo/Vittoria Colonna, Caravaggio/Galilei, De Chirico/Pirandello, Fellini/Flaiano.

subject: ITALIAN
name: The Italian Novella
description: Exploration of Italian culture through the form of the novella from the Middle Ages to the present. Each week is devoted to a groundbreaking author, such as Boccaccio, Sacchetti, Basile, Pirandello, Flaiano, and Calvino.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Topics in Italian Culture and Literature
description: Advanced exploration of special topics in Italian studies.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Advanced Topics in Italian Culture and Literature
description: Advanced exploration of special topics in Italian studies determined by the research interests of a visiting scholar. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Italian Film and Transnational Cinema
description: In-depth exploration of key Italian filmmakers in the context of transnational cinema. Focus on relation between filmmakers (including Visconti/Renoir, Rossellini/Godard, and Antonioni/Wenders) and dynamics of cinematic style and cultural influence.

subject: ITALIAN
name: From the Avant-Garde to the Post-Modern
description: Major authors and movements animating the modern and contemporary literary scene. Content varies-for example, futurism, feminist Italian fiction, and intellectuals and politics from D'Annunzio to Pasolini, Calvino, Eco, and the postmodern.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Major Figures in Italian History and Culture
description: Investigation of the strategic roles played by Italian artists (da Vinci), scientists (Galileo), and political philosophers (Machiavelli, Vico) in forming the canon of modern thought.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Love and Sexuality in the Early Modern Period
description: Analysis of how love and sexuality work as generalized symbolic media of communication in early modern Italian society and culture.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Gender and Sexuality in Italian Culture
description: Interdisciplinary course on gender and visual practices in Italy (photography, film, television, and video).

subject: ITALIAN
name: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Advanced analysis and research of a topic in Italian culture. History of culture, literature, philosophy, the visual arts, film studies and theory of the image, gender and sexuality in contemporary Italy.

subject: ITALIAN
name: Independent Study
description: Supervised independent reading. Consult the director of undergraduate studies.

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese I
description: First-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Japanese. This course introduces the Hiragana and Katakana syllabaries and Kanji (Chinese characters).

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese I
description: Second-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Japanese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 111-1 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese I
description: Third-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Japanese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 111-2 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese II
description: First-quarter course of the college-level second-year Japanese to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 111-3 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese II
description: Second-quarter course of the college-level second-year Japanese to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 121-1 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese II
description: Third-quarter course of the college-level second-year Japanese to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 121-2 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese III
description: First-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency. Focus on social and cultural issues and language for discussing them.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 121-3 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese III
description: Second-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency. Focus on social and cultural issues and language for discussing them.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 211-1 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese III
description: Third-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency. Focus on social and cultural issues and language for discussing them.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 211-2 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese IV: Special Topics in Reading Japanese Literature in Japanese
description: Reading of original texts of Japanese literature, criticism, and nonfiction focused on particular themes. Translation skills are emphasized; discussion in English.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 211-3 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese IV: Reading Modern Japanese Literature in Japanese
description: Focus on learning pre-1946 orthography and reading of original texts of modern short stories. Translation skills are emphasized; discussion in English.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 211-3 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese IV: Contemporary Japanese Literary Works for Reading & Discussion
description: Focus on reading contemporary Japanese poems, essays, short stories, and novels; discussion in Japanese.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 211-3 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese IV: Japanese Newspaper Reading and News Listening
description: Focus on reading Japanese newspaper articles and debating in Japanese the issues discussed. Develops news listening skills.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 211-3 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Japanese IV: Japanese Essay Writing
description: Focus on refining writing skills-narrative, descriptive, persuasive, and argumentative. Review of grammar and expressions through writing clinics.
prereq: grade of at least C- in JAPANESE 211-3 or equivalent

subject: JAPANESE
name: Independent Study
description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Japanese.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz History I
description: The origins of jazz, its performers, and their contributions. Includes a look at contemporaneous social conditions during its development.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz History II
description: The origins of jazz, its performers, and their contributions. Includes a look at contemporaneous social conditions during its development.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Improvisation I
description: The language of jazz. Focus is on melodic development and ear training via repertoire and solos of jazz's most influential figures.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Improvisation II
description: The language of jazz. Focus is on melodic development and ear training via repertoire and solos of jazz's most influential figures.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Improvisation III
description: The language of jazz. Focus is on melodic development and ear training via repertoire and solos of jazz's most influential figures.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Composition and Arranging I
description: The techniques of composing and arranging for large and small ensembles in the jazz tradition. Study of scores by major composers and arrangers from throughout jazz history.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Composition and Arranging II
description: The techniques of composing and arranging for large and small ensembles in the jazz tradition. Study of scores by major composers and arrangers from throughout jazz history.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Selected Topics
description: Topics vary. May be repeated for credit as topics change.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Improvisation IV
description: Continuation of JAZZ_ST 236-3.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Improvisation V
description: Continuation of JAZZ_ST 336-1.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Improvisation VI
description: Continuation of JAZZ_ST 336-2.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Business of Jazz
description: A survey of the music industry as it pertains to jazz. Includes discussions on songwriting, music publishing, national and international copyright law, music licensing, artist management, music production, and related topics.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Keyboard I
description: Basic keyboard skills, with an emphasis on jazz voicing, harmonization, and analysis.

subject: JAZZ_ST
name: Jazz Keyboard II
description: Basic keyboard skills, with an emphasis on jazz voicing, harmonization, and analysis.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Jewish Studies: An Overview
description: Introduction to the field of Jewish studies. Methodologies used to research and analyze Jewish culture, history, and religion.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Imagining Modern Jewish Culture in Yiddish and German
description: History and character of Yiddish and the development of modern German culture in general and German-Jewish culture in particular. Appreciation of the variety of "Judaisms" imagined and reimagined during modern European history. GERMAN 242-0 and JWSH_ST 242-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Introduction to Yiddish Culture: Images of the Shtetl
description: Analysis and discussion of the literary, visual, and filmic images of the communal life developed by Eastern European Jews and inseparably associated with them. GERMAN 266-0, JWSH_ST 266-0 and YIDDISH 266-0 taught together; students may receive credit for only one of these.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Modern Hebrew Literature in Translation
description: History of Hebrew literature.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Modern Jewish Literature
description: Modern European, American, and Israeli Jewish literature in historical context.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Topics in Israel Studies
description: Topics in Israel Studies: History, culture and society of the modern State of Israel. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Topics taught under this course number may be applied towards Weinberg College distribution requirement Area IV.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Topics in Israel Studies
description: Topics in Israel Studies History, culture and society of the modern State of Israel. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Topics taught under this course number may be applied towards Weinberg College distribution requirement Area V.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Topics in Israel Studies
description: Topics in Israel Studies: History, culture and society of the modern State of Israel. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Topics taught under this course number may be applied towards Weinberg College distribution requirement Area VI.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Topics in Israel Studies
description: Topics in Israel Studies: History, culture and society of the modern State of Israel. Content varies. Course number indicates distribution area towards which course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Representing the Holocaust in Literature and Film
description: Analysis of artistic, ethical, and historical questions about representing the Holocaust in different genres.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Yiddish Culture and the Holocaust
description: Analysis of modern Yiddish literature before the Holocaust as well as literary work that emerged from Yiddish-speaking writers who survived the Second World War. GERMAN 366-0, JWSH_ST 366-0 and YIDDISH 366-0 taught together; may receive credit for only one course.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Storytelling in American Jewish Literature
description: Modern Jewish writers from diverse national and linguistic backgrounds who have reshaped the oral tradition in Judaism to their individual talents.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Topics in Jewish Studies
description: Addresses topics not covered by other course offerings. Content varies.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Topics in Modern Jewish Culture
description: Analysis of major texts and figures in 20th and 21st century Jewish literature, with attention to their cultural context and import.

subject: JWSH_ST
name: Independent Study
description: For majors selected as candidates for departmental honors. Consent of department is required to enroll.

subject: JOUR
name: Bridge Program
description: This course will introduce you to the fundamentals of reporting and writing while simultaneously considering the role of news reporting in the midst of COVID-19 and civil unrest across the U.S and beyond.

subject: JOUR
name: Reporting & Writing
description: This course emphasizes the critical practices of ethical journalism, deadline reporting and writing and builds a strong foundation for all Medill classes. It introduces students to the essentials of accurate journalism regardless of platform or storytelling format.

subject: JOUR
name: Multimedia Storytelling
description: This course continues on the strong foundation created in JOUR 201-1 and significantly expands the base of multi-platform tools needed for effective, relevant and engaging storytelling for specific audiences. Instructors will guide students in the continued development of reporting, interviewing, writing and researching with a more sophisticated audience understanding.

subject: JOUR
name: Philosophy of Modern Journalism
description: This course focuses on the evolving relationship between today’s news media landscape and its consumers. Students learn fundamental theories of human behavior and media consumption in order to understand new technologies, content opportunities, and relationship-building with journalism audiences.

subject: JOUR
name: Building a Visual Brand (Non-Majors)
description: This course explores the fundamental tools of design, typographic contrast and color theory. Design is approached through writing and editing as a single process in which the written and visual aspects of journalism are given equal attention. This course is divided into lectures, research, sketching, computer lab time, and critiques.

subject: JOUR
name: Intro to Podcasting
description: This course will focus on helping students become engaged interviewers, critical listeners, and adept storytellers. Each student will produce several audio pieces for this class. Students will give and receive feedback to each other and work in teams. The course involves significant reporting outside of class.

subject: JOUR
name: Sports Marketing for Non-Majors
description: Students will develop an understanding of marketing through the lens of sports and will consider the spectrum of sports marketing, from brands that use sports to capture the attention of customers to teams who want fans to buy season tickets. No journalism or marketing experience required.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism in Practice
description: Practice of reporting, editing, and storytelling skills through topical writing and research assignments. Learning to develop diverse sources and incorporate audio, visual, and multimedia elements for news, magazine, and other audiences. Readings, discussion, and experiential opportunities.
prereq: JOUR 201-1, JOUR 201-2 and Medill sophomore standing

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism in Practice
description: Prerequisites: JOUR 201-1, JOUR 201-2 and Medill sophomore standing.

subject: JOUR
name: Media History
description: This course will explore how media history has influenced the world we live in today. Students will examine who has had the power and ability to tell the stories that shape people’s lives, who has consumed those stories, who has been affected by the stories and whose stories have been neglected or distorted.

subject: JOUR
name: Framed: Media and the Marginalized
description: Through discussion of principles of media professionalism and ethics, and an examination of some of the hot topics featured in today’s headlines, this course will set a framework for recognizing and analyzing media narrative framing, as well as the representation of traditionally marginalized groups within that narrative frame. Ultimately, we will develop a deeper appreciation of media responsibility.

subject: JOUR
name: Media Presentation: Newspaper/Online
description: This course teaches the essentials of editing content for newspaper and for the Web. Students will learn how to edit for grammar and Associated Press style; achieve accuracy, clarity and objectivity; think critically and exercise news judgment; write headlines and captions for print and online; edit photos and graphics; and design pages for newspapers.

subject: JOUR
name: Media Presentation: Magazine Editing
description: This course will help students develop the fundamental editing skills required of an entry-level magazine editor working on print, digital and mobile platforms. Students will gain insight into the magazine business and hone the analytic discipline useful for a variety of career paths within media or without.

subject: JOUR
name: Media Presentation: Video Producing for Broadcast & the Web
description: Writing and producing broadcasts for television, the web, and alternative digital platforms, using the appropriate computer and editing equipment, news wires, and video feeds. Emphasis on the editorial decision-making process.

subject: JOUR
name: Entrepreneurial Approaches to Media Innovation
description: In this course, students will study the pros and cons of locating an innovative new business in the Chicago area; examine products and services that are being built and tested here today; analyze the choices that are being made by media companies, tech entrepreneurs, and investors; and observe how the general public learns about these businesses. By application.

subject: JOUR
name: Storytelling: Interactive News
description: This course explores how newsrooms are using technology in innovative ways to engage their audiences and examines how a digital news presentation evolves across multimedia platforms. This course builds on the foundations of audio, photo, and video storytelling and adds interactivity and engagement techniques enabling students to design dynamic, creative, digital narratives for news and feature reporting.

subject: JOUR
name: Storytelling: Magazine & Feature Writing
description: This course introduces students to feature and magazine storytelling. Students will read and deconstruct an array of non-fiction stories and will report, write, re-write and edit short pieces and one long-form story. The course aims to inspire students to deliver memorable works of narrative, explanatory and service journalism, with particular emphasis on expanding reporting methods and sharpening prose.

subject: JOUR
name: Storytelling: Video Reporting, Shooting, & Editing
description: This class is designed to teach video storytelling in preparation for journalism residency placement and beyond. The course will emphasize a variety of research, writing and field reporting techniques that will prepare students for the challenges of freelance and a professional workplace where video is emphasized.

subject: JOUR
name: Reporting & Producing Social Media Video
description: This class is about the things in your social media timelines that move and make noise—the news clips, explainers and engaging video stories that populate the various social media platforms. But it’s also about the trends, algorithms and business models behind those posts.

subject: JOUR
name: Coverage of Gender and Sexual Minorities
description: Examination of social science research on LGBT communities and translating it for specialized and general audiences. Topics include research aims and limitations; reporting on underrepresented groups; finding fresh angles and credible sources; contextualizing stories of local, national, and international reach.

subject: JOUR
name: Bilingual Reporting
description: This is a bilingual course that explores the history, current state and future of the English, Spanish and bilingual audiences and the media outlets that seek to reach them. Students will get to know Chicago’s vibrant and diverse LatinX communities and practice research and interviewing, reflection and story production in Spanish and in English. Spanish proficiency required.

subject: JOUR
name: Knight Lab
description: Each quarter, multidisciplinary teams of students, faculty, and professionals come together to collaborate in the Knight Lab Studio to produce cutting-edge digital work, research, and thought, innovating across every part of the media-making process. By application only.

subject: JOUR
name: The Googlization of American Media
description: In this course students use recent books, news stories, and other reportage to understand how major tech enterprises are changing journalism, the media business, and democracy itself. Readings, research and writing assignments, group exercises in and outside class, and guest speakers.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism Residency: Argentina
description: By application only.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism Residency: Argentina
description: By application only.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism Residency
description: By application only.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism Residency
description: By application only.

subject: JOUR
name: National Security
description: Relationship between the media and the military, especially since 9/11, and impact on public opinion. Topics include field reporting, ethics of reporting classified material, and issues facing the military.

subject: JOUR
name: Politics, Media and The Republic
description: This seminar will explore such themes as polarization, political image-making and advertising, voting rights and voter suppression, as well as campaign rhetoric and policy issues.

subject: JOUR
name: Dilemmas of American Power
description: This course uses an engaging set of case studies and materials to chart one of the most intriguing stretches of international engagement in U.S. history. Students will work collaboratively to understand why decisions were made, how policies were implemented and sold, and what it all may mean in the end.

subject: JOUR
name: Sports and Society
description: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism Residency: Qatar
description: By application only.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism Residency: Qatar
description: By application only.

subject: JOUR
name: Sports Commentary
description: Students will develop a distinctive voice that stands out from the cacophony of opinions in the sporting world, to create commentary that is informative, thought-provoking and entertaining and to adapt those messages for delivery across multiple media platforms. Students will learn to coalesce their observations, opinions and experiences into compelling arguments.

subject: JOUR
name: Evolution of Sports Media
description: From the foundational elements in the days of typewriters and telegraphs that are still in use today to the technological innovations that will shape the way we watch sports in the future, Sports Media History examines the evolution of this multibillion-dollar field.

subject: JOUR
name: Media History and the Native American Experience
description: In this media history class, we will generate multimedia content for an “Indigenous Tour of Northwestern.” Students will research Native American people, places, policies, and historic social movements that intersect with locations on the Northwestern campus.

subject: JOUR
name: Sports Reporting
description: This course is a dive into the world of sports journalism and how sports reporters do their jobs on a daily basis, utilizing all the fundamentals of good journalism while recognizing that it is also a unique endeavor.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism Residency: South Africa
description: By application only.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism Residency: South Africa
description: By application only.

subject: JOUR
name: Native American Environmental Issues and the Media
description: This course introduces students to indigenous issues, such as treaty-based hunting, fishing, and gathering rights; air and water quality issues; mining; land-to-trust issues; and sacred sites. We will focus on how the media cover these issues and how that coverage contributes to the formation of public opinion and public policy.

subject: JOUR
name: Documentary
description: This course will provide students with a comprehensive overview of HD video production specifically geared towards producing short documentaries that tell human stories. Emphasis is put on the use of character, conflict, drama and surprise in telling these documentary stories. We will also look at different documentary styles and how narrative structures like story arcs are implemented.

subject: JOUR
name: Audio Documentary
description: This course explores different forms of audio documentary production for radio broadcast, as well as web-based multi-media distribution. Emphasis is on radio reporting techniques including interviewing, writing to tape, compelling story-telling, as well as integration of sound and music.

subject: JOUR
name: Media Law & Ethics
description: This course will review the myriad laws, legal cases and ethical standards essential to being a journalist in the 21st Century -- not only for what you report and publish, but also for what you post on social media -- including defamation, privacy, information access, protecting sources, and copyright.

subject: JOUR
name: Journalism of Empathy
description: Exploration of writing and reporting about people and places neglected and misunderstood by mainstream America.

subject: JOUR
name: International Journalism: South Africa
description: This course covers the contemporary history of South Africa with a special focus on the role of media in one of the world’s newest constitutional democracies. Speaking directly with journalists, publishers, executive producers and media executives we’ll explore the state of independent journalism. Required for South Africa Journalism Residency.

subject: JOUR
name: Medill Investigative Lab
description: In this dynamic course grounded in real-time investigative reporting, students will expose a problem of significant national importance and chronicle its effects on the lives and livelihoods of hundreds of millions of people across the country.
prereq: Medill junior standing and instructor consent

subject: JOUR
name: Intro to Investigative Journalism
description: In this course, we’ll focus on the basics of investigative reporting that you can apply to any reporting course, as well as prepare for advanced investigative courses if you so choose. We’ll explore the history, ethics, challenges and successes of investigative reporting and learn the tools used by top investigative reporters.

subject: JOUR
name: Media Design
description: In this course students will be introduced to creating and developing a visual response to communication problems, including understanding of hierarchy, typography, aesthetics, composition and the construction of meaningful images.
prereq: Medill sophomore standing and JOUR 301-0 or JOUR 301-1

subject: JOUR
name: Data Analysis and Visualization
description: In this course, students will learn techniques and theory for analyzing, visualizing, and communicating structured data for journalism contexts. Students will be exposed to ideas and techniques from diverse fields like cognitive science, statistics, and perceptual psychology, and learn how to take an empirical approach to the design and evaluation of data representations like visualizations.

subject: JOUR
name: Introduction to Photojournalism
description: This class will provide students with an introduction to digital photography with an emphasis on photojournalism. Emphasis will be put on using images to portray human stories – ones that surprise, break stereotypes, and capture emotion in dramatic and intimate situations. This class will also focus on basic picture editing and how proper picture selection enhances the total journalistic package.

subject: JOUR
name: Business Reporting
description: In this course, students will learn how to write compelling, informative articles on personal finance, small business, entrepreneurship, Fortune 500 companies, and the economy.

subject: JOUR
name: Health and Science Reporting
description: In this combination writing workshop and seminar, students will read some of the best science and health journalism; meet with expert scientists on campus; and meet the editors and writers from leading scientific journals and publications. Students will learn what makes good science writing, how to find sources, how to evaluate information and how to sort out science from pseudo-science.

subject: JOUR
name: Covering Washington, D.C. as a Mobile Journalist
description: This class will give students hands-on experience covering the nation's capital as a mobile journalist on a beat, producing up-to-the-minute political stories for the Medill on the Hill website. The primary focus of the course, instant newsgathering and multi-media reporting, will enhance innovative story-telling and deadline skills.

subject: JOUR
name: Internship
description: Student-initiated internships in journalism. Supervised by Medill Career Services.
prereq: Sophomore standing and consent of Medill Career Services

subject: JOUR
name: Special Topics
description: Specialized experimental courses offered from time to time by faculty. Topics may include journalism in a networked world and depth reporting using documents and databases.

subject: JOUR
name: Special Topics
description: Courses, such as Strategies for Career Success, offered for one-half of a quarter.

subject: JOUR
name: Special Topics
description: Special Topics.

subject: JOUR
name: Politics and Presidential Elections
description: Students will learn and apply Gestalt theory to design problems and expand their visual lexicon. Photo history will be brought into context with the larger visual narrative and explore how light, shape, form and composition help communicate complex thought and emotion.

subject: JOUR
name: Undergraduate Independent Study
description: Academic work sponsored and supervised by a faculty member working one-on-one with the student. By application.

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean I
description: First-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic four language skills in Korean.

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean I
description: Second-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic four language skills in Korean.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 111-1 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean I
description: Third-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic four language skills in Korean.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 111-2 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean II
description: First-quarter course of the second-year Korean sequence to further develop four language skills in Korean.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 111-3 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean II
description: Second-quarter course of the second-year Korean sequence to further develop four language skills in Korean.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 121-1 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean II
description: Third-quarter course of the second-year Korean sequence to further develop four language skills in Korean.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 121-2 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean II - Accelerated
description: First-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence for heritage learners to further develop four language skills.

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean II - Accelerated
description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence for heritage learners to further develop four language skills in Korean.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 125-1 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean III
description: First-quarter course of the intermediate-toward-advanced level sequence to further develop four language skills in Korean.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 121-3, or in KOREAN 125-2, or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean III
description: Second-quarter course of the intermediate-toward-advanced level sequence to further develop four language skills in Korean.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 211-1 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean III
description: Third-quarter course of the intermediate-toward-advanced level sequence to further develop four language skills in Korean.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 211-2 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean IV: Readings in Korean Literature
description: Reading literature in Korean to further develop literacy skills and understanding of Korean culture and society.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 211-3 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean IV: Korean through Movies
description: Through Korean films and documentaries, improving oral and writing proficiency, and gaining the knowledge of Korean history, culture, and society.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 211-3 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Korean IV: Topics in the News
description: Through current news, improving oral and writing profiency and better understanding Korean culture and society.
prereq: grade of at least C- in KOREAN 211-3 or equivalent

subject: KOREAN
name: Independent Study
description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Korean.

subject: LATIN
name: Elementary Latin
description: Classical Latin vocabulary, grammar, and syntax with graded readings for translation. Course one of three.

subject: LATIN
name: Elementary Latin
description: Classical Latin vocabulary, grammar, and syntax with graded readings for translation. Course two of three.

subject: LATIN
name: Elementary Latin
description: Classical Latin vocabulary, grammar, and syntax with graded readings for translation. Course three of three.

subject: LATIN
name: Introduction to Latin Literature
description: Grammar and vocabulary review. Readings in Cicero, Virgil, and Catullus; emphasis on literary analysis.

subject: LATIN
name: Introduction to Latin Literature
description: Grammar and vocabulary review. Readings in Cicero, Virgil, and Catullus; emphasis on literary analysis.

subject: LATIN
name: Introduction to Latin Literature
description: Grammar and vocabulary review. Readings in Cicero, Virgil, and Catullus; emphasis on literary analysis.

subject: LATIN
name: Readings in Latin Literature
description: Selected topics and authors including Virgil, Horace, Ovid, Cicero, Tacitus, and Seneca.
prereq: LATIN 201-3 or consent of instructor. May be repeated for credit with different topics

subject: LATIN
name: Latin Prose Composition: Advanced Syntax & Composition
description: Rapid review of Latin morphology and basic grammar, followed by careful study of the syntax of Latin prose and by practice in prose composition.

subject: LATIN
name: Independent Study
description: Individual program of study under the direction of a faculty member. For advanced students only. Permission of department required.

subject: LATIN_AM
name: Topics in Latin American and Caribbean Studies
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to significant topics in Latin American and Caribbean studies. Content varies from year to year; may be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: LATINO
name: First-Year Seminar
description: Open to first-year students in Weinberg College.

subject: LATINO
name: Introduction to Latina and Latino Studies
description: Introduction to major themes and debates shaping US Latina/o communities, such as history of colonization, diverse ethnicities, debates on immigration, racialization, assimilation, and cultural resistance.

subject: LATINO
name: Introduction to Latina & Latino Cultural Studies
description: Introduction to representations of identity and difference through literary theories and cultural studies. Draws on diverse cultural texts such as literature, popular music, folklore, journalism, media, visual culture, and performance arts.

subject: LATINO
name: Latina & Latino History
description: History of Latinas/os in the United States and in the context of US-Latin American relations from the 18th century to the present. HISTORY 218-0 and LATINO 218-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LATINO
name: Latina & Latino Youth in U.S. Cities
description: Cultural, social, and political contexts that shape the lives of Latina/o youth in US cities, as well as Latina/o youths' ideas of self-identity and civic engagement.

subject: LATINO
name: Introduction to Latina and Latino Literature
description: Survey of major writers and movements from Spanish colonial era to the present, covering a range of genres and ethnicities. Taught with ENGLISH 277-0 and SPANISH 277-0; may receive credit for only 1 of these courses.

subject: LATINO
name: Latinx Chicago
description: The Chicagoland area has long been a home for Latina/o/x communities. These communities, spanning and spilling beyond city limits, have profoundly shaped life in the Windy City. Drawing on the ever-growing interdisciplinary scholarship on Latinx Chicago, students will explore the local formation of Latinx identities, politics, and cultural production.

subject: LATINO
name: Latina and Latino Social Movements
description: Histories and ideologies of various US Latina/o social movements. Draws upon historical, ethnographic, autobiographical, and documentary accounts.

subject: LATINO
name: Topics in Latina and Latino History
description: Historical approach to US Latina/o lives and communities, such as history of Latina/o Chicago, labor history, and immigration. Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: LATINO
name: Topics in Latina and Latino Social and Political Issues
description: Social and political issues affecting US Latina/o communities. May include quantitative or qualitative methods, or both. Topics may include electoral politics, immigration, and race and demography. Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: LATINO
name: Topics in Latina and Latino Text and Representation
description: The politics of representation in mainstream and Latina/o media, literature, visual culture, popular music, and performance arts. Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: LATINO
name: Capstone Seminar in Latina & Latino Studies
description: Advanced course synthesizing the state of current research. Questions the boundaries of Latina/o studies. Contextualizes research and topics in relation to other ethnic studies, gender/queer studies, and diaspora studies. Primarily for majors and graduate students.

subject: LATINO
name: Independent Study in Latina and Latino Studies
description: Reading, research, and/or tutorials for students pursuing projects outside the context of regularly offered courses.

subject: LOC
name: Intro to Organization Theory & Practice
description: Examines major organizational behavior theories and practices through organizational analysis.

subject: LOC
name: Culture and Cognition
description: Research and theory on the interrelatedness of culture and thought. Combined with LRN_SCI 214-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LOC
name: Culture and Cognition: SESP Leadership Institute
description: Research and theory on the interrelatedness of culture and thought. Combined with LRN_SCI 214-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LOC
name: Introduction to Organizational Learning
description: Looks at perspectives on learning across levels from individuals to groups to organizations. The goal of the course is to set the foundation for comparing and contrasting different views of learning and making assessments of how each permit us to understand individual and collective processes and outcomes. The course emphasizes explanation, design, and critique through a combination of case analyses, primary empirical research, and project-based learning.

subject: LOC
name: Studies in Organizational Change
description: Examines theories and methods of organizational change through analysis of organizational adaptations; applies theories from learning sciences and organizational behavior.

subject: LOC
name: Redesigning Everyday Organizations
description: Concepts and methods for understanding and studying cognition and learning and putting these concepts and methods to use in a design/change project. Taught with LRN_SCI 308-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LOC
name: Team Dynamics
description: In this course, we will explore team dynamics, those forces that influence a team's behavior and performance, and what can enhance or hinder potential for impact. We will analyze the contributors to team functioning and their interrelationships at multiple levels: intrapersonal, interpersonal, group and organizational. Key topics include team development, team make-up and roles, leadership and followership, decision-making, navigating conflict, collaboration and competition, effective communication, content vs. process, diversity and in-group/out-group tensions. Throughout the class, students will be analyzing and applying concepts through case studies and simulations. Assignments to demonstrate mastery include regular written individual papers and a team project. This course is suitable for undergraduate students in LOC, Human Development in Context, and related majors throughout Northwestern that are interested in leadership, teams/groups or organizational change. Taught with HDC 309-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LOC
name: Learning Organizations for Complex Environments
description: Major change factors, including technology, globalization, and demographics, and their impact on organizations; how organizations are creating and responding to these changes through organizational design, learning systems, and human resource changes.

subject: LOC
name: Tools for Organizational Analysis
description: Understanding cause-and-effect relationships pertaining to organizational behavior and performance.

subject: LOC
name: Modern Organization and Innovations
description: Advances in technologies, from computation to analytics to new models of management and organizations, has radically transformed both every day work and classic models of management and organization. This course takes a novel approach to understanding these transformations by partnering a SESP faculty member with industry leaders and change agents to identify and analyze changing organizational forms and the implications for work in the contemporary economy. In doing so, this course will expose students to variants in organizational models, for example, from the highly institutionalized, yet ever changing, digital firm to firm-market hybrids that supply branded service yet do not employ the providers or own the assets that provide services. Students will have weekly analytic assignments that prepare for and reflect on industry co-instructor sessions as well as a final team project. This course is suitable for undergraduate students in LOC, social policy, and related majors throughout northwestern that are interested in leadership or organizational change. This advanced, highly interactive course fulfills new Learning and Organizational Change (LOC) requirements and is open to LOC students and beyond.

subject: LOC
name: Learning and Thinking in Organizations
description: Examines how human learning and thinking can facilitate organizational growth and change through methods such as instructional design, modeling, and evaluation of learning outcomes.

subject: LOC
name: Psychology of Technology & Instructional Design
description: Introduction to theory and practice in the development of technologies for formal and informal learning in the classroom, workplace, and everyday world.

subject: LOC
name: Topics in Learning and Organizational Change
description: Advanced work on special topics.

subject: LOC
name: Organizational Planning & Analysis
description: Culminating experience involving application of knowledge and skills to analyze real-world problems and solutions in learning and organizational change.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Cognition and Action
description: Perspectives on thinking and learning; how individuals reason and accomplish tasks, both on their own and in interaction with each other and with their immediate environments.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Culture, Language, & Identity
description: Social and cultural dimensions of learning, particularly how diverse linguistic and cultural tools mediate forms of identity, learning experiences, and participation in and transformation of social life.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Culture and Cognition
description: Explore the cultural ground of cognition. How do cultural environments structure and orient our conceptual knowledge, and how do these cognitive processes feedback into cultural systems? Key topics include conceptual development, knowledge organization, causal reasoning, moral psychology, and environmental psychology. Jointly, the topics are integrated through a focus on social and ecological thought. We will engage in cultural artifact analyses, field experiences, and research inquiries. Combined with LOC 214-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Design of Learning Environments
description: Conceiving, building, and testing products and services to help people learn. Topics include the human-centered design process, principles for designing learning environments, and agile project management and communication techniques.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Social Contexts of Education
description: Societal structures that organize, supply, and channel individual learning experiences and how they provide the formal and informal settings in which social interaction takes place, particularly in urban settings. How participation in these socializing settings molds the development of individuals' capacities and forms their goals. Combined with TEACH_ED 302-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Learning with New Media
description: Examines ways to study and learn from social media spaces and how digital platforms shape presentation of content and information sharing practices.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Designing Interactive Media and Technology for Learning
description: Building on theory in the learning sciences and a broad set of multimodal technological tools, students develop and test a collection of learning technologies and examine ways to assess the educational impact of their inventions.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Redesigning Everyday Organizations
description: Concepts and methods for understanding and studying cognition and learning and putting these concepts and methods to use in a design/change project. Combined with LOC 308-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Inclusive Making
description: Excitement for the Maker Movement continues to grow. Part of this growth stems from the idea that Making provides a means for democratization of fabrication and invention. While this is true, in part, the practices and people that are typically included under this brand are limited. In particular, issues of diversity, equity and inclusivity are seldom at the forefront of the design and implementation of Makerspaces, the tools used or the artifacts created. Hence, the purpose of this course is to bring issues of diversity, equity and inclusivity to the forefront. In particular, the goals of this course are to push students to 1) critically explore Making as a practice that promotes democratization, 2) develop interfaces that allow a broader population of students to participate in digital fabrication and 3) design artifacts that positively impact accessibility and inclusivity. The course will include guest speakers, laboratory portions and a projects that encourages students to develop publishable scholarship and/or functional prototypes, as they work in interdisciplinary teams. This is a hands-on project course. All students will design and implement interactive technologies. For this reason you will be expected to do computer programming and digital fabrication. However, all projects can be completed in teams. Hence, it is not essential that all students come with prior knowledge in computer programming and digital fabrication. Additionally, a portion of class and office hours will be devoted to helping students gain familiarity in basic digital fabrication and computer programming.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Tangible Interaction Design and Learning
description: Explores the use of tangible interaction to create innovative learning experiences, including distributed cognition, embodied interaction, cultural forms, and design frameworks. Combined with COMP_SCI 313-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Learning and Teaching with Technology
description: Theory and practice of designing school environments that integrate new technologies and media. Combined with TEACH_ED 338-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LRN_SCI
name: Designing and Constructing Models with Multi-agent Languages
description: Exploration and analysis of multi-agent models, which simulate "emergent" scientific phenomena in a wide variety of content domains. Combined with COMP_SCI 372-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LEGAL_ST
name: First-Year Seminar
description: Open to first-year students in Weinberg College; can satisfy at most 1 credit towards major or minor requirements in Legal Studies.

subject: LEGAL_ST
name: Law and Society
description: Introduction to the role of law in American society and the influence of society on law. Courts, the legal profession, law enforcement, inequality, and social change. Taught with SOCIOL 206-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LEGAL_ST
name: Legal Studies Research Methods
description: Introduction to research methodologies used in interdisciplinary legal studies, including jurisprudence and legal reasoning, qualitative and quantitative social science methods, and historical and textual analysis. LEGAL_ST 207-0 and SOCIOL 227-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: LEGAL_ST
name: Introductory Topics in Legal Studies
description: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

subject: LEGAL_ST
name: American Immigration
