prereq: MATH 220-1, MATH 220-2; concurrent enrollment in PHYSICS 136-1 and MATH 230-1

subject: PHYSICS
name: General Physics
description: Calculus-based physics for science and engineering majors and premedical students. Electricity and magnetism.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 136-1 and concurrent enrollment in PHYSICS 136-2

subject: PHYSICS
name: General Physics
description: Calculus-based physics for science and engineering majors and premedical students. Introduction to modern physics; wave phenomena.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-2, PHYSICS 136-2 and concurrent enrollment in PHYSICS 136-3

subject: PHYSICS
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: General Physics 1
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in PHYSICS 135-1. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: General Physics 2
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in PHYSICS 135-2. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: General Physics 3
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in PHYSICS 135-3. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: PHYSICS
name: General Physics Laboratory
description: Introductory physics laboratory for students taking PHYSICS 130-1 or PHYSICS 135-1, with which it must be taken concurrently.

subject: PHYSICS
name: General Physics Laboratory
description: Introductory physics laboratory for students taking PHYSICS 130-2 or PHYSICS 135-2, with which it must be taken concurrently.

subject: PHYSICS
name: General Physics Laboratory
description: Introductory physics laboratory for students taking PHYSICS 130-3 or PHYSICS 135-3, with which it must be taken concurrently.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Fundamentals of Physics
description: Introduction to fundamental topics in classical mechanics for physics majors and minors and students with a strong interest in physics.
prereq: MATH 220-1, MATH 220-2; concurrent enrollment in PHYSICS 136-1 and MATH 230-1

subject: PHYSICS
name: Fundamentals of Physics
description: Introduction to fundamental topics in electricity and magnetism for physics majors and minors and students with a strong interest in physics.
prereq: PHYSICS 140-1, PHYSICS 136-1; concurrent enrollment in PHYSICS 136-2

subject: PHYSICS
name: Fundamentals of Physics
description: Introduction to fundamental topics in wave phenomena and modern physics for physics majors and minors and students with a strong interest in physics.
prereq: PHYSICS 140-2, PHYSICS 136-2; concurrent enrollment in PHYSICS 136-3

subject: PHYSICS
name: Foundations of Modern Physics
description: Principles of waves, probability, quantum theory, and selected topics from special relativity, statistical mechanics, optics, and atomic structure.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, and PHYSICS 135-3 or equivalent; MATH 250-0 or equivalent or concurrent enrollment

subject: PHYSICS
name: Mathematical Tools for the Physical Sciences
description: Introduction to tools for solving physics problems, including integral calculus, complex numbers and complex algebra, matrices and vector spaces, differential equations, and Fourier analysis.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1 and PHYSICS 135-2 or equivalent (concurrent enrollment in PHYSICS 135-2 is sufficient); MATH 230-1

subject: PHYSICS
name: Mathematical Tools for the Physical Sciences
description: Introduction to tools for solving physics problems, including integral calculus, complex numbers and complex algebra, matrices and vector spaces, differential equations, and Fourier analysis.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-3 (or concurrent enrollment); PHYSICS 311-1 or equivalent

subject: PHYSICS
name: Scalar and Vector Field Methods in Physics
description: Physically contextualized introduction to the field concept, the associated methods of calculus, and the solution of key physical partial differential equations. Three lectures and one discussion per week.
prereq: PHYSICS 311-1, PHYSICS 311-2, or MATH 230-1, MATH 230-2, MATH 240-0, and MATH 250-0, or equivalents

subject: PHYSICS
name: Classical Mech
description: Newtonian mechanics, oscillations, the Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formalisms, central-force motion.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1 or equivalent and MATH 230-2 and PHYSICS 311-1 and PHYSICS 311-2; or MATH 240-0, MATH 250-0; or equivalent

subject: PHYSICS
name: Classical Mechanics
description: Motion in a non-inertial reference frame, kinematics of rigid modes, systems with many degrees of freedom.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Statistical Mechanics
description: Ideal gas, Boltzmann distribution, transport phenomena, fluctuation theory, Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac statistics.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, and PHYSICS 135-3; MATH 230-2 or equivalent

subject: PHYSICS
name: Advanced Electricity & Magnetism
description: Electrostatics and magnetostatics, multipole expansion, solutions of Laplace's equation, images, analytic functions.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, and PHYSICS 135-3 and MATH 230-2 and PHYSICS 311-1 and PHYSICS 311-2; or MATH 240-0, MATH 250-0; or equivalent

subject: PHYSICS
name: Advanced Electricity & Magnetism
description: Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic equations, electromagnetic wave propagation and radiation, microwave cavities, diffraction.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, and PHYSICS 135-3 and MATH 230-2 and PHYSICS 311-1 and PHYSICS 311-2; or MATH 240-0, MATH 250-0; or equivalent

subject: PHYSICS
name: Physics of Magic
description: Magic tricks, illusion, and deception used to discuss the rarely explored but often surprisingly flexible boundaries of what is physically possible. Does not fulfill 300-level requirement for majors or minors.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Physics of Condensed Matter
description: Emergent properties and collective descriptions when simple components of matter are combined into larger systems with varying degrees of order.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Quantum Mechanics
description: Introduction to quantum theory. Applications to atomic and molecular systems. The harmonic oscillator, the one-electron atom, the hydrogen molecule, barrier penetration.
prereq: second-year standing in ISP or PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, and PHYSICS 135-3 or equivalent; PHYSICS 239-0; PHYSICS 330-1; PHYSICS 311-1 or MATH 240-0

subject: PHYSICS
name: Quantum Mechanics
description: Introduction to quantum theory. Applications to atomic and molecular systems. The harmonic oscillator, the one-electron atom, the hydrogen molecule, barrier penetration.
prereq: PHYSICS 339-1, second-year standing in ISP or PHYSICS 311-2 or MATH 250-0, MATH 351-0

subject: PHYSICS
name: Particle and Nuclear Physics
description: Nuclei and their constituents; nuclear models; alpha and beta decay; nuclear fission and fusion; the strong, electromagnetic, and weak interactions; and the fundamental particles and particle schemes.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Introduction to General Relativity
description: Review of special relativity and Newtonian gravity; curved space-time; geodesics and conservation laws; Schwarzschild geometry; tests of general relativity; black holes; linearized gravity and gravitational waves; and big bang cosmology.
prereq: PHYSICS 330-1 and PHYSICS 330-2 or consent of instructor

subject: PHYSICS
name: Introduction to Computational Physics
description: Application of computing to physics: Monte Carlo simulation, numerical integration of equations of motion, discrete element methods in electromagnetism.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, and PHYSICS 135-3 or equivalent; MATH 250-0 or equivalent (concurrent enrollment is sufficient); COMP_SCI 110-0 or equivalent prior programming experience

subject: PHYSICS
name: Optics Laboratory
description: Optics/laser lab focusing on optical instruments widely used in medical/biological studies, including optical microscopy, fluorescence spectroscopy, tumor detection in optical scattering, and optical fibers in endoscopes.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Nanolithography
description: Advanced lab involving fabrication of metallic nanometer-scale structures by electron-beam lithography. Characterization of these structures by atomic force microscopy.
prereq: PHYSICS 135-1, PHYSICS 135-2, and PHYSICS 135-3 or equivalent

subject: PHYSICS
name: Electronics
description: Introduction to modern electronics, construction of elementary analog and digital circuits.
prereq: PHYSICS 333-1 and PHYSICS 333-2 or consent of instructor

subject: PHYSICS
name: Advanced Physics Laboratory
description: Modern experimental techniques and data analysis methods. Both classic and modern experiments in atomic/nuclear physics, electricity and magnetism, optics, condensed matter physics, and nonlinear dynamics. This laboratory emphasizes independent work. This course consists primarily of two four-hour sessions per week, which may have lecture and laboratory periods.
prereq: PHYSICS 239-0 or PHYSICS 339-1, and PHYSICS 333-1, or permission of instructor

subject: PHYSICS
name: Classical Optics and Special Relativity
description: Advanced topics following from electrodynamics, including advanced classical optics, Fraunhofer and Fresnel diffraction, radiation from accelerated charges, wave guides and/or antennae, and special relativity, including dynamics.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
description: Advanced topics following from classical mechanics. The focus will be on nonlinear dynamics and chaos theory, though coupled oscillations and continuous systems will also be covered.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Topics in Physics
description: This is a special topics course, and each time it is offered could be a completely different topic. Although the topic can change, it is expected that independent of the content, this is an advanced physics course that builds on core physics knowledge. Prerequisites vary by offering. It would generally require knowledge of at least one core physics course (Physics 330, 332, 333, 339) or the equivalent mathematics or Permission from Instructor.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Independent Thesis Research
description: Individual study under the direction of a faculty member. Open only to advanced students pursuing departmental honors.

subject: PHYSICS
name: Independent Study
description: Opportunity to study an advanced subject of interest under the individual direction of a faculty member. Open to all advanced students; consent of instructor required.

subject: PIANO
name: Piano Repertoire I
description: Analytical and historical study of piano solo and concerto repertoire from early keyboard literature to the present.

subject: PIANO
name: Piano Repertoire II
description: Analytical and historical study of piano solo and concerto repertoire from early keyboard literature to the present.

subject: PIANO
name: Piano Repertoire III
description: Analytical and historical study of piano solo and concerto repertoire from early keyboard literature to the present.

subject: PIANO
name: Piano Pedagogy I
description: Lecture/demonstration/laboratory course in piano teaching at all levels. Principles and techniques of group and individual instruction; survey of teaching materials. Seniors and graduate students.

subject: PIANO
name: Piano Pedagogy II
description: Lecture/demonstration/laboratory course in piano teaching at all levels. Principles and techniques of group and individual instruction; survey of teaching materials. Seniors and graduate students.

subject: PIANO
name: Piano Pedagogy III
description: Lecture/demonstration/laboratory course in piano teaching at all levels. Principles and techniques of group and individual instruction; survey of teaching materials. Seniors and graduate students.

subject: PIANO
name: Collaborative Piano-Beginning I
description: Piano students work with a singer and instrumentalist in the preparation and performance of mainstream recital repertoire.

subject: PIANO
name: Collaborative Piano-Beginning II
description: Piano students work with a singer and instrumentalist in the preparation and performance of mainstream recital repertoire.

subject: PIANO
name: Collaborative Piano-Beginning III
description: Piano students work with a singer and instrumentalist in the preparation and performance of mainstream recital repertoire.

subject: PIANO
name: Duo Class
description: Provides an opportunity for pianists and their vocal and/or instrumental partners to receive intensive coaching on works of their choice. A final performance is required.

subject: PIANO
name: Selected Topics
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: PIANO
name: Repertoire Studies
description: Topics vary by quarter.

subject: POLISH
name: Elementary Polish
description: Polish language and culture. Basic reading, writing, listening, and speaking. No prerequisite.

subject: POLISH
name: Elementary Polish (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 108-2)
description: Polish language and culture. Basic reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

subject: POLISH
name: Elementary Polish (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 108-3)
description: Polish language and culture. Basic reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

subject: POLISH
name: Intermediate Polish: Language and Culture (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 208-1)
description: Reading on topics in Polish culture and society.

subject: POLISH
name: Intermediate Polish: Language and Culture (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 208-2)
description: Reading on topics in Polish culture and society.

subject: POLISH
name: Intermediate Polish: Language and Culture (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 208-3)
description: Reading on topics in Polish culture and society.

subject: POLISH
name: Polish for Advanced and Native Speakers (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 358-1)
description: Polish for advanced speakers, including those who grew up in the United States. Stress on advanced levels of reading and writing as well as speaking. Taught entirely in Polish. Content varies; may be repeated for credit.

subject: POLISH
name: Polish for Advanced and Native Speakers
description: Polish for advanced speakers, including those who grew up in the United States. Stress on advanced levels of reading and writing as well as speaking. Taught entirely in Polish. Content varies; may be repeated for credit.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Introduction to Political Theory
description: Examination of texts in political theory. Topics vary but often include justice, the Greek polis, the modern state, individualism, representative democracy.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Introduction to Empirical Methods in Political Science
description: Tools political scientists use. How qualitative, quantitative, and experimental research designs help answer difficult descriptive and causal questions.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Introduction to Interpretive Methods in Political Science
description: Philosophy of inquiry and interpretive research methods for students of political science. Examines diverse schools of thought on research methods and their relevance for research goals.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Evaluating Evidence
description: Introduction to evaluation of qualitative and quantitative evidence across science, politics, society, health, education, and industry. POLI_SCI 212-0 and COG_SCI 202-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: American Government and Politics
description: The structure and process of American politics from competing perspectives. Analysis of representation, voting, interest groups, parties, leadership, and policymaking institutions. The gateway course for the American politics subfield.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Introduction to Law in the Political Arena
description: Roles of law in society and politics. Police and prisons, law and social change, courts and politics, legal reasoning, Supreme Court decision making, judicial discretion, legal strategies for making change.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Introduction to International Relations
description: Introduction to the major theories, concepts, and problems of contemporary international relations. Security, political economy, and cooperation.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
description: Emphasis may be on industrialized and/or developing states. Major issues include regime-society relations, political change and conflict, and policy making.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Classical Political Theory
description: Political thought of Greece and Rome in historical context and with attention to contemporary theoretical interest.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Subjects, Citizens, Revolutionaries: Early Modern Political Thought
description: Political philosophers from the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries. Topics include sources of power and their impact on justice, equality, and law. No prerequisites, but some knowledge of political theory is desirable.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Modernity and Its Discontents
description: Examination of late 19th and early 20th century social and political thought in the works of writers such as Marx, Weber, Mill, Kafka, Darwin, Nietzsche, Freud, and de Beauvoir. No prerequisites, but some knowledge of political theory is desirable.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Human Rights Between East and West
description: In this course, students consider challenges leveled against the declared universalism of human rights. They assess these challenges from the perspective of two non-western traditions: Islam and Confucianism.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: American Political Thought
description: Advanced introduction to the development of political thought in the United States from the revolutionaries to the 20th century pragmatists.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Deportation Law and Politics
description: Analysis of deportation law and politics from colonial America through today. Requires two visits to Chicago immigration courts.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Critical Theory and the Study of Politics
description: Critical theory examines and contests hegemonic thinking about politics and envisages alternate worlds of political possibility. Note: students cannot receive credit for both POLI_SCI 308-0 (Evanston) and POLI_SCI 308-SA (study abroad).

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Critical Theory and the Study of Politics
description: Critical theory examines and contests hegemonic thinking about politics and envisages alternate worlds of political possibility. This study abroad course is restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program in critical theory, literature, and media.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Political Theories of the Rule of Law
description: Key documents and debates in the development of theories of law and jurisprudence. From Aeschylus to contemporary democratic and legal theories and major court cases on topics ranging from torture to Title IX. POLI_SCI 309-0 and LEGAL_ST 309-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Methods of Political Inference
description: Methods for inferences based on data in political research. Research design and quantitative and qualitative methods of inference. Focuses on descriptive, statistical, and causal inference and the application of different methods to substantive problems.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Logics of Political Inquiry
description: Political science as "science." Identity sources, construction, functions, and validation of social science theory and explanation from varied perspectives.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Statistical Research Methods
description: Intermediate coverage of statistical methods appropriate for data in political science research, such as multiple regression, logit and probit, estimation and inference with non-independent or non-identically distributed sampling, basic time series and panel data methods, and causal inference in statistical models.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: The American Presidency
description: Structural foundations and historical development of the American presidency; predominant scholarly theories of presidential power and leadership; contemporary issues and debates.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Urban Politics
description: Structure of local and regional political power and its relation to the social and economic structure of community.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Ideas and Institutions in Urban Politics
description: Advanced urban politics. Analyzes opportunities for action in local politics and challenges for effective governance in the modern metropolis.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Public Opinion and Voting Behavior
description: Who votes and for whom. Social, psychological, economic, and political factors influencing election choices. Sources of opinions. Focus on American presidential elections with some comparative and nonpresidential material.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Political Parties and Elections
description: Role of political parties in a democratic society. Topics include nomination, national conventions, political funding, campaigns, party organization, and national, state, and local parties.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Congress and the Legislative Process
description: Organization of legislatures to make public policy; impact of constituents and political parties on legislative decision making; polarization; legislative-executive relations. Emphasis on the US Congress and contemporary politics.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Race and Public Policy
description: Analysis of how diversity shapes policy in the United States and how policies contribute to racial and ethnic diversity. Immigration reform, school choice, residential segregation, and criminal justice.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: African American Politics
description: Survey of black politics in the United States, including blacks' relations with government, whites, political parties, public policy, and electoral politics.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Public Policy
description: The role of government in regulating economic and social behavior; theories of public policy making; sources and effects of public policy.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: U.S. Environmental Politics
description: Political problems associated with human impact on natural environment; pollution, natural resources, public lands, land use, energy, and population.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: U.S. Refugee Policy & Localities
description: Comparative understandings of refugee policies in liberal democracies and their relation to constitutional and human rights. Street level bureaucracy, constitutional governance, federalism, integration, refugee resettlement policy, citizenship and belonging. POLI_SCI 330-0 and LEGAL_ST 330-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of the Supreme Court
description: Operation of appellate courts, with emphasis on the US Supreme Court. Decision making by appellate courts and the development of public policy.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Constitutional Law I
description: Introduction to interpretation of the US Constitution by the Supreme Court. Judicial review, federalism, congressional and executive authority, separation of powers. Taught with LEGAL_ST 332-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Constitutional Law II: Civil and Political Rights
description: Consideration of US Supreme Court decisions dealing with civil and political rights, including equality, freedom of speech, and freedom of religion. LEGAL_ST 333-0 and POLI_SCI 333-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Latino Politics
description: Implications of Latino politics including contemporary social and political developments of Latino communities in the United States from a comparative urban framework. Focus on Mexican and Cuban Americans and Puerto Ricans.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Political Psychology
description: Examination of mental processes that underpin political judgments. Origins of political views, influence of parties and news media, decision-making heuristics and biases. Emphasis on ordinary citizens; some attention to elites.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Immigration Politics and Policy
description: Introduction to immigration politics in the U.S. with a focus on policies, public opinion, participation, and mobilization. Emphasis on relationships between nativity, citizenship status, legal status, and race/ethnicity.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: International Relations Theory
description: Conceptual approaches to international relations, including "national interest," sovereignty, international norms and law, and rationality.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: International Political Economy
description: Introduction to the politics of international economic relations. Roots and evolution of the international political economy. Fundamental controversies about international trade, finance, and development.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: International Organizations
description: Institutions that govern the interactions of states, including the WTO, UN, ICJ, and ICC; informal norms, such as international intervention, international criminal law, and sovereignty. POLI_SCI 342-0 and LEGAL_ST 342-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of International Law
description: Non-utopian political science analysis of how law is used to promote collective goals and regulate international relations.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: U.S. Foreign Policy
description: How US foreign policy is formulated, executed, legitimated, and contested. Topics include 9/11 and its aftermath, covert action, interventionism, trade, US respect for international norms, and US engagement with the Middle East.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: National Security
description: Basic issues in national security, focusing primarily on the United States. Topics include the nature of "national interest," major actors in national security policy making and military strategy, and the influence and role of the defense establishment.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: European Union in International Affairs
description: Introduction to the institutions and policies of the European Union today.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Ethics in International Relations
description: Role of ethical considerations in international relations: where and when ethical questions are raised and by whom; causes and predictability of tensions between the ethics and self-interests of nations and political figures.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Globalization
description: Analysis of changes in the world economy and their implications for politics, economics, and society. Politics of multinational production, finance, and trade in the context of governance problems in a globalizing world.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: International Environmental Politics
description: International cooperation and conflict resolution of global and transnational environmental problems such as climate change. Role of political, economic, and normative considerations in the formation of politically feasible solutions to international environmental problems.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Social Movements
description: Theory and case studies examining the processes shaping collective challenges to authority. Topics include causes and mechanics of mobilization, the contexts in which movements emerge, repression and violence, strategies, and determinants of movement outcomes.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of the Middle East
description: Survey of politics and political history of the Middle East and North Africa from World War I to the present. Topics include state building, authoritarianism, political economy, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and the causes, trajectories, and aftermath of the 2011 Arab uprisings.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Global Development
description: Exploration of the economic and social changes constituting development, focusing on comparison between the historical experience in Europe and more recent processes in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. SOCIOL 317-0 and POLI_SCI 352-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of Latin America
description: Patterns of socioeconomic development and regime forms in Latin America. Interaction of internal and international economic and political structures and processes.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of Southeast Asia
description: Political economy of selected Southeast Asian countries, 1945 to present. Important themes include oligarchy and human rights.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of China
description: Chinese politics since 1949, focusing on social issues and state-society relations since 1989. Basic foundation for the non-specialist as well as preparation for advanced study.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Constitutional Challenges in Comparative Perspective
description: Constitutional controversies and resolutions in liberal democracies. Constitutional traditions and governance, rule of law, legitimacy and authority in diverse societies, human rights, social transformation. POLI_SCI 356-0 and LEGAL_ST 356-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Political Economy of Israel
description: Influence of demographics, political factors, and Israeli-Palestinian conflict on development, economic policy, government spending, public health, and socio-economy. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Israel program.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Contemporary South Africa: A Political Economy/Policy Perspective
description: Analysis of the political outcomes of South Africa's transition to democracy, democratic consolidation, the state of the South African political economy, and major policy issues, such as gender equality and HIV/AIDS. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of Africa
description: Political structures and relation of cultural factors to political stability and change; development of modern political systems.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Democratic Transitions
description: Theories of the emergence and breakdown of democracy with a focus on cases from Europe, Latin America, Africa, and Asia. Note: students cannot receive credit for both POLI_SCI 361-0 (Evanston) and POLI_SCI 361-SA (study abroad).

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Democratic Transitions
description: Theories of the emergence and breakdown of democracy with a focus on cases from Europe, Latin America, Africa, and Asia. Note: students cannot receive credit for both POLI_SCI 361-0 (Evanston) and POLI_SCI 361-SA (study abroad).

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of Europe
description: Impact of historical development on contemporary institutions, political and political-economic institutions, interest groups and parties, policy making, and social and economic policy.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: The Political Economy of the European Union
description: The political production, structure, and regulation of economic activity in the EU. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: France: Politics, Culture, & Society
description: Introduction to French politics in the framework of European integration. Covers French efforts to promote integration and France's role in the international system and adaptation to the EU. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Decision Making in the European Union
description: Analysis, by lecture and simulation, of the EU's complicated institutional structure for political decision making. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: The Dynamics of Law Making in the European Union
description: Examination of the dynamics of law making in the EU and conflict/balance between domestic and regional law. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Political Economy of Development
description: Major analytical perspectives of modern political economy seen through concrete problems of development and underdevelopment in the least developed countries.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of Post-Soviet Russia
description: Analysis of Russia's political and economic revolutions after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Examines key concepts in comparative politics, such as revolution, regime change, market formation, nationalism, and state building.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: The Middle East in International Politics
description: International history and politics of the Arab states, Israel, Iran, and Turkey. Colonialism and nationalism, political Islam and secularism, the Iranian Revolution, the Gulf War of 1991, the US-led occupation of Iraq, relations between Turkey and the European Union. Recommended but not required: POLI_SCI 240-0.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Chinese Foreign Policy
description: Basic dynamics of Chinese foreign policy toward a variety of countries and regions.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of Capitalism
description: Effects of politics on the economy and vice versa, especially in advanced industrial economies. The welfare state, varieties of capitalism, and neoliberalism.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Civil Wars
description: Focus on post-Cold War increase in civil wars, including causes and consequences of internal wars, and theories of conflict. Examines recent and contemporary civil wars to illustrate applications of theories and better understand current events.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Drugs and Politics
description: Analysis of the links between illegal drugs and politics, from the politics of local communities to international public policy. Regional focus on North, Central, and South America.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: America and the World
description: Key debates and developments in the history and politics of American foreign relations. Domestic politics and foreign policy, political culture, interventionism, legal globalization, international institutions.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: China in Transition: Ideology, Political Economy, Law, and Relations with the US
description: Broad issues confronting China in its long, tumultuous transition. For students with no background as well as those with extensive prior knowledge of China. Restricted to students in Northwestern's program in China.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Refugee Crises and Human Rights
description: Development of international human rights. Comparative state and regional responses to forced migration due to war, conflict, and generalized violence. Humanitarian intervention, international law, and policy issues, such as gender-based violence, migrants at sea, and human trafficking. POLI_SCI 380-0 and LEGAL_ST 380-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Political Economy of Contemporary China
description: State capitalism, the role of state-owned enterprises in China's economic development, China as a regulatory state, social consequences, financial reforms. Restricted to students in Northwestern's program in China.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Politics of Religious Diversity
description: Intersection of religion, law, and politics in comparative and global perspective. Legal, political, and religious history; discrimination and identity; religion, race, indigeneity, empire; religious liberalization; rule of law; national security.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: War and Change in International Politics
description: Historical and contemporary forms of international order. Western and non-Eurocentric systems; how international order emerges; whether the post-1945 order will change.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: International Responses to Mass Atrocities
description: How the international community can respond to mass atrocities and human rights violations.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Institutions and Society
description: Institutions in a broad societal context. How institutional frameworks apply to government, family, education, and the environment; implications of institutions. POLI_SCI 388-0 and SOCIOL 288-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Understanding Genocide
description: Key debates in the comparative study of genocide. Why genocide occurs, why people become killers, how these processes relate to each other. POLI_SCI 389-0 and SOCIOL 379-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Special Topics in Political Science
description: Designed for investigation of topics of interest to students and faculty that are not covered by other course offerings. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Special Topics in Political Science
description: Designed for investigation of topics of interest to students and faculty that are not covered by other course offerings. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Political Research Seminar
description: Required of all political science majors; ordinarily taken during junior or senior year.

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Senior Thesis Seminar
description: Two consecutive quarters (fall and winter) during which students work on their senior theses.
prereq: POLI_SCI 395-0 and admission to the honors program

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Senior Thesis Seminar
description: Two consecutive quarters (fall and winter) during which students work on their senior theses.
prereq: POLI_SCI 395-0 and admission to the honors program

subject: POLI_SCI
name: Independent Study
description: Study and research projects carried out under faculty supervision. A written proposal, signed by the professor with whom the student will study, should be submitted to the director of undergraduate studies. Consent of department required.

subject: PORT
name: Elementary Portuguese
description: Introduction to grammar and development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Brazilian Portuguese, as well as the history and culture of Portuguese-speaking countries.

subject: PORT
name: Elementary Portuguese
description: Introduction to grammar and development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Brazilian Portuguese, as well as the history and culture of Portuguese-speaking countries.
prereq: PORT 101-1 or sufficient score on placement test

subject: PORT
name: Elementary Portuguese
description: Introduction to grammar and development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Brazilian Portuguese, as well as the history and culture of Portuguese-speaking countries.
prereq: PORT 101-2 or sufficient score on placement examination

subject: PORT
name: First-Year Seminar
description: WCAS first-year seminar.

subject: PORT
name: Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
description: For students proficient in Spanish. Comparative sociolinguistic and interactive approach to communicative competence emphasizing pronunciation, intonation, sentence structure, and patterns of spoken and written Portuguese.
prereq: AP 4 in Spanish or equivalent on the Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: PORT
name: Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
description: For students proficient in Spanish. Comparative sociolinguistic and interactive approach to communicative competence emphasizing pronunciation, intonation, sentence structure, and patterns of spoken and written Portuguese.
prereq: PORT 115-1.This course is equivalent to PORT 121-3

subject: PORT
name: Intermediate Portuguese
description: Port 121 helps students achieve an intermediate level of proficiency through further development of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills. Grammar, vocabulary and pronunciation of Brazilian Portuguese will continue to be developed through meaningful cultural contexts. The course also offers insights into the history and culture of the Portuguese speaking countries in Europe, Africa and America.

subject: PORT
name: Intermediate Portuguese
description: Port 121 helps students achieve an intermediate level of proficiency through further development of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills. Grammar, vocabulary and pronunciation of Brazilian Portuguese will continue to be developed through meaningful cultural contexts. The course also offers insights into the history and culture of the Portuguese speaking countries in Europe, Africa and America.
prereq: PORT 121-1 or sufficient score on the Portuguese Language Placement Exam

subject: PORT
name: Intermediate Portuguese
description: Port 121 helps students achieve an intermediate level of proficiency through further development of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills. Grammar, vocabulary and pronunciation of Brazilian Portuguese will continue to be developed through meaningful cultural contexts. The course also offers insights into the history and culture of the Portuguese speaking countries in Europe, Africa and America.
prereq: PORT 121-2 or Placement. There is no P/N allowed. First class is mandatory

subject: PORT
name: Reading and Speaking Portuguese
description: This intermediate course is designed to expand mastery in reading and speaking Brazilian Portuguese through select cultural videos, readings of literary cronicas, periodicals, and the Internet.
prereq: PORT 115-2, PORT 121-3, or sufficient score on placement examination

subject: PORT
name: Reading and Writing Portuguese
description: Instruction in reading and writing expository and narrative prose. Emphasis on vocabulary, linguistic skills, and syntax appropriate to formal written Portuguese.
prereq: PORT 115-2, PORT 121-3, or sufficient score on placement examination

subject: PORT
name: Icons, Legends, and Myths in Brazil
description: Representations in graphic materials, documentaries, film, theater, folklore, narrative fiction, and popular music of historical, literary, and popular figures in the national imagination. May include English or Portuguese discussion sections. Prerequisite for Portuguese section: PORT 201-0, PORT 202-0, or sufficient score on placement exam. Prerequisite for English section: none.

subject: PORT
name: Topics in Advanced Portuguese
description: Advanced review of grammar concepts and idiomatic use of spoken and written Portuguese. Deals with a variety of topics in the context of Brazilian culture, history, literature, and current events. May be taken more than once for credit with change of topic.

subject: PORT
name: Contemporary Brazil: Literature and Film
description: Study of the literature and film produced in Brazil during the 21st century. Focus on narrative forms, genres, and sociocultural issues.

subject: PORT
name: Topics in Lusophone Cultures
description: Aspects of the literatures and cultures of Brazil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa (Mozambique, Angola, Cape Verde, São Tomé and Principe, Guinea-Bissau). Possible topics include Brazilian modernism, Lusophone African literature and film, race and sexuality in Brazilian literature, travel narrative, literature and ethnography, the Portuguese novel, nation and nationalism. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: PORT
name: Independent Study
description: Independent study under supervision. Consultation with the director of undergraduate studies required.

subject: PSYCH
name: Introduction to Psychology
description: A survey course reviewing primary psychological research and theories of human behavior. Laboratory experience exposes students to psychology as a research science.

subject: PSYCH
name: Statistical Methods in Psychology
description: Measurement; descriptive statistics; probability and sampling; T-test, ANOVA, correlation, and regression.

subject: PSYCH
name: Research Methods in Psychology
description: Methods of psychological research; experimental design; reliability and validity; review and application of statistics; execution and reporting of psychological research.

subject: PSYCH
name: Social Psychology
description: Psychological processes underlying social behavior; topics include social cognition, attraction, aggression, prejudice, and behavior in groups.

subject: PSYCH
name: Psychology of Personality
description: Nature of personality and its development. Modern theoretical interpretations. Biological and social bases of individual differences.

subject: PSYCH
name: Introduction to Neuroscience
description: Designed for students with no prior coursework in neuroscience or biology. Neurophysiology and neuroanatomy; neuroscience of perception, emotion, morality, memory, mental illness, and consciousness. Neuroscience majors may not take PSYCH 221-0. Students may not take PSYCH 221-0 after they have taken NEUROSCI 202-0.

subject: PSYCH
name: Cognitive Psychology
description: Introduction to research into mental processes such as memory, reasoning, problem solving, and decision making.

subject: PSYCH
name: Developmental Psychology
description: Development of cognitive, social, and other psychological functions.

subject: PSYCH
name: Presenting Ideas & Data
description: Understanding principles of cognitive psychology, data visualization, and graphic design to present ideas and data in an engaging, clear, and memorable manner. PSYCH 245-0 and COG_SCI 245-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: PSYCH
name: Health Psychology
description: Overview of research in health psychology. Stress and coping, biological systems affected by stress, social support and health, health behaviors, adjustment to chronic illnesses.

subject: PSYCH
name: Buddhist Psychology
description: Buddhist and scientific psychological views of mind and behavior; meditation techniques.

subject: PSYCH
name: Psychopathology
description: Understanding the nature of psychological, emotional, and behavioral disorders. Emphasis on current evidence regarding causes and characteristics of these disorders.

subject: PSYCH
name: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
description: Definition and history of clinical psychology, personality theory in clinical psychology, diagnosis and classification of disorders, assessment, psychotherapy, and ethical issues.

subject: PSYCH
name: Cognitive Behavior Therapy
description: Scientific foundations of cognitive behavior therapy for a wide range of disorders. Focus on the rationale for different treatments and evidence of efficacy and process. Comparisons with other scientifically validated treatments.

subject: PSYCH
name: Special Topics in Social/Clinical/Personality
description: Topic to be announced. Prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: PSYCH
name: Psychology of Attitudes
description: Survey of social psychological research on attitudes; focus on the formation of attitudes, the relationship between attitudes and behavior, and attitude change.

subject: PSYCH
name: Relationship Science
description: Social-psychological analysis of close relationships, with an emphasis on romantic relationships. Interpersonal processes associated with relationship formation, development, and dissolution.

subject: PSYCH
name: The Holocaust: Psychological Themes & Perspectives
description: This course will be an exploration of how particular psychological theories and concepts can inform our understanding of the events of the Holocaust at both a group and individual level. Material from the fields of Social and Clinical Psychology will be a particular focus of the course.

subject: PSYCH
name: Intermediate Neuroscience
description: Intermediate principles of neuroscience; neurophysiology, neuropharmacology, neuroanatomy, and electrophysiological substrates of psychological processes.

subject: PSYCH
name: Perception
description: Human perception, particularly vision but also hearing, taste, smell, and touch. Biological foundations, development, and disorders of perception. The senses in everyday life.

subject: PSYCH
name: Selected Topics in Neuroscience and Psychophysiology
description: Applied psychophysiology; brain activity coding of cognitive events, biofeedback, opiate pain control.

subject: PSYCH
name: Brain and Cognition
description: Neural bases of cognitive processing with emphases on neuroimaging approaches in the areas of encoding, perception, attention, memory, language, reading, motor control, and executive functioning. Taught with CSD 303-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: PSYCH
name: Brain Damage and the Mind
description: Survey of human cognition as studied via investigations of brain damage and brain-imaging techniques.

subject: PSYCH
name: Special Topics in Cognition/Neuroscience
description: Topic to be announced. Prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: PSYCH
name: Psychology of Thinking
description: Research methods and recent experimental findings for types of human thinking. Students conduct original research.

subject: PSYCH
name: Consciousness
description: Examines how psychologists, neuroscientists, computer scientists, and physicists have tackled fundamental questions about consciousness using empirical and theoretical methods.
prereq: a course in cognition and/or neuroscience, or instructor permission based on a strong background in neurobiology and/or physics; PSYCH 205-0 strongly recommended

subject: PSYCH
name: Psychology and Law
description: Examines the application of psychology to law, including topics such as the insanity defense, criminal profiling, eyewitness testimony, and interrogation.
prereq: PSYCH 110-0. Taught with LEGAL_ST 350-0; may not receive credit for both courses

subject: PSYCH
name: Positive Psychology: The Science of Well-Being
description: Key developments in the field of positive psychology. Eudaimonic and hedonic wellbeing, mindfulness and flow, importance of social connections, emotional resilience, positive institutions.

subject: PSYCH
name: Evolutionary Psychology
description: Theory, methodology, and empirical data related to how evolution has influenced human psychology and behavior. Emphasis on mating.

subject: PSYCH
name: Psychology of Beauty
description: Theory, methodology, and empirical data related to the psychological impact of human beauty. Emphasis on both cultural and evolutionary perspectives.

subject: PSYCH
name: Cultural Psychology
description: Introduction to concepts and empirical methods used to study how culture shapes mind, brain, and behavior over multiple time scales, including over generations and the lifespan and across situational contexts.

subject: PSYCH
name: Psychology of Gender
description: Examination of sex differences and similarities. Evaluation of explanations for differences. Review of how gender affects achievement, relationships, and mental health.

subject: PSYCH
name: Special Topics in Psychology
description: Topic to be announced. Prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: PSYCH
name: Native Americans and Environmental Decision Making
description: Focus on Native Americans, culture and cultural processes, and environmental decision making. Emphasis on contemporary Native American cultures and relevant research. ENVR_POL 356-0 and PSYCH 356-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: PSYCH
name: Personality Research
description: Research in personality, with emphasis on experimental approaches and methods. Basic concepts of test reliability and validity. Students conduct original research.

subject: PSYCH
name: Social and Personality Development
description: Research methods, theories, and facts relating to the development and modification of attitudes and behavior.
prereq: PSYCH 205-0; and PSYCH 213-0, PSYCH 215-0, or PSYCH 244-0

subject: PSYCH
name: Stereotyping & Prejudice
description: Analysis of the causes and consequences of stereotyping and prejudice, as well as methods used to study these issues. Students conduct original research.

subject: PSYCH
name: Child Psychopathology
description: Major forms of psychopathology present during childhood, including disorders exclusive to childhood and those that may appear during any developmental period. Developmental models of the etiology and course of major psychopathologies.

subject: PSYCH
name: Psychological Tests & Measures
description: Explores the science of psychological assessment, including its history, test construction and evaluation, and common measures of personality, psychopathology, and ability. Students create and evaluate their own psychological measures.

subject: PSYCH
name: Cognitive Development
description: Cognitive development in infancy, childhood, and adolescence. Focus on theoretical explanations for cognitive change and development in core domains, including language, space, number, time, and social relations.

subject: PSYCH
name: Language and Cognition
description: Exposure to original research and theoretical perspectives on language and its relation to thought and behavior. Critical analysis of theories and methods. Topics may vary.

subject: PSYCH
name: Decision Making
description: Human decision making from both descriptive and prescriptive perspectives. Theories and models of decision making applied to a variety of contexts.

subject: PSYCH
name: Human Memory
description: Scientific study of human memory, including memory systems of the brain, amnesia, remembering, forgetting, encoding, consolidation, memory suppression, and memory distortion. Emphasizes original research reports in cognitive neuroscience.
prereq: PSYCH 205-0; PSYCH 328-0, PSYCH 378-0, or consent of instructor

subject: PSYCH
name: Images of Cognition
description: Study of brain processes underlying cognition. Analysis of brain structure and function. Introduction to imaging techniques including fMRI, PET, and ERP.
prereq: PSYCH 205-0; a course in cognition and/or neuroscience (e.g., PSYCH 221-0, PSYCH 228-0, PSYCH 320-0, PSYCH 328-0; COG_SCI 210-0) or consent of instructor

subject: PSYCH
name: Neuroscience & Behavior Laboratory
description: Classical exercises in the physiological psychology laboratory, including brainwave recording and electrophysiology.

subject: PSYCH
name: Advanced Statistics & Experimental Design
description: Advanced topics in research design and analysis of data. Focus on both theory and applications.

subject: PSYCH
name: Children & the Law
description: Examines from a developmental perspective research on children's involvement in the legal system as decision makers, witnesses, victims, and perpetrators. Taught with LEGAL_ST 381-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: PSYCH
name: Psychology and Food
description: Social, cultural, cognitive, evolutionary, and biological factors that influence food choice and consumption. Conducting and evaluating research on eating behavior. Students conduct original research.

subject: PSYCH
name: Consumer Psychology and Marketing Research
description: Application of psychological theories, findings, and methodologies to marketing research questions and problems. Students conduct a marketing research project for an actual client.

subject: PSYCH
name: Advanced Seminar in Personality, Clinical, or Social Psychology
description: Discussion and critical analysis of research methods and findings in an area of personality, clinical, and/or social psychology. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: PSYCH
name: Advanced Seminar in Cognition or Neuroscience
description: Discussion and critical analysis of research methods and findings in an area of cognitive psychology and/or neuroscience. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: PSYCH
name: Advanced Seminar in Psychology
description: Discussion and critical analysis of research methods and findings in psychology. Interdisciplinary focus, often spanning natural and social science aspects of psychology. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: PSYCH
name: Advanced Supervised Research 1
description: Design, implementation, and reporting of a psychology research project.
prereq: PSYCH 205-0 and consent of instructor; PSYCH 397-2 must be taken with the same professor as PSYCH 397-1. Weinberg College limits on 398 and 399 enrollments also apply to 397

subject: PSYCH
name: Advanced Supervised Research 2
description: Design, implementation, and reporting of a psychology research project.
prereq: PSYCH 205-0 and consent of instructor; PSYCH 397-2 must be taken with the same professor as PSYCH 397-1. Weinberg College limits on 398 and 399 enrollments also apply to 397

subject: PSYCH
name: Senior Thesis Seminar
description: Open only to students pursuing departmental honors. They must apply for admission in spring quarter of junior year.

subject: PSYCH
name: Senior Thesis Seminar
description: Open only to students pursuing departmental honors. They must apply for admission in spring quarter of junior year.

subject: PSYCH
name: Senior Thesis Seminar
description: Open only to students pursuing departmental honors. They must apply for admission in spring quarter of junior year.

subject: PSYCH
name: Independent Study
description: Consent of instructor required. Generally limited to juniors and seniors. See department requirements for eligibility.

subject: RTVF
name: Media Construction
description: Introduces the core components of media-idea, image, sound, and sequence- with the technical fundamentals involved in shooting and editing video. Students work with SLR and digital video cameras and with Photoshop and Final Cut Pro editing software, completing four projects in different genres during the quarter. Prerequisite for all upper-level production courses. Required for majors; typically taken in first year.

subject: RTVF
name: First-Year Topics Seminar
description: Beginning seminar focused around a special topic of media analysis, history, or theory. Students will learn research, analytic, and writing skills while focusing on issues relevant to film, media and/or digital arts and culture.

subject: RTVF
name: Analyzing Media Texts
description: Introduction to the study of the moving image. Basic elements of style across media including film, television, and interactive media. Focus on close analysis of texts to find significance. Prerequisite for upper level courses in the department. Required for majors; typically taken in first year.

subject: RTVF
name: Foundations of Screenwriting
description: Introduction to writing for the screen (film, television, and/or computer). Structure, character, dialogue, format, voice, scope, pace, context. Lecture/workshop. Prerequisite for upper-level writing courses in the department.

subject: RTVF
name: Studies in Media Topics
description: Theoretical or practical or both; emphasis on evolving trends.

subject: RTVF
name: Television History
description: Political, cultural, social, and industrial history of television, from the classic network era to the post-network contemporary period of media convergence. Exploration of programs as well as major events and shifts in television history.

subject: RTVF
name: History of Film I
description: International survey of motion pictures as a distinctive medium of expression from its prehistory to the present.

subject: RTVF
name: History of Film II
description: International survey of motion pictures as a distinctive medium of expression from its prehistory to the present.

subject: RTVF
name: Doc Film History & Criticism
description: Survey of the schools, styles, and purposes of documentary film as a unique form of artistic expression and sociopolitical persuasion.

subject: RTVF
name: Documentary Film & Video
description: Contemporary work and issues in documentary film and video.

subject: RTVF
name: History of the Recording Industry
description: Exploration of the history of the recording industry from the invention of the phonograph in 1877 to recent developments in digital audio.

subject: RTVF
name: Audio Drama
description: Introduction to masterpieces of audio and radio drama in three historical periods: classic American (1937-54); mid-century British (1954-1974) and contemporary global traditions.

subject: RTVF
name: Media and Cultural Theory
description: Introduction to the critical analysis of film, television, and other popular media by surveying influential theories of media, culture, and power.

subject: RTVF
name: Radio/Tv/Film Authorship
description: Idea of authorship in the media and an examination of different uses of author theory related to the work of particular artists.

subject: RTVF
name: Radio/Television/Film Genre
description: Concept of genre in the media, with reference to popular American forms.

subject: RTVF
name: Film, Media & Gender
description: Explores issues of gender in film and media. Introduces students to major debates and theories regarding gender and sexuality in the media.

subject: RTVF
name: Film & TV Criticism
description: Contemporary critical methods applied to film and/or television. Students read literature on critical methods and analysis and write critical analyses of films and television programs.

subject: RTVF
name: Culture Industries
description: Overview of business and social organization of film and television industry. Introduction to how media industries produce cultural products for local, national, and transnational audiences.

subject: RTVF
name: Technological Innovations
description: How technology develops and is assimilated into mass media.

subject: RTVF
name: History of Hollywood Cinema
description: Overview of the development of the classical Hollywood cinema, with particular emphasis on the 1920s through the early 1960s. Explores the relationship between industry practices and aesthetic features of classical narrative film genres.

subject: RTVF
name: National Cinema
description: Historical aspects of cinema in a culture outside the United States or a social/cultural/intellectual movement within cinema's general evolution.

subject: RTVF
name: Film, Media, and Globalization
description: Explores theories of media's role in the globalization of cultures. Examines transnational production, marketing, and reception of film, television, and/or digital media.

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Improv
description: In-depth study and practice of improv techniques and aesthetics. Sample topics include Intro to Improv, Improvising Characters, Writing and Performing Stand-up, Writing with Improv, Improvising the Text-based Collaborative Show, Improvised Comedy Web Series.

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Media Writing
description: Various approaches to screenwriting, emphasizing different modes and genres, such as the short film, the feature film, screenplays based on preexisting material, the teen film, interactive computer scenarios. May be repeated for credit, depending on the change in topic.

subject: RTVF
name: Writing the TV Pilot
description: Students will learn the craft of writing a television pilot in this small, workshop-based course.

subject: RTVF
name: Writing the Feature
description: Students will learn the craft of writing a feature film in this small, workshop-based course.

subject: RTVF
name: Writing the Adaptation
description: Students will learn the craft of writing an adaptation in this small, workshop-based course.

subject: RTVF
name: Introduction to Acting for the Screen
description: Foundational concerns and practices for screen acting. Scene analysis, rehearsal, staging and camera space, casting, editing for performance. Creating and portraying characters for most effective capture by the camera. Film directing techniques as related to the actor. Required introductory course for the Acting for Screen module sequence.

subject: RTVF
name: Diagnostic Scene Study
description: Retrospective critique of curricular and extracurricular performance work in the Acting for Screen module. Evaluation of performer's range and capabilities in terms of future projects and identity as an actor. Relationship between actor and director relative to the camera. Required course for the module.

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Acting for the Screen
description: Production-based courses on a range of practices and methods in acting for screen. May be repeated as topic varies. Counts as elective for the Acting for Screen module.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 for theatre majors; THEATRE 171-0 for RTVF majors; both courses for other School of Communication students

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Pre-Production
description: In-depth study of preproduction film, video, and media techniques and aesthetics. Sample topics include storyboarding, producing, and motion graphics.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Editing
description: The technique and art of editing for film. Topics include editing for continuity, controlling pace and rhythm, and editing nonlinear narratives.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Sound
description: In-depth study of sound techniques and aesthetics.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Cinematography
description: In-depth study of cinematography techniques and aesthetics.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Interactive Media
description: Exploration of the techniques and aesthetics of interactivity using various media.
prereq: RTVF 190-0, second-year standing (not through AP credits), and consent of instructor

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Non-fiction Media
description: In-depth study of nonfiction media techniques and aesthetics.
prereq: 190 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Post-Production
description: In-depth study of postproduction film, video, and media techniques and aesthetics. Sample topics include color correction, special-effects cinematography, and finishing.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Topics in Film/Video/Audio Production
description: In-depth study and practice of one area of film, video, or television. May be taken more than once for credit, depending on changes in topic.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Lighting and Cinematography
description: Techniques, aesthetics, and technologies of lighting and camera skills, including film and video.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Introduction to Sound Production
description: Introduction to the theories and principles of basic sound production. Demos, lectures, readings, screenings, and exercises cover all basics of sound recording technology.

subject: RTVF
name: Introduction to Sound Postproduction
description: Introduction to the theories and principles of basic sound production. Demos, lectures, readings, screenings, and exercises cover all basics of sound recording technology.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Practicum in RTVF Research
description: Collaboration with a faculty member on design and execution of a media research project. Students learn how to construct and complete a research project and document results. Requires a paper or other form of work product as determined by the faculty member.

subject: RTVF
name: Directing
description: Single-camera dramatic directing, including visualization and breakdown of scripts, camera blocking, and working with actors.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Documentary Production
description: Students examine documentary practices and produce their own shorts.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: 2D Computer Animation
description: Animation techniques in the 2-D sphere and incorporation of visual design principles.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Experimental Media Production
description: Creation of an experimental work as a linear film or video, an interactive website, an installation, a game, or a multidisciplinary performance.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Computer Animation: 3D
description: The fundamental concepts and techniques of 3-D computer modeling and animation. Use of concepts acquired in camera-based production techniques to create a rendered animation.
prereq: RTVF 190-0 and second-year standing (not through AP credits)

subject: RTVF
name: Advanced Directing I
description: Two-quarter sequence for students creating advanced artistic production, with critique of work throughout the production and postproduction process; conceptual resources offered as needed. Students may work in any genre (documentary, narrative, experimental) and any medium. Admission based on portfolio of previous media work and proposal for project, including script and budget.

subject: RTVF
name: Advanced Directing II
description: Two-quarter sequence for students creating advanced artistic production, with critique of work throughout the production and postproduction process; conceptual resources offered as needed. Students may work in any genre (documentary, narrative, experimental) and any medium. Admission based on portfolio of previous media work and proposal for project, including script and budget.

subject: RTVF
name: Symposium: Issues in RTVF
description: Special issues and topics in the analysis of radio, television, film, and popular culture.

subject: RTVF
name: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite: consent of undergraduate dean after submission of petition.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Religion
description: Religion as it has appeared in the past and as humans continue to express it in their personal and social lives.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Religion, Media, and Culture
description: Integrating multimedia modes of learning and engaging students in skill-developing mediamaking assignments, this course offers undergraduates an introduction to studying the phenomena of religion in relationship to dynamics of media, society, and culture. No prerequisites required.

subject: RELIGION
name: Religion, Medicine & Suffering in the West
description: Examination of religious healing ceremonies and Christian perspectives on pain and suffering in light of the meaning of physical pain in people's everyday lives.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Hinduism
description: Unity and diversity of Hindu mythology, beliefs, and practices from ancient times to the present.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Buddhism
description: The Buddha's life and teachings, traditions that developed from these teachings, and systems of meditation, rituals, and ethics.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Hebrew Bible
description: Major genres of Old Testament literature. Basic theological views and the sociopolitical history of ancient Israel.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to the New Testament
description: Beginning, development, and content of the New Testament; its Jewish and Hellenistic environment.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Judaism
description: Main concepts in the theology of Judaism, main rituals and customs, and main institutions.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Christianity
description: Doctrine, worship, and institutions in the various branches of Christianity.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Islam
description: Principal beliefs and practices of Muslims set against the historic development of the faith.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Native American Religions
description: Diversity and common elements of Native American religious traditions; comparative study of sacred story, ritual, spiritual philosophy, and practice.

subject: RELIGION
name: American Religion, Ecology and Culture
description: The historical rise of environmentalism in American culture and its impact on religious thought and practice. ENVR_POL 261-0 and RELIGION 261-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: RELIGION
name: American Religious History from 1865 to the Great Depression
description: Topics include urban religion, African American churches, Christians and foreign policy, immigrant religion, the spiritual crisis of the 1920s, and Pentecostalism.

subject: RELIGION
name: American Religious History from World War II to the Present
description: Religion and the making of contemporary America, including Cold War religion, the Black Gods of the Great Migration, the rise of the Christian Right, and modern American Catholicism and Judaism.

subject: RELIGION
name: Introduction to Theology
description: Theology as an academic discipline with a long history of asking-in dialogue with thinkers past and present-fundamental questions about religious experience, texts, practices, and ideas.

subject: RELIGION
name: Theology of Love
description: The concept of love from theological, historical, philosophical, and biblical perspectives.

subject: RELIGION
name: Luther and the West
description: Examination of Luther's work in the context of his life and times. Introduces basic dimensions of Western thought, showing how theology relates to broader cultural, political, social, and aesthetic issues. GERMAN 272-0 and RELIGION 272-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: RELIGION
name: Mysticism and Spirituality
description: Examines mysticism (mystical experience, relationship, prayer, or consciousness) and spirituality (spiritual presence and practice) across religious traditions and outside traditions.

subject: RELIGION
name: Ahimsa: Nonviolence in South Asia and Beyond
description: Theory and practice of nonviolence in human action, taking into account ethics as well as efficacy. Emphasis on both spiritual and practical approaches to nonviolence and its usefulness in effecting spiritual development and social change.

subject: RELIGION
name: Hindu Epics: Mahābhārata
description: Immersion in the ancient Sanskrit epic in translation and modern retellings, focusing on classical Hindu myth and theology as well as issues of justice, war, gender, and violence.

subject: RELIGION
name: Hindu Epics: Rāmāyaṇa
description: Immersion in the ancient Sanskrit epic in translation and modern retellings, focusing on classical Hindu myth and theology as well as issues of justice, violence, gender, and love.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in Hinduism
description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Buddhism and Gender
description: Women, men, and gendered symbolism in Buddhism from the time of the Buddha to the present. Draws on canonical texts, narrative literature, autobiography and biography, and ethnography.

subject: RELIGION
name: Tibetan Religion and Culture
description: Propagation of religions in Tibet in their larger historical, cultural, and political contexts.

subject: RELIGION
name: Buddhism in the Contemporary World
description: An exploration of where, why, and how Buddhist practices, ideas, and iconography are spreading and being reinterpreted in the modern world.

subject: RELIGION
name: Buddhist Auto/biography
description: An exploration of Buddhist narratives of the self, including Sanskrit and Tibetan-language biographies and autobiographies in English translation, in conversation with literary theory.

subject: RELIGION
name: Religion and the Body in China
description: Explores the place of the body in Chinese religion, from the ancient period to the present day. Touches on dying and the afterlife, food and drink, health and medicine, gender and family, and other themes.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in East Asian Religions
description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in Buddhism
description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in the Bible
description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Varieties of Ancient Judaism
description: Introduction to the Judaisms that flourished from the fifth century BCE to the third century CE.

subject: RELIGION
name: Modern Jewish Thought
description: How Judaism dealt with modernity and the problems it posed: Spinoza, Mendelssohn, Cohen, Buber, Rosenzweig, and Levinas.

subject: RELIGION
name: Judaism in the Modern World
description: Radical changes that emancipation and modernity have brought to the religious expression of Judaism. May be repeated for credit.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in Judaism
description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Christian Mystical Theology
description: Writings of mystics (e.g., Meister Eckhart, Cloud of Unknowing, Julian of Norwich, Teresa of Avila) in their cultural context.

subject: RELIGION
name: Blood, Sex, and Justice: Issues in Christian Ethics
description: Four contemporary moral issues viewed from a variety of Christian approaches.

subject: RELIGION
name: Idea of Sainthood in Christianity
description: Historical and contemporary conceptions of sanctity, especially in Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy.

subject: RELIGION
name: Church Architecture
description: Survey of historical and recent churches: spatial dynamics, centering focus, aesthetic impact, and symbolic resonance.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in Christianity
description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: The Qur'an
description: Islam's sacred scripture, Muslim understandings of revelation and prophecy, and debates about the Qur'an in the contemporary world.

subject: RELIGION
name: Islamic Law
description: Evolution of Islamic Law from the Prophet Muhammad to the contemporary world, focusing on the impact of colonialism.

subject: RELIGION
name: Trends in Islamic Thought
description: Qur'anic, medieval, and modern approaches to problems in faith and social action.

subject: RELIGION
name: Sufism
description: The historical development of Islamic mystical traditions, with special attention to notions of mystical experience, sainthood, and devotion to the Prophet Muhammad.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in Islam
description: Selected topics in Islamic history and thought. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in Islam
description: Selected topics in Islamic history and thought. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: African American Religions
description: Exploration of the historical diversity of African American religious experiences and identities.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in Women and Religion in America
description: Topics, figures, events, and dynamics in the history of American women and religion.

subject: RELIGION
name: American Teenage Rites of Passage
description: Examination of various rites of passage experienced by US teens.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in American Religion
description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Religion and Film
