description: Content varies (e.g., films of Robert Bresson; Kieslowski's Decalogue; Dreyer and Tarkovsky). May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Religion and Bioethics
description: Analysis of contemporary dilemmas in medicine and the life sciences; responses to these dilemmas from religious perspectives.

subject: RELIGION
name: Contemporary Religious Thought
description: Content varies (e.g., convergence between religious paths, science and religion, politics and religion). May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Foundations of Christian Thought
description: Christian interpretations of salvation, Christ, and God, from Augustine to Julian of Norwich.

subject: RELIGION
name: Christianity and the Making of Modernity
description: Role of Christian thought in shaping the turbulent history of the West from the 16th to the late-18th centuries. Christianity's engagement with local and global events, from reformation to revolution, reason to romanticism.

subject: RELIGION
name: Christian Thought in Global Perspective
description: Globalization of Christian thought in the 19th-21st centuries, considering religious differences, colonialism, war, and democracy. Approaches to theology in Asia, Latin America, and Africa.

subject: RELIGION
name: Death: Myth and Meaning
description: Ideas, beliefs, and practices pertaining to death from a variety of ancient and modern cultures. Immortality, afterlife, care for the dying, suicide, funerary rituals, transhumanism.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in Comparative Religion
description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: RELIGION
name: Global Catholicism in the Contemporary World
description: Historical and contemporary global Catholicism. Topics include the church and political modernity; local saints; controversies over worship styles; Catholics and political revolutions; the Vatican; the pontificate of John Paul II.

subject: RELIGION
name: Catholicism & Making of the Modern World
description: 16th-17th century Catholic influences on missions, colonial ventures, science, and the development of non-European history; the effects of these efforts upon Catholicism's understanding of itself and early "global culture."

subject: RELIGION
name: Catholic Social Ethics
description: Ecclesiastical, academic, and popular Catholic social ethics from 1891 to the present-for example, the living wage and Catholic Worker movements, peace initiatives, liberation ethics, and immigration, environment, sexuality, and gender issues.

subject: RELIGION
name: Soundings in the Catholic Tradition
description: Topics in Catholic religious thought or religious movements. May be taken multiple times with different content.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in United States Catholicism
description: Historical and contemporary subjects in the study of Catholic culture in the United States. May be taken multiple times with different content.

subject: RELIGION
name: Topics in Latin America Catholicism
description: Historical and contemporary subjects in the study of Catholic culture in Latin America. May be taken multiple times with different content.

subject: RELIGION
name: Theories of Religion
description: Ways of critically analyzing religious experience and its meaning. Phenomenology of religion, history of religions, comparative religions. For majors only.

subject: RELIGION
name: Senior Seminar
description: For honors students writing the senior thesis.

subject: RELIGION
name: Senior Seminar
description: For honors students writing the senior thesis.

subject: RELIGION
name: Independent Study
description: Reading and conferences on special subjects for advanced students. Consent of instructor required.

subject: RUSSIAN

subject: RUSSIAN
name: Elementary Russian (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 101-3)

subject: RUSSIAN
name: Intermediate Russian (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 102-1)

subject: RUSSIAN

description: Russian language and culture. Reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

subject: RUSSIAN
name: Intermediate Russian (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 102-3)
description: Russian language and culture. Reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

prereq: RUSSIAN 102-3 or consent of language director

prereq: RUSSIAN 102-3 or consent of language director

subject: RUSSIAN
name: Advanced Russian in Conversations (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 302-3)
description: Conversation, listening comprehension, reading, and com-position. Contemporary readings on Russian culture and society. Combined third-and fourth-year multi-skill course.
prereq: RUSSIAN 102-3 or consent of language director

subject: RUSSIAN
name: Advanced Russian Language and Culture (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 303-1: Modern Russian reading
description: Conversation, listening comprehension, reading, and composition. Exploration of modern Russian language and culture through readings, video, and film. Combined third-and fourth-year multi-skill course.
prereq: RUSSIAN 102-3 or consent of language director

name: Advanced Russian Language and Culture (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 303-2: Modern Russian reading)

description: Conversation, listening comprehension, reading, and composition. Exploration of modern Russian language and culture through readings, video, and film. Combined third-and fourth-year multi-skill course.
prereq: RUSSIAN 102-3 or consent of language director

subject: RUSSIAN
name: Adv Contemp Russian
description: Russian for advanced speakers, including heritage speakers. Stress on skills in speaking, reading, and writing in professional and formal environments. Taught entirely in Russian.

subject: RUSSIAN
name: Adv Contemp Russian
description: Russian for advanced speakers, including heritage speakers. Stress on skills in speaking, reading, and writing in professional and formal environments.

subject: RUSSIAN
name: Russian Prose (Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 359-1 or 359-2)
description: Selected works of Russian masters. Lecture, readings and discussion in Russian. Russian modernist prose, socialist realism and 1940s to the present. Content varies. May be repeated for credit.

subject: SESP
name: Community Engagement
description: Critical reflection on community service experiences in relation to broader societal issues. Conceptual frameworks for understanding the meaning and nature of community. For Civic Engagement Certificate students only.

subject: SESP
name: Understanding Knowledge
description: N/A.

subject: SESP
name: Human Development: Childhood and Adolescence
description: Personal, social, and cognitive development from birth through adolescence. Interplay of biological and experiential factors on linguistic and conceptual development, ego, and personality.

subject: SESP
name: Introduction to Community Development
description: Historical and contemporary community-building efforts, focusing on Chicago's neighborhoods. Community development strategies: the settlement house, community organizing, and community economic development.

subject: SESP
name: Human Development: Adulthood and Aging
description: Psychological, sociological, and biological factors influencing socialization and development from young and middle adulthood through old age. Influences of family, school, and work on the individual.

subject: SESP
name: Designing for Social Change
description: Processes, challenges, and ethics of designing programs, at home and abroad, for realizing human rights and meaningful social change.

subject: SESP
name: Introduction to Statistics and Research Methodology
description: Definitions and classifications of terms used in quantitative methods; measures of typical and maximum performance, reliability, and validity checks; reporting and displaying data; interpreting results.

subject: SESP
name: Leaders Lab
description: N/A.

subject: SESP
name: Community Based Research Methods
description: N/A.

subject: SESP
name: Field Research Methods
description: Guided practice in systematic and participant observation. Observer bias, field notes, unobtrusive measures.

subject: SESP
name: Peer-Led Learning: Theory and Practice
description: SESP 291 is the training program for students working as first-time mentors in the Peer Leaders program. It is taken over two academic quarters, with each quarter offering .25 credit (a total of .5 credit). You will receive a "K" grade for fall quarter, which means you are continuing in the course. After winter quarter, you will receive a letter grade which will be retroactively applied to fall quarter.

subject: SESP
name: Theory and Practice of Community Consulting
description: Course on the importance of community capacity building and the community-consulting process; start of preliminary work for the Certificate in Civic Engagement capstone project.

subject: SESP
name: Student Organized Seminar
description: Courses proposed by students and supervised by faculty sponsors on special topics approved by the SESP undergraduate education director. May be taken only once per quarter; pass/no credit only. Consultation with the SESP student affairs assistant dean advised.

subject: SESP
name: Civic Engagement Capstone Research
description: Independent study courses leading to completion of the Certificate in Civic Engagement capstone project.

subject: SESP
name: Certificate in Civic Engagement- Capstone Project
description: Independent study courses leading to completion of the Certificate in Civic Engagement capstone project.

subject: SESP
name: Methods for Causal Inference
description: N/A.

subject: SESP
name: Gender and the Life Course
description: How gender influences major life stages. Focus on the psychosocial effects of gender on children; young, midlife, and old adults; societal institutions; and selected social policy issues.

subject: SESP
name: Race and Education
description: Conceptual underpinnings of the construct of race and how conceptions of race have influenced the course of education in the United States.

subject: SESP
name: Crafting Child Policy
description: N/A.

subject: SESP
name: Trauma and Atrocity: Holocaust Memory, Memorials and Museums:
description: N/A.

subject: SESP
name: Pedagogies for History and Injustice: Holocaust Education Design
description: N/A.

subject: SESP
name: Race, Adolescence, and School Discipline
description: In recent years, racial disparities in school discipline have attracted the attention of educators, policymakers, parents, and the general public. Why is it so hard for legal, political, and educational institutions to improve school discipline? How do intersections of race, gender, and social class matter for students' experiences of school discipline? Are there schools that are getting discipline right? What does that look like, and to what extent can other schools learn from their successes? In this course, we will learn about evidence-based policy improvements and imagine how to create schools where race does not predict discipline.

subject: SESP
name: Special Topics
description: Advanced work on special topics.

subject: SESP
name: Special Topics
description: Advanced work on special topics. This course is limited to students approved to study abroad through the Global Learning Office (GLO).

subject: SESP
name: Practicum in Human Development; Learning Sciences
description: Real-world participant observation in professional activities and projects; development of analytical field studies of the practicum experience based on field notes, recorded observations, and class discussions; culminates in a final research paper.
prereq: SESP 272-0; consent of SESP practicum director 2 quarters before registration (3 quarters if a Summer Session practicum). For LRN SCI students only

subject: SESP
name: Practicum in Human Development - Washington, D.C.
description: See description for SESP 382-0. Offered during Summer Session only.
prereq: SESP 272-0; consent of SESP practicum director 3 quarters before registration. For participants in the Washington, DC, field studies program only

subject: SESP
name: Practicum: Human Development & Psychological Svcs.
description: See description and prerequisites for SESP 382-0. For HDC students only.

subject: SESP
name: Practicum: Learning& Organizational Change
description: See description and prerequisites for SESP 382-0. For LOC students only.

subject: SESP
name: Practicum: Social Policy
description: See description and prerequisites for SESP 382-0. For SOC POL students only.

subject: SESP
name: Practicum in Human Development - San Francisco
description: See description and prerequisites for SESP 382-0. Offered during Summer Session only. For participants in the San Francisco field studies program only.

subject: SESP
name: Research Apprenticeship
description: Opportunity to participate in faculty research projects.
prereq: consent of the faculty member and the SESP assistant dean for student affairs; submission of completed Request for Independent Study/Special Courses Form at registration

subject: SESP
name: Advanced Research Design
description: Overview of research methods that may be used to design and implement the honors thesis.

subject: SESP

description: Students develop, design, implement, and evaluate a research project under a faculty advisor's guidance.
prereq: senior status, cumulative GPA by the end winter quarter of the junior year, recommendation for the honors program from SESP 391-0 instructor(s); consent of program director

subject: SESP

prereq: consent of the supervising faculty member(s) and the SESP assistant dean for student affairs; submission of completed Request for Independent Study/Special Courses Form at registration

subject: SHC

description: For students who wish to qualify for honors by writing a senior thesis.

subject: SHC
name: Science in Human Culture Senior Seminar
description: For students who wish to qualify for honors by writing a senior thesis.

subject: SHC
name: Science in Human Culture Senior Seminar
description: For students who wish to qualify for honors by writing a senior thesis.

subject: DSGN
name: Design Thinking and Communication
description: Integrated introduction to the user-centered design process and technical communication. Students will address current challenges experienced by project partners. This course will guide students through identifying unmet needs, conducting research, generating and evaluating potential solutions, presenting a final design concept with supporting justification and documentation for design decisions. Students will also enhance their abilities of contributing to an equitable team, project management, fabrication skills, and producing written, oral, graphical, and interpersonal communication. One lecture, two section meetings, and lab. Co-registration with ENGLISH 106-1 required. Primarily intended for first-year engineering students.

subject: DSGN
name: Design Thinking and Communication
description: Integrated iteration on the user-centered design process and technical communication. This course will build on the learning objectives from DTC-1 while adding more focus on ethics in design and communication, equitable distribution of teamwork, project management, documenting and communicating progress, and exploring a wider variety of project topics. One lecture, two section meetings, and lab. Co-registration with ENGLISH 106-2 required. Primarily intended for first-year engineering students.

subject: DSGN
name: Design Thinking and Doing
description: Project-based introduction to design, structured as a hands-on studio course. Students learn methods of design innovation and work in teams, exploring ideas, prototyping solutions, and interacting with users. Intended for non-McCormick students.
prereq: Reserved for First-Year Students, Sophomores, and Juniors

subject: DSGN
name: Introduction to Design Sketching
description: Design sketching to increase one's skills as a basic but essential form of communication. It is the medium for preliminary ideation. Basic rules and skills in a design studio setting.

subject: DSGN
name: Advanced Sketching
description: Advanced sketching techniques. Further development of skills for the design studio setting.

subject: DSGN
name: Introduction to Solid Modeling: Solidworks
description: Solid modeling by creating three-dimensional shapes through two-dimensional sketches. Assemblies of individual parts. CAD modeling theory; modeling objects using different approaches for creating identical features. Lecture balanced with hands-on use of SolidWorks.

subject: DSGN
name: Visual Thinking for Design
description: Often times when we confront a new problem space we choose to build up our understanding through research, readings and lectures. Visual Thinking for Design will focus upon complementing this understanding through the use of visual stimulus. We will work with visual thinking methods to help expand our understanding of a problem space resulting in a greater generation of ideas and a more tangible organization of our thoughts. No formal prerequisites. DSGN 220-0, Intro to Sketching, and some experience with Adobe Photoshop would be helpful but not necessary.

subject: DSGN
name: Introductory Topics in Design
description: Topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the institute; taught at an intermediate level.

subject: DSGN
name: Intermediate Topics in Engineering Design
description: Topics suggested by students and faculty and approved by the institute.

subject: DSGN
name: Designing Your Life
description: The course will approach life as a series of design projects to help students craft a total life. It includes seminar-style discussions, role-playing, short writing assignments, hands-on making, guest speakers, and individual mentoring and coaching.

subject: DSGN
name: Human-Centered Service Design
description: This is a project-based course for students interested in a human-centered design approach to service design. Outcomes may include organizational structures, new service designs, and possibly designed products to support the service.will Design of new or improved services that tap deeply into people's needs for connectedness, belonging, and autonomy. Project outcomes may include organizational structures, service designs, and designed products.

subject: DSGN
name: UX Design
description: Hands-on course covering the full range of user experience design, from screen-based experience to interaction with physical products to end-to-end environment design.

subject: DSGN
name: Human-Centered Product Design
description: Project-based course focusing on user needs: observational methods, brainstorming, prototyping, business models, and the social and engineering concerns for product design.

subject: DSGN
name: Design, Technology, and Research
description: Design, Technology, and Research (DTR) is an CS and Segal learning initiative that empowers students to drive cutting-edge research through the development of systems that shape new experiences with people and technology. Students participate in DTR through fast-paced, quarter-long programs (intended to be repeated). Students work with a mentor to identify a direction of research, explore and iterate over designs, prototype at varying fidelities, build working systems, conduct evaluative studies, and report findings through conference publications. As a cohort, each week students demo their prototypes, provide and receive feedback, and help each other resolve technical challenges. DTR adapts and extends agile development and design-based research practices with scrums, sprints, studio critique, design logs, and pair research.

subject: DSGN
name: Introduction to Industrial Design Methods
description: Process of product development from an industrial design perspective.

subject: DSGN
name: Advanced Solid Modeling
description: This course provides advanced instruction on the use of CAD modeling using Solidworks software.

subject: DSGN
name: Rendering
description: This course provides an introduction to Keyshot software, a photorealistic rendering package.
prereq: DSGN 240-0 or MECH_ENG 240-0; or consent of instructor

subject: DSGN
name: Computer-Aided Manufacturing
description: Course Overview: Computer Aided Manufacturing will teach the NX manufacturing environment to program machining operations for CNC milling, as well as the operation of CNC milling machines. Students will learn the basics of NX manufacturing, various manufacturing steps such as operations, tools, and geometry, and the generation of g-code to machine a part. The class will then transition to machine shop lessons, where students will be taught safe operation of CNC milling centers. The goal of the class is to teach the complete path from part design to manufacturing setup and g-code generation, to proper machine operation and part manufacturing. Remote Learning Quarters: Each student enrolled will be provided with a small CNC milling center to be operated at home, using materials and tools provided to them. New curriculum will focus on the programming and operation of 2.5D cutting, machine setup, troubleshooting, and optimization of the CNC machine.
prereq: DSGN 106-1 and DSGN 106-2 and one of the following: DSGN 240-0, DSGN 245-0, or MECH_ENG 240-0

subject: DSGN
name: Manufacturing Methods for Product Design
description: Who takes it: DSGN 346 is taken by MaDE undergraduate students. MaDE students may petition for this course to count in place of the of the ME 340-1 degree requirement. Description: Design for fabrication is an introduction to manufacturing processes including casting, injection molding, additive manufacturing, extrusion, machining, joining, and forming, using materials commonly found in modern consumer and industrial products. Online lectures will be paired with weekly, hands-on labs where students will be able to apply theory of manufacturing processes to the design of parts and process tooling for various fabrication methods. Focus will be placed on the exploration of part design and process parameters, to obtain an optimal outcome for a given manufacturing process. Students will become proficient in both the advantages and limitations of various fabrication methods, in order to better prepare them for the design of a component and implementation into a production line.
prereq: DSGN 106-1 and DSGN 106-2 and one of the following: DSGN 240-0, MECH_ENG 240-0, or DSGN 245-0, or instructor approval of previous CAD experience

subject: DSGN
name: Rapid Prototyping
description: Course Overview: DSGN 348 will cover the field of additive manufacturing methods, and instruct students on the operation of equipment in the Northwestern Rapid Prototyping lab. Students will review the fundamentals and theory behind rapid prototyping methods, different methods and materials used, applications of rapid prototyping technology, advanced CAD modeling, and reverse engineering methods. The course will include lab work, where students will learn the operation of additive manufacturing machines, laser scanners, and CAD surfacing software. Students completing this class will be qualified to operate all RP lab equipment, and be proficient at advanced reverse engineering and RP software. Remote Learning Quarters: Each student enrolled will be provided with a 3D printer and printing material to use at home, with coursework exploring the setup, troubleshooting, and optimization of extrusion-based printing.
prereq: DSGN 240-0 or DSGN 245-0, MECH_ENG 240-0, or approval of instructor

subject: DSGN
name: Intellectual Property and Innovation
description: The course will explore the critical role of designers, business strategists and engineers in the invention/creative process. It is open to non STEM students as well. DSGN 350 will enlighten students through narrative case study examples each class to the process and practice of protecting your creations with intellectual property strategies.

subject: DSGN
name: Design Competition
description: Undergraduate teams compete in McCormick's annual autonomous robot contest. Work begins winter quarter; teams must pass a qualifying milestone to register for credit in spring quarter. Students may register for this course no more than twice.

subject: DSGN
name: Portfolio Development & Presentation
description: Creation of design projects that showcase engineering work and further career goals. The portfolio physically presents a story that embodies its creator's goals.

subject: DSGN
name: Data as Art
description: Information visualization across multiple disciplines.

subject: DSGN
name: Industrial Design Projects I
description: Design thinking; user-centric principles of design and DFM. Indus-trial design project for personal portfolio development. Concept ideation and sketching; use of discovery research and data visualization; problem framing and prototyping; design for manufacturing, Keyshot rendering, rapid prototyping. Pt 1 in two-course sequence.
prereq: DSGN 243-0 and either DSGN 240-0 or MECH_ENG 240-0 and either DSGN 220-0 or DSGN 320-0; or consent of the instructor. Reserved for Juniors and Seniors

subject: DSGN
name: Industrial Design Projects II
description: Design thinking; user-centric principles of design and DFM. Indus-trial design project for personal portfolio development. Concept ideation and sketching; use of discovery research and data visualization; problem framing and prototyping; design for manufacturing, Keyshot rendering, rapid prototyping.

subject: DSGN
name: Service Design Studio I
description: This course explores the human centered approach to the design of services. Students will explore and apply design thinking to client sponsored projects and synthesize both user and client needs to the design of tangible consumer touch points. This includes experiences plans, digital interface designs, communication models, organizational designs, systems and/or brand tonality deliverables. Pt 1 in two-course sequence.
prereq: DSGN 305-0 or DSGN 306-0 or DSGN 308-0; or consent of instructor. Reserved for Juniors and Seniors

subject: DSGN
name: Service Design Studio II
description: This course explores the human centered approach to the design of services. Students will explore and apply design thinking to client sponsored projects and synthesize both user and client needs to the design of tangible consumer touch points. This may include experiences plans, digital interface designs, communication models, organizational designs, systems and/or brand tonality deliverables.

subject: DSGN
name: Interdisciplinary Product Design Projects I
description: Open-ended, team-based product or system design projects in real-world settings. Sequence must be taken in consecutive quarters. Project research, concept development, professional communication, advanced topics in design. One of DSGN 305-0, DSGN 306-0, or DSGN 308-0 is recommended before taking this course. Pt 1 in two-course sequence.
prereq: DSGN 106-1 or DSGN 208-0. Reserved for Juniors and Seniors

subject: DSGN
name: Interdisciplinary Product Design Projects II
description: Open-ended, team-based product or system design projects in real-world settings. Sequence must be taken in consecutive quarters. Implementation, evaluation, communication, documentation.

subject: DSGN
name: Manufacturing Engineering Design
description: Hands-on design project course addressing LEAN manufacturing engineering design topics, such as DFA (design for assembly), DFM (design for manufacturing), automation, quality control, process planning, tooling design, concurrent engineering, and continuous improvement. In this course you are not challenged to design a new product, but you are given all the components of an existing proudct and you design the manufacutring specifications, and process. Design strategy, manufacturring modeling and optimization, engineering documentation, quality control, manufacuring costing and product manufacturing productivity skills are put into practice in the final pilot run of the manufactring process by each team.
prereq: MECH_ENG 240-0, or consent of instructor. Reserved for Juniors and Seniors

subject: DSGN
name: Special Topics
description: Topics relevant to design engineering and approved by the institute.

subject: DSGN
name: Advanced Topics in Design
description: Topics suggested by students and faculty and approved by the institute.

subject: DSGN
name: Independent Study Project
description: Independent study on a manufacturing engineering topic supervised by a faculty member.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Elementary Czech
description: Czech language and culture. Basic reading, writing, listening, and speaking. No prerequisite.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Introduction to Russian Literature
description: Comprehensive overview of the central prose works and literary movements in 19th-century Russia. 1. Thematic and formal study of major works by Pushkin, Gogol, Lermontov, Turgenev. 2. Tolstoy, Dostoevsky. 3. Turgenev, the late Tolstoy, Chekhov, Bunin.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Introduction to Russian Literature
description: Comprehensive overview of the central prose works and literary movements in 19th-century Russia. 1. Thematic and formal study of major works by Pushkin, Gogol, Lermontov, Turgenev. 2. Tolstoy, Dostoevsky. 3. Turgenev, the late Tolstoy, Chekhov, Bunin.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Introduction to Russian Literature
description: Comprehensive overview of the central prose works and literary movements in 19th-century Russia. 1. Thematic and formal study of major works by Pushkin, Gogol, Lermontov, Turgenev. 2. Tolstoy, Dostoevsky. 3. Turgenev, the late Tolstoy, Chekhov, Bunin.

subject: SLAVIC
name: 20th-Century Russian Literature
description: Major works in cultural-historical context, from the revolutions of 1917 through the present. Variable content depending on instructor. Focus on one of the following: Russian modernism in literature, music, film, and visual art; non-conformism in Soviet literature and visual arts (1940s to 1986); and contemporary Russian culture.

subject: SLAVIC
name: 20th-Century Russian Literature
description: Major works in cultural-historical context, from the revolutions of 1917 through the present. Variable content depending on instructor. Russian literature, film, and visual art in the transition from communism to post-communism. Writers examined may include Pasternak, Bulgakov, Solzhenitsyn, and Sinyavsky/Tertz.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Language, Politics, & Identity
description: Role of language in constructing, preserving, and manipulating political and national identities. Topics include language discrimination, linguistic nationalism, language and religion, alphabet issues, dialect issues. Regional content varies. LING 222-0 and SLAVIC 222-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Slavic Civilizations
description: Culture, history, language, and literature of the Slavs historically and/or in modern periods. Content varies with instructor; may be repeated for credit.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Slavic Civilizations
description: Culture, history, language, and literature of the Slavs historically and/or in modern periods. Content varies with instructor; may be repeated for credit. Restricted to students participating in NU-Sponsored study abroad programs.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Economics and the Humanities: Understanding Choice
description: A conversation among disciplines, especially economics and literary studies. Explores social, ethical, and political big questions.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Heart of Europe: Poland in the Twentieth Century
description: Study of key developments in Polish history, literature, and thought by way of texts drawn from literature, history, politics, journalism, memoirs, essays, and film. Poland as a microcosm for recent European history and culture.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Czech Culture: Film, Visual Arts & Music
description: Czech culture represented in film and visual arts.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Visual Art in the Context of Russian Culture
description: Introduction to the history of Russian art: survey of major trends in Russian visual art in the dual contexts of Russian culture and European visual art. Focus on interconnections among visual arts, literature, and political history. Russian art from the medieval period to the beginning of the 20th century.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Visual Art in the Context of Russian Culture
description: Introduction to the history of Russian art: survey of major trends in Russian visual art in the dual contexts of Russian culture and European visual art. Focus on interconnections among visual arts, literature, and political history. Russian art of the 20th century.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Tolstoy
description: This course is devoted to a careful consideration of one book, Tolstoy's War and Peace, as we come to appreciate why it is often considered the world's greatest novel.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Dostoevsky
description: Introduction to Dostoevsky's life and works: Notes from the Underground, Crime and Punishment, Brothers Karamazov.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Chekhov
description: Introduction to the fiction and plays of Anton Chekhov, father of the modern short story. His writing in its Russian cultural context and his influence on English-language drama, fiction, and film. Readings include The Cherry Orchard, The Seagull, Uncle Vania, and short stories.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Making a Dictionary: The Northwestern Project
description: Creation of an online dictionary of Northwestern language. Learning about the connection between language, society, and identity; sociolinguistic fieldwork; lexicography; politics of dictionaries. LING 363-0 and SLAVIC 322-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Structure of Modern Russian
description: Theories and methods of linguistics as applied to the description of modern Russian. Phonetics, morphology, and other topics.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Survey of 19th Century Russian Poetry
description: Introduction to the wealth of Russian 19th century lyric poetry and basic techniques for its study: Pushkin, Baratynsky, Lermontov, Tyutchev, Fet.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Survey of 20th Century Russian Poetry
description: Introduction to the major currents of Russian 20thcentury lyric poetry and basic techniques for its study: Tsvetaeva, Mayakovsky, Khlebnikov, Blok, Akhmatova, Mandelshtam, Pasternak, Brodsky.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Russian Film
description: Development of Russian film and film theory from the silent era to the 1980s. Golden Age of Russian cinema (Eisenstein, Pudovkin, Vertov, Protazanov, Vasiliev brothers, Dovzhenko, socialist realism).

subject: SLAVIC
name: Russian Film
description: Development of Russian film and film theory from the silent era to the 1980s. Russian film since World War II (more socialist realism, neorealism, Tarkovsky, Mikhalkov, Paradjanov, Abuladze; criticism and semiotic theory).

subject: SLAVIC
name: Andrei Tarkovsky's Aesthetics and World Cinema
description: Major films of Tarkovsky and of Russian and non-Russian directors whose work is related to his (Eisenstein, Wenders, Bergman, Kurosawa).

subject: SLAVIC
name: 200 Years of Russian Drama
description: Dramatic traditions of Russia from the 19th century through Russian modernism to contemporary theater. Dramas by Gogol, Ostrovsky, Gorky, Chekhov, Blok, Mayakovsky, and others.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Literature and Politics in Central and Eastern Europe
description: Literature has played a central role in defining the political agendas in central and eastern Europe. Course concerns the interaction of literature with cultural and political history. Content varies. May be repeated for credit.

subject: SLAVIC
name: East European Literature and Visual Arts
description: Postwar film and visual arts of the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, and the former Yugoslavia; national identity, dissidence, and literary postmodernism. Content varies; may be repeated for credit.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Prague: City of Cultures, City of Conflict
description: Examination of the cultural, political, and social transformation of Prague from the 19th century to the present. Cosmopolitan Prague, communist Prague, and capitalist Prague.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Topics in Literature and Arts
description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Independent Study
description: For majors selected as candidates for departmental honors; for other advanced students with consent of instructor.

subject: SLAVIC
name: Independent Study
description: For majors selected as candidates for departmental honors; for other advanced students with consent of instructor.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Introduction to Social Policy
description: Social policy formulation: the substance of major American social policies, the agenda-setting process, and how the political system shapes social policy in this country.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Social Policy & the Human Services
description: Development of social policy for human services in the United States. Human service policies for education, mental health, physical health, prisons, income, and aging.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Law and Social Policy
description: Use and influence of the legal system in and on social institutions and policy.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Educational Policy
description: Conflict between societal imperatives to select and prepare young people for future careers and to offer youths opportunity; how society and schools address this conflict; various approaches to policy reform.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Legal Aspects of Education
description: School governance structure and decision making; relevant state and federal legislation; role of the US Supreme Court in affecting public schooling.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Social Policy and the United States Health Care System
description: Examines the health care delivery system in the United States through a review of US health policy issues.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Social Policymaking and Implementation
description: Examines the process by which social policies are made, the process and realities of their implementation, and the attendant politics.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Race, Inequality, and the Political Analysis of Public Policy
description: The purpose of this course is to make you a better political analyst. This course will familiarize you with substantive research on politics that has concrete insights for reformers, political advocates, and other public policy stakeholders. The class will cover substantive issues in politics along with how they intersect with class, race, gender and partisanship. While the main focus of the course is to discuss critical issues, there will also be an emphasis on public policy and political science writing formats, styles and standards. It cannot be emphasized enough how important research, analytic and writing skills are to virtually all careers; nothing is more quickly discrediting of good ideas than bad writing. The first half of class is mainly lecture and discussion. The second half of class has been designed to promote your learning as a writer and thinker in public policy. It will provide students with a designated forum for developing and “work shopping” their written work and discussing issues covered in class. The TA will offer feedback on questions as students write, edit, and revise their papers. We will also frequently practice skills in responding critically to colleagues’ texts. One or more quizzes may be administered as well.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Economics of Social Policy
description: Economic concepts and empirical tools to analyze the design and effects of social policies. Topics include the social safety net, health insurance, minimum wage, and taxation. Pre-Requisites are Econ 281 and Econ 310-1 or SESP 310 for SESP students.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Economics of Inequality and Discrimination
description: Economic concepts and empirical tools to analyze the causes and consequences of inequality and discrimination. Topics include housing policy, crime, earnings inequality, and the role of education.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Economics of Education Policy
description: Economic concepts and empirical tools to analyze the design and effects of education policies, including school choice, accountability, education finance, class size policy, and teacher compensation and retention.

subject: SOC_POL
name: Economics of Health, Human Capital, and Happiness
description: Understanding causal relationships is a central goal in social science and science in general. Correlations help to predict outcomes, but if we want to influence outcomes we need to understand causal pathways. It is not sufficient to observe what is happening, we need to know why it is happening. In this course students will learn the toolbox of causal inference econometrics with applications to the economics of health, human capital, and subjective wellbeing. The empirical methods we will cover include multivariate regressions, panel data, difference-indifference designs, instrumental variables, randomized control trials, and regression discontinuities. We will also discuss causal evidence derived from theoretical models and machine learning. Health, human capital, and subjective wellbeing (“happiness”) are core dimensions of social welfare and inequality in our society. They matter as an outcome for people’s lives and they matter as an input into economic and social productivity. Moreover, health, human capital, and happiness are impacted by behaviors and by social and environmental conditions – factors that can be impacted via social policies. To develop effective social policies, however, it is crucial to understand the causal mechanisms driving these factors. We will discuss fetal origins, the impact of air pollution on health, causes and consequences of mental illness in childhood and youth, the impact of income on health, trends in mortality, the economic drivers of fertility, happiness across countries and over time, and the roots of midlife crisis.
prereq: ECON 202-0 (Intro to Microeconomics) and a 200-level statistics class (SESP 210-0, STAT 202-0, STAT 210-0 and PSYCH 201-0 are all suitable)

subject: SOC_POL
name: Special Topics in Social Policy
description: Advanced work on special topics.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Introduction to Sociology
description: Broad overview of a wide range of social issues and ways of sociological thinking. Characteristics of group life. Interrelations of society, culture, and personality; major social institutions and processes.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Social Inequality: Race, Class, and Power
description: Origins and functions of stratification. Class, prestige, and esteem. Interaction of racial and cultural groups. Inequality in workplaces, neighborhoods, schools, families, media, and other settings.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Social Problems
description: Emergence of social problems. How the media, politicians, lawmakers, and others define social issues. How lives and self-images are shaped when people are connected to a social problem.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Law and Society
description: Introduction to the role of law in American society and the influence of society on law. Courts, the legal profession, law enforcement, inequality, and social change. Taught with LEGAL_ST 206-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Cities in Society
description: Introduction to issues of cities and metropolitan areas, including spatial, economic, and political trends; private and public decision making; class, race, and gender; and possible solutions to inequalities and planning challenges.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Race and Society
description: Critical analysis of the biological myth and social reality of race; factors responsible for persistent racial inequality in the United States; social and political implications of race.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Families and Societies
description: Changes, continuities, and variations in family life in industrialized countries over the past century. Key concepts in sociology and the study of families. Explanations for changes and implications for inequality.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Food and Society: An Introduction
description: Overview of past and present food systems from a sociological perspective, examining the roles of culture, government policy, and social movements in shaping such systems and future alternatives. ENVR_POL 211-0 and SOCIOL 211-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Environment and Society
description: Key environmental problems, such as climate change and oil spills; how they are shaped by the market, government regulations, and social movements; possible solutions. SOCIOL 212-0 and ENVR_POL 212-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Economy and Society
description: Introduction to sociological approaches to economic life. Topics include property rights, illegal markets, money, economic inequalities, direct sales, and boycotts.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Gender and Society
description: How our society creates ideas of what gender and gender-appropriate behaviors are. How these ideas are linked to sexuality and relationships, and how they become part of political conflict.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Global Perspectives on Education
description: Global comparison of educational systems and learning experiences, with focus on inequality, trends in literacy and achievement, and social factors shaping schooling worldwide.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Education and Inequality: Focus on Chicago
description: Causes and consequences of educational inequality. History, educational outcomes, and recent reform efforts of Chicago Public Schools.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Health, Biomedicine, Culture, and Society
description: Provides a broad introduction to controversies surrounding health and biomedicine by analyzing culture, politics, values, and social institutions. SOCIOL 220-0 is taught with HUM 220-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Social and Health Inequalities
description: Bidirectional relationship between social (e.g., class, gender, and racial/ethnic) and health inequalities, including institutional/structural, individual/family/psychosocial, and biological mechanisms.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociological Analysis
description: Logic and methods of social research, qualitative and quantitative analysis of social data, and ethical, political, and policy issues in social research. Foundation for further work in social research.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Legal Studies Research Methods
description: Introduction to research methodologies used in interdisciplinary legal studies, including jurisprudence and legal reasoning, qualitative and quantitative social science methods, and historical and textual analysis. LEGAL_ST 207-0 and SOCIOL 227-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sexuality and Society
description: Examination of the role of sexuality in the cultural, economic, political, and social organization of the United States. Sex work, sex tourism, sexual migration, LGBT social movements, and moral panics. SOCIOL 232-0 is taught with GNDR_ST 232-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Introductory Topics in Sociology
description: Introduction to different key issues in the field. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with a different topic.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Introduction to Native American Studies
description: Provides an overview of the culture and history of Native groups and how these histories influence modern Native America. Explores the current economic and social experiences of Indians and tribes.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Institutions and Society
description: Institutions in a broad societal context. How institutional frameworks apply to government, family, education, and the environment; implications of institutions. POLI_SCI 388-0 and SOCIOL 288-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: The City: Urbanization and Urbanism
description: Theories of urbanization, housing, jobs, race and class, segregation, community and social networks politics, reform policies and planning. Research projects.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociology of Organizations
description: Structure and function of formal organizations, especially in business and government. Stratification, social control, and conflict. Discretion, rules, and information in achieving goals. Modes of participation. Development of informal norms.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Analysis and Interpretation of Social Data
description: Introduction to quantitative methods: the interpretation of descriptive statistics, relationships between variables, multiple regression, and the logic of inferential statistics.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Politics of Racial Knowledge
description: Major developments in the history of racial knowledge, from Enlightenment philosophy to contemporary genomics. The intersection of politics and science in creating notions of race. Students are encouraged to take SOCIOL 208-0 prior to enrolling.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Population Dynamics
description: Social causes and consequences of population dynamics (fertility, mortality, marriage, divorce, migration) and population structures (age, sex, size, density). Relationship between population changes and health, environmental, and economic outcomes.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociological Theory
description: Sociological perspectives developed by classic theorists. Elucidation and testing of sociological principles in contemporary research. Primarily for sociology majors. Open to others with consent of instructor.

subject: SOCIOL
name: School and Society
description: Reciprocal influences between formal institutions of education and the broader society from different theoretical perspectives. Internal organization of schools, inequality in educational settings and outcomes by gender, class, and race/ethnicity.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Crime, Politics, and Society
description: Politics of defining, counting, explaining, and responding to crime, with emphasis on the social organization of crimes of the streets and crimes of the suites; also, domestic and international war crimes.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Political Sociology
description: Selected topics in political economy and sociology: revolutions, the development of the modern state, third world development, international conflict, politics of memory and civil society.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociology of the Family
description: Influence of socioeconomic and other structural and cultural resources and constraints on family structure and dynamics. Historical and comparative perspectives on the modern family.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Food, Politics and Society
description: Social groups, institutions, and policies shaping food production, distribution, and consumption around the world; their social and environmental consequences. Alternatives to existing food systems. SOCIOL 311-0 and ENVR_POL 311-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Social Change and the Environment
description: The ways social patterns of production and consumption affect the natural environment, such as climate and biodiversity. Roles of social actors and structures in shaping environmental problems and policies. SOCIOL 312-0 and ENVR_POL 312-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociology of Religion
description: Sociological approach to the study of American religion. Communities, practices, race, gender, and politics in the shaping of religion.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Economic Sociology
description: Sociological approach to production, distribution, consumption, and markets. Classic and contemporary approaches to the economy compared across social science disciplines.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Global Development
description: Exploration of the economic and social changes constituting development, focusing on comparison between the historical experience in Europe and more recent processes in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. SOCIOL 317-0 and POLI_SCI 352-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociology of Law
description: Sociological analysis of legal institutions such as courts, the police, and lawyers. Law, inequality, and social change. SOCIOL 318-0 is taught with LEGAL_ST 308-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociology of Science
description: Science as social system. Personality, class, and cultural factors in scientific development, creativity, choice of role, simultaneous invention, and priority disputes. Social effects on objectivity and bias.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Numbers, Identity & Modernity: How Calculation Shapes Who We Are & What We Know
description: Investigation of how we make and use numbers, how we know ourselves through numbers, the kinds of authority we grant to numbers, and how numbers inform our ethics.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociology of Immigration
description: Sociological approach to immigration addressing such issues as assimilation, race/ethnicity, gender, transnationalism.

subject: SOCIOL
name: American Subcultures and Ethnic Groups
description: Differentiation, organization, and stratification by ethnicity, race, lifestyle, and other traits. Maintenance of subgroup boundaries and distinctiveness. Consequences of difference: identity, political and economic participation, group solidarity.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Global Capitalism
description: Sociological aspects of the rise of industrial capitalism. Rise of industrial capitalism in Europe, different forms of capitalism across the world, and consequences for poverty and inequality. Development and underdevelopment.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Global & Local Inequalities
description: Inequalities in economic and social status, including in income, health, politics, social policy, the family, gender, and race. Contemporary US focus but also historical and global trends.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Youth and Society
description: How modern definitions of childhood and adolescence have evolved. Diversity across the lives of young people today and the development of social networks and transitions to adulthood.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Inequality & American Society
description: Introduction to research on social stratification and inequality, focusing on American society. Theories of distributive justice, trends, intergenerational mobility, gender and race inequality, causes and consequences of inequalities.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Field Research and Methods of Data Collection
description: Practicum in firsthand data collection using observation and structured and unstructured interviewing. Issues of reliability and validity and qualitative analysis.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Law, Markets, and Globalization
description: The role of national and international law in recent economic globalization trends, global convergence in law, legal transplants, globalization and the environment.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Markets, Hierarchies & Democracies
description: The forms and social structures for making economic and political decisions in modern societies.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Work and Occupations
description: Sociological perspectives on work. Work, class, status, and power. Society, economy, technology, and occupational structure; organization of workplace. Work in the global economy.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Social Protest and Social Change Around the World
description: How and why social protests can initiate major social change within societies and social groups around the world.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociology of Rational Decision Making
description: Analysis of the role played by numerical and quantitative information in organizational decision making in the private and public sectors.

subject: SOCIOL
name: The Climate Crisis, Policies, and Society
description: Examination of main impacts of climate change and of different perspectives toward mitigation and adaptation: market-based, institutionalist, bio-environmentalist, social movement, and climate justice. SOCIOL 336-0 and ENVR_POL 336-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Class and Culture
description: The role that culture plays in the formation and reproduction of social classes. Class socialization, culture and class boundaries, class identities and class consciousness, culture and class action.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Race, Politics, and the Law
description: Current role of race and racism from multiple disciplinary perspectives. Application to contemporary legal and political issues. How law deals with racial inequality. LEGAL_ST 348-0 and SOCIOL 348-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.
prereq: LEGAL_ST 206-0, SOCIOL 206-0, SOCIOL 208-0, LEGAL_ST 308-0, or SOCIOL 318-0

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociology of the Arts
description: Art as collective activity. Conventions in art and aesthetics. Professionals and audiences and other aspects of culture.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Medical Sociology
description: Social construction of health and illness; inequalities in distribution of illness and health care; organization of health care work and occupations.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Sociology of Gender
description: Gender and issues of social reproduction and social change with sexuality and reproduction emphasized.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Topics in Sociological Analysis
description: Advanced work on special topics in sociological study. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Understanding Genocide
description: Key debates in the comparative study of genocide. Why genocide occurs, why people become killers, how these processes relate to each other. POLI_SCI 389-0 and SOCIOL 379-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Seminars
description: Close focus on key issues in sociology. In-depth analyses of a range of current social issues from a sociological perspective with focus on development of critical thinking and research skills.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Senior Research Seminar
description: Independent research projects carried out under faculty supervision.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Senior Research Seminar
description: Independent research projects carried out under faculty supervision.

subject: SOCIOL
name: Independent Study
description: Consent of department required. May reenroll for consecutive quarters.

subject: SPANISH
name: Elementary Spanish
description: First course of a three-quarter sequence in introductory Spanish, designed for students who have never studied Spanish or studied Spanish less than two years in high school. Students will learn Spanish in order to use it beyond the classroom in meaningful and authentic ways at the Novice level of proficiency. This means that students will be able to communicate short messages on everyday topics that affect them directly. Class is taught in Spanish.

subject: SPANISH
name: Elementary Spanish
description: Second course of a three-quarter sequence in introductory Spanish. Students will learn Spanish in order to use it beyond the classroom in meaningful and authentic ways at the Novice High-Intermediate Low level of proficiency. This means that students will be able to communicate short messages on everyday topics that affect them directly. Class is taught in Spanish.

subject: SPANISH
name: Elementary Spanish
description: Third course of a three-quarter sequence in introductory Spanish. Students will learn Spanish in order to use it beyond the classroom in meaningful and authentic ways at the Intermediate Low level of proficiency. This means that students will be able to communicate messages on everyday topics that affect them directly. Class is taught in Spanish.

subject: SPANISH
name: Accelerated Elementary Spanish
description: First course of a two-quarter sequence in introductory Spanish designed for students with previous experience in Spanish. Development of proficiency in speaking, listening, writing, and reading in a cultural context. Offered in winter.
prereq: sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Accelerated Elementary Spanish
description: Second course of a two-quarter sequence in introductory Spanish designed for students with previous experience in Spanish. Development of proficiency in speaking, listening, writing, and reading in a cultural context. Offered in spring.

subject: SPANISH
name: Intermediate Spanish
description: First course in a three-quarter sequence in Intermediate Spanish. Further development of communicative proficiency with an emphasis on the functional use of Spanish and cultural content and reflection.
prereq: SPANISH 101-3, SPANISH 115-2, or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Intermediate Spanish
description: Second course in a three-quarter sequence in Intermediate Spanish. Further development of communicative proficiency with an emphasis on the functional use of Spanish and cultural content and reflection.
prereq: SPANISH 121-1, or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Intermediate Spanish
description: Third course in a three-quarter sequence in Intermediate Spanish. Further development of communicative proficiency with an emphasis on the functional use of Spanish and cultural content and reflection.
prereq: SPANISH 121-2, or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Accelerated Intermediate Spanish
description: Accelerated course in Intermediate Spanish. Further development of grammar, vocabulary, speaking, and writing skills through readings and films. Offered in fall only.
prereq: AP score of 3 or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Accelerated Intermediate Spanish for Heritage Language Learners
description: The main purpose of this course is to build upon the language knowledge that students bring to the classroom and advance their proficiency of Spanish for multiple contexts. The course content will generate opportunities for students to hone their oral and written skills, to become acquainted with more formal registers of Spanish and to deepen their sense of pride in their linguistic and cultural heritage in order to communicate more effectively and more confidently in the target language. Offered in fall only.
prereq: AP score of 3 or or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Language in Context: Latinx, Language and Culture
description: An introduction to the socio-political and linguistic richness of Spanish-speaking communities in the US is the basis for development of written and oral discourse of heritage learners. This course allows Spanish heritage learners to acquire more knowledge of their linguistic and cultural heritage, to become more competent in Spanish literacy skills and to develop and/or augment Spanish academic language skills. Students develop strategic Spanish academic vocabulary, learn to critically analyze a text, and write short academic essays.
prereq: SPANISH 121-3, SPANISH 125-0, SPANISH 127-0, AP score of 4, or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Language in Context: Contemporary Spain
description: An introduction to the culture and sociopolitical issues of contemporary Spain is the basis for reviewing and solidifying communicative functions that pose certain challenges to Spanish learners, and for fully integrating all language skills in Spanish.
prereq: SPANISH 121-3, SPANISH 125-0, AP score of 4, or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Conversation on Human Rights: Latin America
description: This course is the first of a sequence designed to develop speaking and writing skills in Spanish through the question of human rights in Latin American during the 20th and 21st centuries. This question will be addressed through readings, analysis and discussions of articles, literary and historical texts, as well as films. A special focus will be on countries in the Southern Cone and on accurate informal and formal conversation.
prereq: SPANISH 199-0 or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Conversation on Current Topics
description: Second course of sequence designed to develop speaking strategies and structures through examination of culturally related topics in the Spanish-speaking world. Emphasis on formal conversation and specialized vocabulary.
prereq: SPANISH 201-0, AP score of 5, or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Individual and Society through Written Expression
description: First course of a sequence that develops writing skills and structures through examination of the relationship between the individual and society. Emphasis on textual analysis and development of descriptive, narrative and argumentative essays.
prereq: SPANISH 201-0, AP score of 5, or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Reading and Writing the Art of Protest
description: Second course of a sequence designed to develop advanced writing skills and structures through analysis of socially committed art. Emphasis on cultural analysis, close readings and the development of longer essays.

subject: SPANISH
name: Spanish for Professions: Health Care
description: Advanced course to develop communication skills in Spanish for healthcare purposes. Emphasis on language skills for the medical field, specialized terminology and vocabulary, and cultural nuances.

subject: SPANISH
name: Spanish for Professions: Business
description: Advanced course to develop communication skills in Spanish for business purposes. Emphasis on language skills for the global marketplace: specialized terminology, comprehension of cultural nuances, analytical writing skills and project-based assignments.

subject: SPANISH
name: Spanish for Heritage Speakers
description: Third course in a sequence for heritage language learners. Focuses on the development of writing skills and communicative abilities in a formal, academic register through the study of academic and literary texts that examine current issues related to the Spanish-speaking world and in particular, the Latinx community in the U.S.
prereq: SPANISH 197-0, AP score of 5, or sufficient score on Spanish Language Placement Exam

subject: SPANISH
name: Spanish and the Community
description: The main objective of this course is the development of advanced Spanish communication skills, as well as a thorough and personal cultural knowledge of the Hispanic communities in the Chicagoland, through readings, discussions, writing, and interviews.

subject: SPANISH
name: Icons, Legends, & Myths in Latin American, Latino and/or Iberian Cultures
description: Diverse representations of historical, literary, and popular figures, such as the caudillo , the obispo , El Cid, Don Juan, the conquistador, the gaucho, Simón Bolívar, and Evita.

subject: SPANISH
name: Studies in Ibero-American Culture and Society
description: Issues and debates in society, such as those around gender, race, and class, and their representation in music, architecture, visual arts, and fiction. Restricted to students on Northwestern study abroad programs.

subject: SPANISH
name: Cervantes (Taught in English)
description: Study of Don Quixote and other selected works with attention to the historical and cultural context of the 17th century.

subject: SPANISH
name: Nationalism, Borders, and Immigration in Spain
description: Interdisciplinary approach to national identity and nationalism in Spain with attention to political and cultural struggles for regional autonomy and to social conflicts arising from immigration.

subject: SPANISH
name: The "New" Latin American Narrative (Taught in English)
description: Emphasis on novels and short fiction from the Latin American "Boom" of the 1960s and 1970s, with attention also to important precursors and recent trends. Focus on works by writers such as Julio Cortázar, Gabriel García Márquez, Manuel Puig, and Luisa Valenzuela.

subject: SPANISH
name: Discovering Jewish Latin America
description: Exploration of the Jewish presence in Latin America; focus on diverse forms of cultural production (e.g., literature, testimonial writing, film, photography, theater, art, music) throughout the region.

subject: SPANISH
name: Literature in Spain before 1700
description: Survey of the origins of the Spanish language and the development of Spanish literature from the Middle Ages to the end of the Spanish Golden Age. Study of representative figures and major literary developments in conjunction with religious and cultural history. Prerequisite (may be taken concurrently): SPANISH 220-0 or SPANISH 204-0.

subject: SPANISH
name: Literature in Spain since 1700
description: Survey of literature in Spain from the 18th to the 20th century. Study of representative figures and major literary developments in conjunction with political and cultural history. Prerequisite (may be taken concurrently): SPANISH 220-0 or SPANISH 204-0.

subject: SPANISH
name: Literature in Latin America before 1888
description: Survey of pre-Hispanic, colonial, and romantic traditions in Latin America. Focus on authors and texts such as Popul Vuh, Inca Garcilaso de la Vega, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz, and Martín Fierro. Prerequisite (may be taken concurrently): SPANISH 220-0 or SPANISH 204-0.

subject: SPANISH
name: Literature in Latin America since 1888
description: Survey of the modern period, including modernismo, the historical avant-garde, the "Boom," and recent literary trends. Authors such as Delmira Agustini, Jorge Luis Borges, Julio Cortázar, Pablo Neruda, and Cristina Peri Rossi. Prerequisite (may be taken concurrently): SPANISH 220-0 or SPANISH 204-0.

subject: SPANISH
name: Introduction to Latina/o Literature
description: Survey of major writers and movements from the Spanish colonial era to the present, covering a range of genres and ethnicities. Taught with ENGLISH 277-0 and LATINO 277-0; may receive credit for only 1 of these courses.

subject: SPANISH
name: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics
description: An introductory course designed to present students with an overview of the phonology, phonetics, morphology, syntax, and sociolinguistic and pragmatic elements specific to Spanish language.

subject: SPANISH
name: Spanish Phonetics and Phonology
description: Introduction to the theory and practice of Spanish sounds and phonology. Articulation and production, classification and description, combination and syllabification, sonority sequencing, and prevalent dialects. Introduction to basic principles of ethnographic research, data collection, and analysis.

subject: SPANISH
name: Topics in Language
description: Special topics in historical, grammatical, or other linguistic aspects of Spanish.

subject: SPANISH
name: Advanced Grammar
description: An advanced course designed to polish and improve language usage through in-depth study and development of grammar knowledge and skills, focusing on items most problematic for non-native speakers of Spanish. Offered in winter only.

subject: SPANISH
name: Advanced Grammar
description: An advanced course designed to polish and improve language usage through in-depth study and development of grammar knowledge and skills, focusing on items most problematic for non-native speakers of Spanish. Offered in winter only.

subject: SPANISH
name: Origins of Spanish Civilization
description: Introduction to Spanish civilization from its origins to 1453. Focus on the Roman, Visigoth, and Muslim conquests and their differences, the Christian reconquest, and the evolution of Spanish from Latin.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Golden Age Poetry and Prose
description: Major authors of the 17th century, including Garcilaso de la Vega, Fray Luis de León, and Santa Teresa de Jesús. Works by Cervantes other than Don Quijote.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Golden Age Drama
description: Major dramatists of the 17th century, including Lope de Vega, Tirso de Molina, Cervantes, and Calderón de la Barca.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Cervantes' Don Quixote
description: Close reading of Don Quijote, with attention to its historical and cultural context.

subject: SPANISH
name: Realism in Spain: The Problem of Representation
description: Theories and practices of realist authors in modern Spanish literature. Issues of literary representation and mimesis. Aesthetic and ideological foundations of realism in the 19th century, and in 20th century variants such as social realism, antirealism, and postmodern documentarism.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Avant-Garde Writers and Experimental Fiction in Spain
description: Aesthetic principles, modes of writing, and uses of media of avant-garde writers and artists in 20th-century Spain. The use of experimental forms in the critique of the bourgeois order and late capitalist society.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: The Spanish Civil War: The Good Fight
description: Analysis of the Spanish Civil War (1936-39) and its effects on 20th century Spanish culture and society. Issues may include the relationship between utopic thought and artistic avant-gardes during this period; literary and filmic representations of the war; and the war's connections to World War II.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Modern Fiction in Spain: Studies in Genre
description: Study of literary genres (narrative, poetry, drama) or subgenres (detective fiction, autobiography, the fantastic). May be repeated for credit with different topic.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Colonial Latin American Literature
description: Major texts and writers of the colonial period, including chronicles of discovery and conquest from both indigenous and Hispanic sources. Works by authors such as Inca Garcilaso de la Vega, Bartolomé de las Casas, and Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Latin American Modernismo
description: Significant poetry, narrative, and criticism from the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Topics such as decadence, aestheticism, the flâneur and the rastacuero, cosmopolitanism, the modern city, and exoticism.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Race and Representation in Latin America
description: Analysis of the history and materials concerning the representation of race in Latin American literatures and cultures. Possible topics include indigenismo, negritude, afro-latinidad, indigeneity, critical race theory, decolonial theory, etc.

subject: SPANISH
name: Latin American Avant-Gardes
description: Poetry, prose, and visual art by major figures and groups in 20th century vanguard movements. Works by authors such as Roberto Arlt, Alejo Carpentier, Nicolás Guillén, Vicente Huidobro, and César Vallejo.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Borges
description: The poetry, essays, and short fiction of Jorge Luis Borges.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Reading the 'Boom'
description: Historical, literary, and cultural characteristics of the "Boom" in the 1960s and 1970s and the development of the "new" narrative in Latin America. Works by authors such as José Donoso, Carlos Fuentes, Gabriel García Márquez, and Mario Vargas Llosa.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Testimonial Narrative in Latin America
description: Study of the tradition of testimonial writing in Latin America with attention to cultural, political, and historical contexts and questions of truth, memory, and subjectivity. Works by authors such as Miguel Barnet, Rigoberta Menchú, Elena Poniatowska, Jacobo Timerman, and Rodolfo Walsh.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Literature and Revolution in Latin America
description: Revolutionary practices in Latin American literatures as well as literary representations of revolution. Authors such as Mariano Azuela, Nellie Campobello, Roque Dalton, and Rodolfo Usigli.

subject: SPANISH
name: Readings in Latin American Short Fiction
description: Theory and practice of Latin American short fiction. Close reading of texts by authors such as Jorge Luis Borges, Alejo Carpentier, Julio Cortázar, Rosario Ferré, and Gabriel García Márquez.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Visual Culture in Latina/o America and Spain
description: History and materials of Latin American, Spanish, or US Latina/o visual cultures. Possible topics: photography, exhibitions, video practice, and visual production in popular culture.
prereq: course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Spain: Studies in Culture and Society
description: Significant issues in the social, political, and cultural development of Spain. May be repeated for credit with different topic.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 220-0, SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Latin America: Studies in Culture and Society
description: Analysis of the history of culture in Latin America with an emphasis on the intersection of politics, society, and literature and on the relationship between literary and visual culture. May be repeated for credit with different topic.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 220-0, SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Citizenship and Urban Violence in Latin America
description: An investigation of the association between Latin America and the violence that underlies all phases of its history, particularly its urban history, through fictional and theoretical texts, films, and music.

subject: SPANISH
name: Topics in US Latina/o Literary and Cultural Studies
description: Analysis of diverse literary and/or cultural productions by and about US Latina/os. Topics may include the politics of representation, cultural and social identity, race, ethnicity and gender, transnationalism and globalization. Case studies vary across cultural practices, media, and literary texts.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 220-0, SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Cultural Borders/Border Cultures
