description: Examining diverse (literary, artistic, and cinematic) representations of border spaces and subjectivities in Latin America (the US-Mexico border; the Caribbean as a border space) in order to study the processes of contact, hybridization, adaptation, and exclusion that are generated, and the modes of self-fashioning that are produced, from within this cultural dislocation.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 220-0, SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Topics in Film: The Silver Screen in Latin America and/or Spain
description: Introduction to film in Latin America and/or Spain during the 20th century. Topics vary and may include a historical survey of film, a study of films of a specific period, a comparative analysis of literary works and cinematic adaptations, or the work of specific filmmakers. May be repeated for credit with different topic.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 220-0, SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Topics in Film: The Silver Screen in Latin America and/or Spain
description: Introduction to film in Latin America and/or Spain during the 20th century. Topics vary and may include a historical survey of film, a study of films of a specific period, a comparative analysis of literary works and cinematic adaptations, or the work of specific filmmakers. May be repeated for credit with different topic.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 220-0, SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Topics in Latin American, Latina and Latino, and/or Iberian Cultures
description: Advanced study of topics in the literary traditions of either Latin America or Spain. Possible topics include intellectual history, transatlantic exchanges, literature of the fantastic, feminist traditions, hybrid cultures, and history and fiction. May be repeated for credit with different topic.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Topics in Latin American, Latina and Latino, and/or Iberian Cultures
description: Advanced study of topics in the literary traditions of either Latin America or Spain. Possible topics include intellectual history, transatlantic exchanges, literature of the fantastic, feminist traditions, hybrid cultures, and history and fiction. May be repeated for credit with different topic.
prereq: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0

subject: SPANISH
name: Topics in Latin American, Latina and Latino, and Iberian Literatures and Cultures
description: Aspects of the literatures and cultures of Latin America and Spain. Possible topics include postcolonial criticism and its reception in Hispanic cultures, notions of translation, theories of poetics, orality and oral culture, the memoir, and travel writing. May be repeated for credit with different topic (Taught in English).

subject: SPANISH
name: Independent Study
description: Independent reading under supervision. Consultation with director of undergraduate studies required.

subject: STAT
name: Introduction to Statistics
description: Data collection, summarization, correlation, regression, probability, sampling, estimation, tests of significance. Does not require calculus and makes minimal use of mathematics. May not receive credit for both STAT 202-0 and STAT 210-0.

subject: STAT
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Introduction to Statistics
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in STAT 202-0. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: STAT
name: Introductory Statistics for the Social Sciences
description: A mathematical introduction to probability theory and statistical methods, including properties of probability distributions, sampling distributions, estimation, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing. STAT 210-0 is primarily intended for economics majors. May not receive credit for both STAT 202-0 and STAT 210-0.
prereq: strong background in high school algebra (calculus is not required)

subject: STAT
name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Introductory Statistics for the Social Sciences
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in STAT 210-0. Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: STAT
name: Applied Statistics
description: Basic concepts of using statistical models to draw conclusions from experimental and survey data. Topics include simple linear regression, multiple regression, analysis of variance, and analysis of covariance. Practical application of the methods and the interpretation of the results will be emphasized.

subject: STAT
name: Data Science 1 with R
description: Series aims to develop the practical skills necessary for conducting data science while surveying foundational analytic methods with a focus on application. Substantial data analysis project required in each course. Data Science 1 focuses on data management, manipulation, and visualization skills and techniques for exploratory data analysis. Students may not receive credit for both this course and STAT 303-1.

subject: STAT
name: Data Science 2 with R
description: Series aims to develop the practical skills necessary for conducting data science while surveying foundational analytic methods with a focus on application. Substantial data analysis project required in each course. Data Science 2 focuses on foundational analytic methods such as linear regression, resampling, and tree-based methods. Students may not receive credit for both this course and STAT 303-2.

subject: STAT
name: Data Science 3 with R
description: Series aims to develop the practical skills necessary for conducting data science while surveying foundational analytic methods with a focus on application. Substantial data analysis project required in each course. Data Science 3 focuses on methods such as support vector machines, clustering, and neural networks. Students may not receive credit for both this course and STAT 303-3.

subject: STAT
name: Data Visualization
description: Introduction to the knowledge, skills, and tools required to visualize data of various formats across statistical domains and to create quality visualizations for both data exploration and presentation.

subject: STAT
name: Data Science 1 with Python
description: First course in Data Science, with focus on data management, manipulation, and visualization skills and techniques for exploratory data analysis. The course also introduces the Python programming language in the context of Data Science. Students may not receive credit for both this course and STAT 301-1.
prereq: STAT 202-0 or STAT 210-0 or consent of the instructor

subject: STAT
name: Data Science 2 with Python
description: This course introduces supervised machine learning in Python, with a focus on linear and logistic regression. It prepares students for learning advanced machine learning methods. Students may not receive credit for both this course and STAT 301-2.
prereq: STAT 303-1 or consent of the instructor

subject: STAT
name: Data Science 3 with Python
description: The course introduces advanced machine learning methods in Python, including supervised and unsupervised learning. It provides the knowledge and skills necessary to tackle real world problems with machine learning. Students may not receive credit for both this course and STAT 301-3.
prereq: STAT 303-2 or consent of the instructor

subject: STAT
name: Statistical Theory & Methods 1
description: Sample spaces, computing probabilities, random variables, distribution functions, expected values, variance, correlation, limit theory. May not receive credit for both STAT 320-1 and any of STAT 383-0, MATH 310-1, MATH 311-1, MATH 314-0, MATH 385-0, ELEC_ENG 302-0, or IEMS 202-0. Co-requisites: STAT 202-0 or STAT 210-0, MATH 226-0, and MATH 230-2.

subject: STAT
name: Statistical Theory & Methods 2
description: Sampling, parameter estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis tests.

subject: STAT
name: Statistical Theory & Methods 3
description: Comparison of parameters, goodness-of-fit tests, regression analysis, analysis of variance, and nonparametric methods.

subject: STAT
name: Survey Sampling
description: Probability sampling, simple random sampling, error estimation, sample size, stratification, systematic sampling, replication methods, ratio and regression estimation, cluster sampling.
prereq: MATH 230-1 and 2 quarters of statistics, or consent of instructor

subject: STAT
name: Causal Inference
description: Introduction to modern statistical thinking about causal inference. Topics include completely randomized experiments, confounding, ignorability of assignment mechanisms, matching, observational studies, noncompliance, and Bayesian methods.

subject: STAT
name: Applied Statistics for Research 1
description: First Quarter: Design of experiments and surveys, numerical summaries of data, graphical summaries of data, correlation and regression, probability, sample mean, sample proportion, confidence intervals and tests of significance, one and two sample problems, ANOVA. Second Quarter: Simple linear regression, inference, diagnostics, multiple regression diagnostics, autocorrelation, 1-way ANOVA, power and sample size determination, 2-way ANOVA, ANCOVA, randomized block designs.

subject: STAT
name: Applied Statistics for Research 2
description: Second Quarter: Simple linear regression, inference, diagnostics, multiple regression diagnostics, autocorrelation, 1-way ANOVA, power and sample size determination, 2-way ANOVA, ANCOVA, randomized block designs.

subject: STAT
name: Statistics for Life Sciences
description: Application of statistical methods and data analysis techniques to the life sciences. Parametric statistics, nonparametric approaches, resampling-based approaches.

subject: STAT
name: Statistical Data Mining
description: Methods for modeling binary responses with multiple explanatory variables. Potential topics include statistical decision theory, binary regression models, cluster analysis, probabilistic conditional independence, and graphical models.
prereq: courses in probability and statistics comparable to STAT 320-1, STAT 320-2; a course in multiple regression comparable to STAT 350-0; familiarity with statistical computing software such as MINITAB or SPSS

subject: STAT
name: Statistical Computing
description: Exploration of theory and practice of computational statistics with emphasis on statistical programming in R.

subject: STAT
name: Statistical Demography
description: Introduction to statistical theory of demographic rates (births, deaths, migration) in multistate setting; statistical models underlying formal demography; analysis of error in demographic forecasting.

subject: STAT
name: Applied Multivariate Analysis
description: Statistical methods for describing and analyzing multivariate data. Principal component analysis, factor analysis, canonical correlation, clustering. Emphasis on statistical and geometric motivation, practical application, and interpretation of results.

subject: STAT
name: Regression Analysis
description: Simple linear regression and correlation, multiple regression, residual analysis, selection of subsets of variables, multi-collinearity and shrinkage estimation, nonlinear regression. Prerequisite or corequisite: STAT 320-2.

subject: STAT
name: Design and Analysis of Experiments
description: Methods of designing experiments and analyzing data obtained from them: one-way and two-way layouts, incomplete block designs, factorial designs, random effects, split-plot and nested designs.

subject: STAT
name: Nonparametric Statistical Methods
description: Survey of nonparametric methods, with emphasis on understanding their application. Estimation of a distribution function, density estimation, and nonparametric regression.

subject: STAT
name: Advanced Regression
description: This course covers modern regression methods, including: (1) generalized linear models (binary, categorical, and count data), (2) random effects, mixed effects, and nonlinear models, and (3) model selection. The course emphasizes both the theoretical development of the methods, as well as their application, including the communication of models and results both verbally and in writing.

subject: STAT
name: Applied Time Series Modeling and Forecasting
description: Introduction to modern time series analysis. Autocorrelation, time series regression and forecasting, ARIMA and GARCH models.

subject: STAT
name: Analysis of Qualitative Data
description: Introduction to the analysis of qualitative data. Measures of association, loglinear models, logits, and probits.

subject: STAT
name: Hierarchical Linear Models
description: Introduction to the theory and application of hierarchical linear models. Two and three level linear models, hierarchical generalized linear models, and application of hierarchical models to organizational research and growth models.

subject: STAT
name: Introduction to Bayesian Statistics
description: Introduction to basic concepts and principles in Bayesian inference such as the prior, likelihood, posterior and predictive distributions, as well as an introduction to a variety of computational algorithms for Bayesian inference. Students learn how to develop, describe, implement and critique statistical models from a Bayesian perspective.
prereq: STAT 320-1, STAT 320-2, STAT 301-2 or 350-0, or consent of instructor

subject: STAT
name: Topics in Statistics
description: Topics in theoretical and applied statistics to be chosen by instructor.

subject: STAT
name: Introduction to the Analysis of Financial Data
description: Statistical methods for analyzing financial data. Models for asset returns, portfolio theory, parameter estimation.

subject: STAT
name: Human Rights Statistics
description: Development, analysis, interpretation, use, and misuse of statistical data and methods for description, evaluation, and political action regarding war, disappearances, justice, violence against women, trafficking, profiling, elections, hunger, refugees, discrimination, etc.
prereq: Two of STAT 325-0, STAT 350-0, STAT 320-2, STAT 320-3; or ECON 381-1, ECON 381-2; or MATH 386-1, MATH 386-2; or IEMS 303-0, IEMS 304-0

subject: STAT
name: Probability and Statistics for ISP
description: Probability and statistics. Ordinarily taken only by students in ISP; permission required otherwise. May not receive credit for both STAT 383-0 and any of STAT 320-1; MATH 310-1, MATH 311-1, MATH 314-0, MATH 385-0; ELEC_ENG 302-0; or IEMS 202-0.
prereq: MATH 281-1, MATH 281-2, MATH 281-3; PHYSICS 125-1, PHYSICS 125-2, PHYSICS 125-3

subject: STAT
name: Independent Study
description: Independent work under the guidance of a faculty member. Consent of department required.

subject: STRINGS
name: Applied Double Bass for Music Majors

subject: STRINGS
name: Applied Double Bass for Music Majors

subject: STRINGS
name: Suzuki Pedagogy
description: Fundamental principles of Suzuki philosophy and materials, with emphasis on application to violin. Open to all string players.

subject: STRINGS
name: Violin and Viola Pedagogy I
description: Developmental approach to teaching beginning through advanced precollege violin and viola students. Includes apprenticeship teaching and observations. Designed as a one-year sequence. Open to all violinists and violists.

subject: STRINGS
name: Violin and Viola Pedagogy II
description: Developmental approach to teaching beginning through advanced precollege violin and viola students. Includes apprenticeship teaching and observations. Designed as a one-year sequence. Open to all violinists and violists.

subject: STRINGS
name: Violin and Viola Pedagogy III
description: Developmental approach to teaching beginning through advanced precollege violin and viola students. Includes apprenticeship teaching and observations. Designed as a one-year sequence. Open to all violinists and violists.

subject: STRINGS
name: Cello and Double Bass Pedagogy I
description: Developmental approach to teaching beginning through advanced precollege cello and double bass students.

subject: STRINGS
name: Cello and Double Bass Pedagogy II
description: Developmental approach to teaching beginning through advanced precollege cello and double bass students.

subject: STRINGS
name: Cello and Double Bass Pedagogy III
description: Developmental approach to teaching beginning through advanced precollege cello and double bass students.

subject: STRINGS
name: Harp Technique and Pedagogy I
description: Pedagogical instruction and demonstration of teaching techniques for all levels and ages.

subject: STRINGS
name: Harp Technique and Pedagogy II
description: Pedagogical instruction and demonstration of teaching techniques for all levels and ages.

subject: STRINGS
name: Harp Technique and Pedagogy III
description: Pedagogical instruction and demonstration of teaching techniques for all levels and ages.

subject: STRINGS
name: Selected Topics
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: STRINGS
name: Applied Double Bass for Music Majors

subject: STRINGS
name: Guitar Ensemble for Music Majors
description: Performance of the chamber literature for guitar: guitar duos, trios, and quartets; flute and guitar; voice and guitar; chamber works with strings; other instrumental combinations.

subject: STRINGS
name: Lute and Guitar History and Literature I
description: Analytical and historical survey of the literature for plucked instruments from the 16th through the 20th centuries. The study of tablatures, instrument construction and tuning, performance practice, and style.

subject: STRINGS
name: Lute and Guitar History and Literature II
description: Analytical and historical survey of the literature for plucked instruments from the 16th through the 20th centuries. The study of tablatures, instrument construction and tuning, performance practice, and style.

subject: STRINGS
name: Lute and Guitar History and Literature III
description: Analytical and historical survey of the literature for plucked instruments from the 16th through the 20th centuries. The study of tablatures, instrument construction and tuning, performance practice, and style.

subject: STRINGS
name: Guitar Pedagogy I
description: Principles of individual and group study. Survey of development of right-and left-hand technique from 16th-century lute and vihuela tutors through modern classical guitar methods. Interaction between musical texture and technical innovations; influence of fingering on stylistic inflection and ornamentation.

subject: STRINGS
name: Guitar Pedagogy II
description: Principles of individual and group study. Survey of development of right-and left-hand technique from 16th-century lute and vihuela tutors through modern classical guitar methods. Interaction between musical texture and technical innovations; influence of fingering on stylistic inflection and ornamentation.

subject: STRINGS
name: Guitar Pedagogy III
description: Principles of individual and group study. Survey of development of right-and left-hand technique from 16th-century lute and vihuela tutors through modern classical guitar methods. Interaction between musical texture and technical innovations; influence of fingering on stylistic inflection and ornamentation.

subject: STRINGS
name: Studio Ensemble for Music Majors
description: Small ensembles based on studio instruments.

subject: STRINGS
name: Repertoire Studies
description: Topics vary by quarter.

subject: SWAHILI
name: Swahili I
description: Basic literacy skills and interactive proficiency; Swahili in cultural and historical context.

subject: SWAHILI
name: Swahili I

subject: SWAHILI
name: Introduction to Swahili Literature
description: Swahili verbal arts in the oral tradition.

subject: SWAHILI
name: Introduction to Swahili Literature
description: Classical Swahili literature.

subject: SWAHILI
name: Introduction to Swahili Literature
description: Standard Swahili literature.

subject: SWAHILI
name: Independent Study
description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Swahili.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Social Contexts of Education
description: Societal structures that organize, supply, and channel individual learning experiences and how they provide the formal and informal settings in which social interaction takes place, particularly in urban settings. How participation in these socializing settings molds the development of individuals' capacities and forms their goals. Taught with LRN_SCI 302-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Seminar on Teaching: Introduction to Schooling in Communities
description: Action research methods- including observation/field notes, interviewing, and artifact analysis-as means to understanding how schools work and how theory and practice relate. Includes 30 hours of field experience.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Speech & Communication in the School Environment
description: Communication in the classroom and school environment for teacher and student. Basic public speaking, interpersonal communication, creating a positive climate for classroom discourse, facilitating group activities.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Foundations of Learning in a New Language
description: Historical, political, sociocultural, and educational practices that impact linguistically and culturally diverse learners in American schools.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Problems in the Philosophy of Education
description: Classical and modern philosophies of education. Text interpretation, analysis of ideas, argument construction; relationship of philosophy to educational issues. Students develop their own philosophy of education.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Content Area Reading and Writing
description: Theory and practical methods of reading methodology to enable teacher candidates to scaffold the literacy skills of English-language learners and students not reading at grade level.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Critical Issues in Literacy
description: Continues on the work in MS_ED 422-0 and TEACH_ED 322-0, delving deeply into critical literacy issues.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Educating Exceptional Children
description: Students with disabilities, including learning disabilities resulting from human development and/or accidents; understanding and application of approved emergency, educational, and rehabilitative activities; interrelationships with medical, health, and educational personnel.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Dynamics of Middle School Curriculum
description: Identifying and understanding the effects of middle school dynamics (principles, structures, and practices) on classroom learning and instruction. Focuses on the development and social problems of fifth through eighth graders.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Early Adolescent Development and Intervention
description: Interaction of physical, mental, and emotional health and the surrounding social environment of middle school students; developmental characteristics of early adolescence; the middle school teacher's role in assessment and referral.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Instructional Design & Assessment
description: Students will gain an overview of various approaches to curriculum design and instructional models, and will investigate several kinds of assessments, including formative and summative, and how those assessments are linked to instructional design, teaching and learning. Opportunities will be given to practice grading, providing good feedback, and managing a class assessment system.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Learning and Teaching with Techology
description: Theory and practice of designing school environments that integrate new technologies and media. Taught with LRN_SCI 338-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Special Topics in Teacher Education
description: Advanced work on special topics.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Methods & Techniques: World Languages
description: Analysis of research, teaching methodologies, and literature related to the content area. Focuses on learning experiences, methods, and educational techniques appropriate for elementary, middle school, and high school students. Concurrent registration in TEACH_ED 378-0 or TEACH_ED 379-0 required.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Methods & Techniques: English
description: Analysis of research, teaching methodologies, and literature related to the content area. Learning experiences, methods, and educational techniques appropriate for high school students.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Methods and Techniques: Secondary Mathematics
description: See description for MS_ED 456-0.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Methods and Techniques: Science
description: See description for MS_ED 456-0.

subject: TEACH_ED

description: See description for MS_ED 456-0.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Middle Grades Methods & Techniques of Teaching: English

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Middle Grades Methods & Techniques of Teaching: Mathematics

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Middle Grades Methods & Techniques of Teaching: Science

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Middle Grades Methods & Techniques of Teaching: Social Sciences

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Topics in High School Math
description: Content varies.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Theory and Practice of Teaching: Secondary Humanities
description: Exploration of education theory in the seminar, plus 10 hours a week of fieldwork. Concurrent registration in the applicable methods and techniques course (TEACH_ED 355-0 - TEACH_ED 359-0) required.
prereq: TEACH_ED 304-0 and passing score on the ILTS Test of Academic Proficiency

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Theory and Practice of Teaching: Secondary Math/Science
description: See description for MS_ED 478-0.

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Student Teaching: Humanities
description: Seminar and accompanying fulltime, 10-week internship involving intensive clinical experience and teaching under the supervision of a mentor.
prereq: TEACH_ED 304-0; TEACH_ED 378-0 or TEACH_ED 379-0; applicable course(s) from TEACH_ED 355-0 - TEACH_ED 359-0; successful completion of the practicum experience; passing score on the applicable ILTS Content Area Test

subject: TEACH_ED
name: Student Teaching Seminar: Math/Science
description: See description for TEACH_ED 388-0.

subject: THEATRE
name: Production in Context
description: A combination of lecture, discussion, and production lab participation implementing the directing and design process of a theatrical production.

subject: THEATRE
name: Production Laboratory
description: (0 units) Registration for students fulfilling production crew requirements.

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre in Context: Introduction
description: Introductory course that features lectures, discussion, creative assignments, theatre analysis, research, and guest artists.

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre in Context: Analysis & Research
description: Seminar that emphasizes theatre history, analysis, criticism, research, and writing skills.

subject: THEATRE
name: Voice for Performance
description: The focus is on the development of vocal technique for the performer through work on body alignment, breathing, vocal placement, resonance and exploration of the sounds of English using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet). Individual vocal problems are analyzed and remedial work prescribed. Concentrates on developing the speaking voice using the sounds of English and their relationship to meaning through the use of poetry and selected text. Open to theatre majors only.

subject: THEATRE
name: Basic Acting
description: For non-majors. Introduction to the study of acting: sensory response, imagination, and characterization work leading to prepared scenes from selected plays.

subject: THEATRE
name: Fundamentals of Stage Directing
description: An introductory course focusing on defining the role of the director, as well as practical strategies for work with text and actors.

subject: THEATRE
name: Introduction to Theatre Design
description: Introduces the principles and elements of visual design as they relate to the theatre design areas of scenery, costume, and lighting. Applies these principles and elements to a play by creating scenery, costume, and lighting design ideas based on text analysis, point of view, and research in a production notebook format. Does not count toward the requirements for the theatre major. Course is a requirement and prerequisite for all 200-level design courses for the theatre minor.

subject: THEATRE
name: Design Process: Scene
description: Development of stage design for the theatrical designer, from initial reading of the script to final design. Crew participation in department productions. 1. Scene design.
prereq: sophomore standing and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Design Process: Costume
description: Development of stage design for the theatrical designer, from initial reading of the script to final design. Crew participation in department productions. 2. Costume design.
prereq: sophomore standing and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Design Process: Lighting
description: Development of stage design for the theatrical designer, from initial reading of the script to final design. Crew participation in department productions. 3. Lighting design.
prereq: sophomore standing and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Stage Makeup
description: Theory and practice of stage makeup. Crew participation in department productions.

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre Sound
description: An introductory class in sound design for the theatre. Crew participation in department productions.

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre for Young Audiences
description: Selection, evaluation, direction, and production of plays for children.

subject: THEATRE
name: Special Topics in Theatre Studies
description: Content varies. Studies of individual playwrights, national or regional theatres, historical periods, performace practices, or theoretical inquiries.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre History I: Pre-1650
description: Survey of the theory and history of world theatre and drama before 1650.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre History II: Post 1650
description: Survey of the theory and history of world theatre and drama after 1650.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Topics in Shakespeare
description: Critical study of Shakespeare's plays, theatrical culture, and theories and adaptations based on his work.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Modern & Contemp Theatre: Modern
description: Critical study of major dramatists, theories, and production styles. 1870-1920.

subject: THEATRE
name: Modern & Contemp Theatre: Contemporary
description: Critical study of major dramatists, theories, and production styles. 1920-present.

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre of the Americas
description: Survey of theatre and drama of the Americas; examines relevance of plays, performances such as pageants and blackface minstrelsy, theatre companies, and their original contexts to their national identity.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Intermediate Voice I
description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire.  Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

subject: THEATRE
name: Intermediate Voice II
description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire.  Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

subject: THEATRE
name: Intermediate Voice III
description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire.  Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

subject: THEATRE
name: Music Theatre History
description: Three-part course, covering the major movements in the histories of dance, opera, and musical comedy. Examination of artists and their works.

subject: THEATRE
name: Creating the Musical
description: A large variety of topics courses designed to educate students on the various areas of musical creation. Topics will cover: lyric writing, song writing, book creation, score/scene creation, among others.

subject: THEATRE
name: Voice for Shakespeare
description: The focus of the class is on the training and development of the actor's voice integrating the work in THEATRE 170-0 Voice for Performance with the focus on Shakespeare's heightened text. Students work to develop optimal pitch, vocal range, improve articulation, intonation and stress through the performance of Shakespeare's Sonnets, scenes, monologues and group work.

subject: THEATRE
name: Acting I
description: 1. Basic concepts.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1,THEATRE 140-2 (or equivalent) and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Acting I
description: 2. Dramatic imagination.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 (or equivalent) and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Acting I
description: 3. Dramatic characterization.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 (or equivalent) and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Intro to Playwriting
description: A course in which students read plays, complete writing exercises based on the reading, see plays off campus, and ultimately research and write the beginning of a full-length play of their own. The course is open to students in any major and writers of all levels.

subject: THEATRE
name: Introduction to Stage Management
description: Preproduction, rehearsal, and technical rehearsal process of theatrical productions. Basic stage management tools taught in theory: assembling a production book, blocking, scheduling, communication, and cueing.

subject: THEATRE
name: Special Topics in Directing
description: Studies wih Directing Faculty on special topics related to directing and theatrical forms.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Stage Directing
description: Studies in particular aspects of directing or in forms of theatre. Students will further develop practical and theoretical skills as directors.
prereq: THEATRE 211-0 Fundamentals of Directing, permission of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Text Analysis
description: Seminar in analysis of dramatic texts as related to the problems of realized theatrical production.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Design Process: Scene
description: For advanced undergraduate set design students and graduate students studying scene design as a secondary area. Lectures and design projects.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Design Process: Costume
description: For advanced undergraduates studying costume design and graduate students studying costume design as a secondary area. Lectures and design projects.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Design Process: Lighting
description: For advanced undergraduate lighting design students and graduate students studying lighting design as a secondary area. Lectures and design projects.

subject: THEATRE
name: History of Costume and Decor
description: Style and aesthetics of art, architecture, fashion, and decorative arts. Special emphasis on periods of theatrical production. Current topic will be listed in the quarterly class schedule. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Theatre Sound
description: Planning and execution of sound for theatrical production; design of the actor's acoustical environment. Crew participation in department productions.
prereq: junior standing and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Scene Painting
description: Traditional and contemporary theory and practice of scene painting. Lecture and studio. Lab fee required.

subject: THEATRE
name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: Graphic Arts for the Stage Designer
description: Techniques and materials of graphic communication for the stage designer. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: THEATRE
name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: Rendering the Theatrical Space
description: Techniques and materials of graphic communication for the stage designer. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: THEATRE
name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: Rendering the Theatrical Figure
description: Techniques and materials of graphic communication for the stage designer. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: THEATRE
name: Drawing & Painting for the Theatre: Drafting
description: Techniques and materials of graphic communication for the stage designer. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: THEATRE
name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: Freehand Drawing
description: Drawing and composition using a variety of drawing materials and media for scenery, costume, and lighting designers. Lecture and studio.

subject: THEATRE
name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: The Figure in Space
description: Drawing and composition using a variety of drawing materials and media for scenery, costume, and lighting designers. Lecture and studio.

subject: THEATRE
name: Textile Arts and Crafts
description: For advanced undergraduate and graduate students studying costume design. Topics may include fabric dying, fabric modification, wig ventilation, millinery construction, and yarn arts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: THEATRE
name: Period Pattern Drafting and Draping
description: Techniques of flat pattern drafting and advanced construction used to create historical garment patterns for the stage. 1. Flat patterns.
prereq: junior standing and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Period Pattern Drafting and Draping
description: Techniques of flat pattern drafting and advanced construction used to create historical garment patterns for the stage. 2. Draping.
prereq: junior standing and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Period Pattern Drafting and Draping
description: Techniques of flat pattern drafting and advanced construction used to create historical garment patterns for the stage. 3. Period patterns.
prereq: junior standing and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Computer Graphics for the Theatre Artist
description: Computer graphics for the stage designer. Investigation of available software programs and strategies for use in theatre. Current topic will be listed in the quarterly class schedule. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Lecture/laboratory. Crew participation in department productions may be required.

subject: THEATRE
name: The Art of Storytelling
description: Ancient traditions and current renaissance of storytelling. Strategies for selecting, preparing, and sharing stories in performance. Applications in theatre, communication, education, religion, law, healing professions, leadership, and business. 1. Basic techniques. Students use storytelling in presentations and performance.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Storytelling
description: Ancient traditions and current renaissance of storytelling. Strategies for selecting, preparing, and sharing stories in performance. Applications in theatre, communication, education, religion, law, healing professions, leadership, and business. 2. Advanced techniques of research, preparation, and performance, culminating in a public event. Students use storytelling in presentations and performance.

subject: THEATRE
name: Creative Drama
description: Applications of creative drama in many areas (e.g., teaching, performance, therapy, writing, recreation). Students explore the use of process-centered improvisations in their lives and work.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Creative Drama
description: Explores improvised drama as a teaching method and a means of learning for the elementary school child. Theory and practice through reading, discussion, films, and observation. Course culminates in extended teaching projects with children from local schools.
prereq: THEATRE 333-1 (or equivalent) and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Special Topics in Advanced Theatre Studies
description: Content varies. Advanced study of individual playwrights, practitioners, regional theatres, historical periods, performance practices, or theoretical inquiries.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre and Social Change
description: Prerequisite: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor.

subject: THEATRE
name: Dramaturgy
description: Seminar in creative dramaturgical research as it relates to the problems of realized theatrical production.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Puppetry History & Performance
description: Seminar in the history and theory of puppetry with an emphasis on embodied experimentation.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Gender & Performance
description: Exploration of recent research on the social and political background of gender, particularly women's access to performative expressions. Historical aesthetics: changing debates on women's participation in the public theatre and the significance of the body in performance.

subject: THEATRE
name: African American Theatre
description: Study of African American playwrights, practitioners, theatre companies, historical performance practices, theoretical inquiries, or transnational infuences.
prereq: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or AF_AM_ST 259-0 or consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Asian American Theatre
description: Study of Asian American playwrights, practitioners, theatre companies, historical performance practices, theoretical inquiries, or transnational infuences.

subject: THEATRE
name: Latinx Theatre
description: Study of Latinx playwrights, practitioners, theatre companies, historical performance practices, theoretical inquiries, or transnational infuences.

subject: THEATRE
name: Transnational Theatre
description: Study of the history, theory, or literature of transnational theatre and other performance forms.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Voice I
description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire. Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Voice II
description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire. Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Voice III
description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire. Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Voice IV
description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing, to build endurance and stamina, and help you to transition into your professional singing career. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, perfecting cuts for optimum singing performance, vocal reliability, vocal health,  and application of technique to repertoire. This year long curriculum will culminate in a capstone experience.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Voice V
description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing, to build endurance and stamina, and help you to transition into your professional singing career. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, perfecting cuts for optimum singing performance, vocal reliability, vocal health,  and application of technique to repertoire. This year long curriculum will culminate in a capstone experience.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Voice VI
description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing, to build endurance and stamina, and help you to transition into your professional singing career. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, perfecting cuts for optimum singing performance, vocal reliability, vocal health,  and application of technique to repertoire. This year long curriculum will culminate in a capstone experience.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Music Theatre Techniques I
description: Various performance styles of musical theatre. Current topic will be listed in the quarterly class schedule. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Instructor consent required.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Music Theatre Techniques II
description: Various performance styles of musical theatre. Current topic will be listed in the quarterly class schedule. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Instructor consent required.

subject: THEATRE
name: Musical Theatre Techniques for Non-Music Theatre Cert

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Creating the Musical
description: A large variety of advanced topics courses designed to educate students on the various areas of musical creation. Topics will cover: lyric writing, song writing, book creation, score/scene creation, amoung others.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Musicianship for Actors: Theatre Styles and Genres

subject: THEATRE
name: Standing Down Straight for Actors
description: Standing Down Straight® for Actors is a holistic, universally applicable voice-and-movement technique for theatre students. Students explore using natural speech patterns and natural movement patterns as the basis of all stage expression. Thus, in class exercises, monologues, and partnered scenes, they explore using gravity-directed relaxation as a way to calm body and mind - so that both body and mind can work with power, intensity, and without strain.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Voice Styles
description: Advanced vocal techniques for the stage actor. Vocal styles including performing the plays of language and heightened text using texts of Molière, Oscar Wilde, Bernard Shaw, Noël Coward, Tom Stoppard.
prereq: THEATRE 170-0 Voice for Performance, THEATRE 272-0 Voice for Shakespeare and permission of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Acting II: Analysis and Performance
description: Theory, principles, and techniques of interpretation of drama from the actor's point of view. 1. tragedy.

subject: THEATRE
name: Acting II: Analysis and Performance
description: Theory, principles, and techniques of interpretation of drama from the actor's point of view. 2. verse.

subject: THEATRE
name: Acting II: Analysis and Performance
description: Theory, principles, and techniques of interpretation of drama from the actor's point of view. 3. realism.

subject: THEATRE
name: Dialects for the Stage
description: Using the International Phonetic Alphabet, dialect recordings and selected text, students are given the tools to acquire a variety of dialects for performance in theatre and film. Principal dialects covered are standard British (Received Pronunciation), Cockney, Irish (North and South), French, Russian, German, American Southern and New York.
prereq: THEATRE 170-0 Voice for Performance, THEATRE 272-0 Voice for Shakespeare and permission of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Acting Topics
description: Special Topics for advanced senior actors explore complex forms of theatrical performance, technique, style, and cultural aspects an educated actor must consider and implement.

subject: THEATRE
name: Intro to Acting for the Screen

subject: THEATRE
name: Topics in Acting for the Screen
description: Foundational concerns and practices for screen-specific acting. Scenic analysis, rehearsal, staging and camera space, casting, editing for performance. Creating and portraying characters for most effective capture by the camera. Film directing techniques as related to the actor. Required introductory course for the Acting for the Screen module sequence.

subject: THEATRE
name: Diagnostic Scene Study for the Screen
description: Retrospective critique of curricular and extracurricular performance work in the Acting for Screen module. Evaluation of performer's range and capabilities in terms of future projects and identity as an actor. Relationship between actor and director relative to the camera. Required course for the module.
prereq: THEATRE 376-0 and two approved module electives

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Playwriting Sequence
description: Fundamental techniques of playwriting: a yearlong sequence aimed at developing original, full-length play.

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Playwriting Sequence
description: Fundamental techniques of playwriting. A yearlong sequence aimed at developing an original full-length play.
prereq: junior or senior standing and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Playwriting Sequence
description: Fundamental techniques of playwriting. A yearlong sequence aimed at developing an original full-length play.
prereq: junior or senior standing and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Advanced Stage Management
description: Problem solving in the stage manager¿s leadership role; advanced study in production realization and communication. Students will be required to stage manage or assistant stage manage a department production and will prepare a production book based on the production.

subject: THEATRE
name: Production Management
description: Production Management roles and responsibilites, production budgets, timelines and building and leading production team.
prereq: Introdution to Stage Management and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Internship in Theatre Practice
description: Practice (3 units for undergraduates; 2 units for graduates) Production and/or management activities in a theatre company. Application required.

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre Practicum
description: Research, teaching, and/or production assistance in collaboration with departmental faculty. The aim of the practicum is for students to learn about theatrical education, research, or artistic process through applied practice rather than through traditional coursework (including independent study) or external professional opportunities (internships, apprenticeships, etc.). A student may take up to 4 credits of CMN 340-0 or THEATRE 395-0. One credit of CMN 340-0, THEATRE 395-0 may count towards the major requirements; the remaining three will be applied to Elective credit.

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre Management and Arts Leadership
description: Exploring and understanding the Artistic and Business leadership and parnternship in the Commerical and not for profit theatre communities.
prereq: Introduction to Stage Management and consent of instructor

subject: THEATRE
name: Theatre Marketing
description: Partnering with the Broadway in Chicago, students will interview and be placed into marketing teams to market a new musical.
prereq: consent of instructor and resume review

subject: THEATRE
name: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite: consent of undergraduate dean after submission of petition.

subject: TRANS
name: Seminar in Transportation and Logistics
description: Yearlong senior seminar on the structure of the transportation and supply-chain industries and evaluation of relevant public policy. Students receive 1 credit in the spring quarter of their senior year.

subject: TRANS
name: Independent Study
description: Advanced work chosen by mutual agreement with a faculty member. Only 1 unit may count toward the minor. Consent of faculty required.

subject: TURKISH
name: Turkish I
description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing. Offers students a systematic introduction to Turkish language and culture. Print and audiovisual materials used to supplement textbook.
prereq: None or one year of high-school German or placement exam results

subject: TURKISH
name: Turkish I
description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing. Offers students a systematic introduction to Turkish language and culture. Print and audiovisual materials used to supplement textbook.

subject: TURKISH
name: Turkish II
description: This sequence further develops speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing, through the use of printed and audiovisual materials in Turkish. Offers insights into modern Turkish culture.

subject: VOICE
name: Applied Voice for Music Majors
description: Lessons consist of individual instruction, with each student receiving the equivalent of 50 minutes of instruction weekly.

subject: VOICE
name: Phonetics and Diction I
description: Required of first-year and transfer students majoring in voice. Three quarters: Italian, German, French.

subject: VOICE
name: Phonetics and Diction II
description: Required of first-year and transfer students majoring in voice. Three quarters: Italian, German, French.

subject: VOICE
name: Phonetics and Diction III
description: Required of first-year and transfer students majoring in voice. Three quarters: Italian, German, French.

subject: VOICE
name: Applied Voice for Music Majors
description: Lessons consist of individual instruction, with each student receiving the equivalent of 50 minutes of instruction weekly.

subject: VOICE
name: Applied Voice for Music Majors
description: Lessons consist of individual instruction, with each student receiving the equivalent of 50 minutes of instruction weekly.

subject: VOICE
name: Vocal Solo Class
description: Weekly recital hour. Required for any student registered for full-credit private voice lessons.

subject: VOICE
name: Vocal Pedagogy for Undergraduates
description: The fundamentals of vocal production, including laryngeal anatomy, posture, breathing, resonance, articulation, and registration. Topics also include health care of the professional voice and some pathologies of the vocal folds.

subject: VOICE
name: Selected Topics in Voice
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May include chanson, recitative, and non-English languages. May be repeated.

subject: VOICE
name: Undergraduate Opera Workshop I
description: Advanced techniques for the performance of arias; methods of text and character analysis; audition techniques; study of opera scenes.

subject: VOICE
name: Undergraduate Opera Workshop II
description: Advanced techniques for the performance of arias; methods of text and character analysis; audition techniques; study of opera scenes.

subject: VOICE
name: Undergraduate Opera Workshop III
description: Advanced techniques for the performance of arias; methods of text and character analysis; audition techniques; study of opera scenes.

subject: VOICE
name: Opera Performance
description: Opera Production.

subject: VOICE
name: Professional Preparation For Singers
description: Designed to help the aspiring singer make the leap into professional work. Covers the musical, physical, and business aspects of being a professional musician. Includes teaching by guest artists.

subject: VOICE
name: Repertoire Studies
description: Topics vary by quarter and may include the German Lied, chanson, oratorio repertoire, and recitative.

subject: VOICE
name: Independent Study
description: Permission of instructor and department required.

subject: WIND_PER
name: Applied French Horn for Music Majors

subject: WIND_PER
name: Applied French Horn for Music Majors

subject: WIND_PER
name: Selected Topics
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: WIND_PER
name: Percussion Pedagogy
description: Methods, materials, and writings related to percussion playing and teaching.

subject: WIND_PER
name: Repertoire Studies
description: Includes winds/brass/percussion orchestral repertoire, clarinet orchestral studies, and studies in woodwind and brass literature.

subject: YIDDISH
name: Introduction to Yiddish Culture: Images of the Shtetl
description: Analysis and discussion of the literary, visual, and filmic images of the communal life developed by Eastern European Jews and inseparably associated with them. GERMAN 266-0, JWSH_ST 266-0 and YIDDISH 266-0 taught together; students may receive credit for only one of these.

subject: YIDDISH
name: Yiddish Culture and the Holocaust
description: Analysis of modern Yiddish literature before the Holocaust as well as literary work that emerged from Yiddish-speaking writers who survived the Second World War. GERMAN 366-0, JWSH_ST 366-0 and YIDDISH 366-0 taught together; may receive credit for only one course.

subject: YIDDISH
name: Independent Study
description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
